There are 30 seats in the indoor dining area and counter seating for 4 in front of the kitchen. There's also outdoor patio seating, however, there are no heat lamps.

P A R K I N G
Difficult street parking.

Ragazza has one of the BEST pizzas in SF (trumps Tony's, Beretta, Delfina, Flour+Water and Zero Zero in my book), but sadly I will NOT be back nor would I recommend it to any of my friends because of Grace. I'm going to be nice and leave it at that.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
A group of friends and I were on the wait list to eat at this place and the restaurant was about to close in 30mins, yet they let us in, took our order, let us eat and never rushed us out and were very friendly. It was our friends birthday and they brought her a Nutella pizza at no additional cost! 
I give this place 5 stars because they quality of the food was amazing, staff were super friendly, prices are fair, and the atmosphere is great!
author: Edith G.

description: We've been coming to San Francisco for 7 years. This is however is our first time dining at Ragazza's! And the silly part of this story is, we've stayed at The Metro Hotel literally next door on many of our stays. Why oh why have we missed having such great pizza all these years?!  The pies are amazing, the kale & farro with goat cheese AMAZING!  Carlos our server was charming and quick to point out wine preferences.  Wonderful food & service!  We'll be back.
author: Marcia S.

description:
Amazing!
We arrived at about 7pm with no reservation on Saturday, waitress told me the wait would be around 45-60 min, left our number, walked off and ready to eat elsewhere, 20 min later, got a text saying our table is ready!! Perfect.

Three of us sat down at a small table, but that's fine, not too uncomfortable. We ordered the arancini, pasta and maitake mushroom pie, olive oil cake and chocolate tart. They all Amazed me! The portion of pasta is very small but so good I would still order it nex t time, the pie is very innovative, so good so comforting, its a must try for everybody! And lastly, the cake just perfectly ended our dinner. 

I really like their dishes because I could tell they made really good use of small and simple ingredients. You can taste all the ingredients in the dishes, they are so simple, yet rare combinations that go really well together! Will definitely come back to try more dishes...or to have those delicious dishes again!

Tips are that they are not good for big parties. And it can get loud sometimes. And most importantly, they take reservations!!!
author: Wing C.

description:
I've been to this place a few times with my girlfriend and we have left full and satisfied each time.

Tonight we started with the kale salad with green goddess dressing, which was excellent. The large size is two fairly large appetizer portions of salad, so keep that in mind when ordering.

We also had the Moto pizza without the sausage, which is apparently called the "Atomica." Also great, especially if you like spicy pizzas.

I would definitely recommend this place, especially if you're going on a date. Be prepared to wait a bit for a table though, it's a pretty small space.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Had two pies here and we were disappointed with both. Moto was dry, didn't have enough sauce and Bianca was too oily and over salted. Prices too high for the mediocre food, service and ambience. We missed Delfina after spending our time here.
author: Shruti M.

description:
Came here for a dinner after a long day at work on a Tuesday. They don't take reservations, but you can call ahead and they have a good phone wait list system. No wait when we got there. 

Arancini was amazing. Perfectly fried mozzarella and risotto with a perfect marinara sauce. 

Heirloom tomatoes: HUGE plate, way too big to finish. Sauce was amazing. Tomatoes perfect, not too watery and had a good taste.  

Amatriciana pie (pizza) was delicious. Perfect pancetta on top, great sauce with amazing herbs, perfect thin and crispy crust, egg makes the whole dish outstanding. Would order again no questions asked. 

All for a pretty reasonable price. Rarely do I put 5 stars when I take price into consideration, but for San Francisco this place stands alone.
author: Byron S.

description:
Service was delightful.  Interior is small with a tight squeeze between tables.

Wait was annoying but then again it was a Saturday night. Was told 10-15 mins, turned out to be 40 mins.

Kale salad was surprisingly good.  I think Kale and I'm like, ew. (totally channeled a bimbo there...)

Day Boat Scallops was tasty but not worth $28.  Never had lentils prepared so well, it was the bed for the scallops.

Pasta was OK, got the Cavatelli with Wild Boar Sugo.  Though the wine paired with it made it a gillion times better.

Pizzas, very tasty; good crusts.
author: Alice L.

description: That was the Best Pork Chop I have ever had in my whole entire life. Kudos to the chef and team last night.
author: Julia K.

description:
I used to manage a restaurant so I'm ultra-picky about food and service. We ate here last night for the first time and every single dish was interesting, nicely complex and very delicious. I got the sense that whatever you order is going to turn out that way. 

The service? I can't remember having better service at any restaurant at any price - friendly, helpful and attentive. All the staff we interacted with made it a wonderful dining experience. 

There are so many four star restaurants in the area but it's going to be difficult to just not keep going back here whenever I want a great meal served perfectly.
author: Richard D.

description:
The mozzarella/prosciutto was an amazing appetizer. It's on the in-house menu, not on the Yelp menu. Soft mozzarella on top of smoked prosciutto with Borlotti beans served with cracker bread.

Raggaza's most famous pizza, the Amatriciana, was just alright. Though it had cheese, tomato sauce, and egg, there was way too much crust. And in some areas, the thin crust was burned (i.e., black). I should have read the Yelp reviews and ordered another egg or two for pizza.

Short wait on weekday evenings. The restaurant was small, but comfortable and cozy.
author: Marc B.

description:
Four and a half stars.

The restaurant has a maximum capacity of 38, so you get a really intimate dining experience.  We started off with the homemade focaccia to warm our stomachs up for our main courses.

When you go, definitely get the pasta with the duck breast and spinach.  It was amazingly delicious and very filling.  The pasta melted in your mouth.  My friend had it and I kept sneaking bites because it was that good.

The pizzas are really big.  I ordered the margherita pizza, but it was more of a cheese pizza.  There were no tomatoes on it and the cheese was all melted together, not how I typically think of a margherita pizza.

The service was very friendly.  Every staff member we talked to was very helpful and made sure we got the best experience possible.

I wish we would have had room for dessert because I'm sure that would have been amazing too.
author: Katrina D.

description:
This place is amazing.   Great kale salad , Bianca pizza to die for.   Everything is right !!!!
Now monday - Friday from 5-630, get wine half off for their 5 year anniversary !
Heated patio in the back !
author: T L.

description: Been here twice now; good pizza! Brussel sprout pizza is really good. Nettle pizza was a little salty. The crust has a nice chew to it. The kale salad was a tasty appetizer. Note that they have run out of focaccia in the past! Cool workers, loud vibrant atmosphere, would come back again.
author: Linus W.

description:
Legit pizza. Service was excellent. 
Front of the house staff were genuinely warm and inviting. The food was excellent. Nice back patio. Espresso was even smooth. 
I would certainly go back. The prices were reasonable. 
Terrific local, neighborhood spot. Go!
author: marc g.

description: Love this place. Outdoor patio is gorgeous! Did not like the arincini. They weren't hot enough and they lacked a zing in flavor. I recommend the magic mushroom pizza! Come here for a romantic dinner and try to get a seat on the patio!
author: Heather R.

description:
This place is awesome! I stopped by for dinner here with 2 of my good friends, 1 of them was visiting from out of town so we wanted to try something new. Ragazza had good reviews and was close by to our location. So off we went!

This place isn't huge, so I don't think coming in large groups would be ideal. They also seem to be pretty popular because we came on a Tuesday night and it took a bit for us to be seated. I think they don't take reservations so you should take that into consideration. Don't come here about-to-pass-out-hungry because you may have to wait!

Anyway, the food was absolutely delicious. We ordered the potato pizza and the bucatini pasta to share between the 3 of us. The pasta was definitely my favorite, it had sundried tomatoes and I'm not sure what else but my god. The sauce was perfection! It was just the right amount of food and it disappeared within minutes.

We then ordered dessert: tiramisu & olive oil cake. The cake wasn't my favorite, it was a bit dry. The tiramisu, on the other hand, was sooooo freakin' good. My friends and I were basically fighting for the last spoonful of it. It was so creamy and delicious.

My friend and I have plans to come back here, but it's a shame they change the menu so often! I checked their website and that delicious pasta is already off the menu :(
author: Sandra N.

description:
Mixed feels - I was expecting a ton after having the best pizza of my life in Portland, so I may be a bit unfairly biased (not all bias is unfair! ;)) Here's another pro/con list to help me sort out the feels:

Pros:
- Creative menu, and presumably high-quality ingredients for your fancy pies
- The food looks beautiful - impeccable presentation
- Attentive service, and we were lucky to not have to wait at all around 6p on a Friday night
- Cute interior, despite a pretty small size. Great ambiance

Cons:
- The pizzas are pretty small. One person would likely be able to eat almost an entire pie - I've definitely been to fancy pizza places where the same prices would buy you a much more sizeable product. I was warned, but still disappointing
- Overly salty, and initially, the taste (Bianca and Summer Squash) didn't wow me. It was adequate. I will add, though, that we took home some leftovers, and the flavors did improve with 1-2 days

So, kind of meh. I think you'd be able to get a tastier, larger, and overall more satisfying product for the same price elsewhere. I'm personally eager to try Little Star's thin crust pizzas - they're a short walk from this place!
author: Shendi X.

description: Gialina and Ragazza are by far what I compare every pizza place to! Have yet to be disappointed by any of the pizzas. Also love sitting at the bar to watch the cooks work their magic. Highly recommend the asparagus and moto pizzas.
author: Jenna M.

description: The pizza could've been more cooked but it was some of the best west coast pizza I had out there, I did go with a plain Margherita which was a great choice but also has me curious how the rest taste so I'll be back
author: Mike V.

description:
We living local and were lucky to find this restaurant 40 metres from our front door. 

We visited twice and one experience was good and the other great. It was less to do with food and more to do with the service......for the good experience the service was matter of fact and lacking that little bit of energy that makes you feel that the person is really trying to help make your meal a truly positive experience. When it was great the energy was all there!

The Pizza's, or as the menu describes them as pies,  are simply delicious...we had a number and our favourites were the Moto with its tomatoes, chilies, mushrooms, onions, Italian sausage and mozzarella...so yummy with it tasty light crust. The same crust was the pie base for the Broccoli Rabe with onions, peppers, Italian sausage and fortina...excellent too!

And a dish we loved was the 'Wild Arugula' with it's beets, goats cheese and pistachios...good comfort food.

A good wine selection compliments the menu. We will be back for more Pies!
author: Mick A.

description: Alex is a great server! Great recommendations! Great SunChock Piew Salametto piccante leeks onions creme Manilla clams are Devine!! Great Italian beers and tasty vino!!! So elegant and patio is relaxing and quiet!!!! Come to this pie joint!
author: Kevin A.

description: Delicious gourmet pizzas and salads. Small cozy place with walk-ins.
author: Christina J.

description:
Not the worst pizza I've ever had but that's the best I can say about it. The staff is friendly and they do work fast, and the counters and floors are clean, but I'm pretty sure some of the ingredients (like the sauce) are not made fresh. 

To be fair I know this restaurant is not among the finest ones in the city, but to be honest I wasn't overwhelmed but my pizza. 

I guess I might go back if I was in a hurry or for convenience but I don't see why I should have to pay for something that I can get better and cheaper a block away.
author: Grethel S.

description: I'm not sure if it is bad software, or lazy staff, but don't trust them when they say they will call you when the table is ready.  After being told it would be a 25-30 minute wait, and providing my phone number, I went across the street for a drink.  I got a confirmation text saying I would be notified when the table was ready.  An hour later I called, and asked what the deal was.  They told me they had called, which they had not, and that they had cancelled my place in line.  I had to walk back across the street and show them my call history just so they would admit there had been a screw up.  But at that point they were not taking new tables, it was 10PM, and our plan to get dinner was ruined.  General incompetence is my best guess.
author: Dory K.

description:
If you're dining on the weekends at peak times, expect to wait at least 1.5 to 2 hours. Put your name down and kill some time at the bar across the street. But please do wait. It's worth every minute.   If you're planning to dine Mon - Thurs, they do accept call-aheads.

Their homemade pastas (any and all of them) are fantastic!!! The first time I dined here was in the early fall and I was lucky enough to enjoy their seasonal uni pasta with their house-made fire-roasted tomatoes. I died for a moment and went to heaven.  Their fresh burrata with proscuitto, heirloom tomatoes, and aged balsamic was so delightful.  

I took a few friends here recently in January and tried their braised lamb belly cavatelli. I wish their pasta portions were a tad bigger because I definitely did not want to share this dish. The cavatelli was cooked to perfection and incredibly soft.  

Another reason why I love this place is for their ice cream. Bi-Rite ice cream. YUP!  No need to go to the Mission to enjoy a scoop of this deliciousness.  

The service is friendly and attentive with a warm ambiance topped with comforting food. Perfect.
author: Angela D.

description:
Wow. I didn't think I would give a restaurant with great food two stars. Why?! Customer Service. I thought as a paying customer whether I'm eating in or taking out that I would be treated with decent customer service. On a late a cold and rainy night...they make you stand outside until your food is ready, even though there are empty tables inside. I had an option to wait in the front or back patio and only wet chairs to sit on for 30 min.

Unless it's cheap and good food, I can forgo decent service. There are other pricier restaurants in SF with good service that I would rather give my business to than Ragazza

Yes, I'm writing this as I'm standing in the rain, watching people eat in a half empty restaurant. All I asked for is a chair to sit on while I wait for my food!!!
author: Michelle M.

description: The pizza crust is so yummy! I had the Bianca. Arugula on my pizza is always a plus! And prosciutto!
author: Cindy V.

description: I visited Ragazza after the constant nagging of one of my best friends, who lives near the area. She told me specifically to try the Amatriciana Pizza, which has tomato, pancetta, chilies, pecorino, oregano & an egg, it sounded delicious! Who knew an egg sunny side up would go so great with a pizza? Having a look at their menu, I saw that they also offer many other types of pizza to suit everyone's tastes.  All the ingredients were fresh and the pizza was tasty and crunchy. The staff & service were attentive and helpful. Great eats, great price, great place!  Definitely worth a visit!! Amazing experience here at Ragazza's.
author: Sasha R.

description:
Date & Time:  Wednesday September 22, 2010 @ 6pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  NOPA Couples, Groups & Young Families.  Ladies in Red & White Striped Tops & Gentlemen in Long-Sleeved Tee's 
Vibe:  Lively
Music:  Staff's Ipod Selections
Decor:  Cozy & Modern.  Black & White Photographs & Red Tiled Ragazza Signage Adorn The Walls.  Bench Seating & Tables for Two
Service:  Very Sweet Girls in Checked Shirts
Imbibe:  Lechaler Pinot Nero Trentino & Meyer Lemon Tea
Devour:  Oven Roasted Local Sardines w/ Sicilian Stuffing & Breadcrumbs, Pork Belly w/ Tomato & Corn Salad, Salume Plate, Meatball Pie + Egg, Chocolate Pistachio Cake & Fig CheeseCake
Total:  $79.73
Note:  Brought to You By The People of Gialina Pizzeria
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Ordered the Nettles & AMA -- they were both so salty, almost threw up:( Gave feedback to a guy called Matt -- all he had to say was that they have been opened for 5 yrs now & they have never had this complaint -- well, there's always a first time Matt and you could have been more polite and accepted that there was a problem. Lost a few customers tonite.
author: Bonnie D.

description: Sat outside for a family style dinner. Food was great. Portions were perfect. Good times.
author: Lindsay K.

description:
Came here last night for a dinner with a high school mentor. After realizing its Gialina's sister restaurant, I was excited because we loooove Gialina but after moving to SF, Glen Park is kind of far away. We got the following:
- Little Gem Salad: meh, I could have done without honestly. It was decent but lacking a fresh citrus flavor. The faro made it kind of heavy also but a decent salad. 
- Fava bean dip: AMAZING! Our friends told us how time consuming and strenuous Fava beans were to prepare. 
- Amatriciana pizza and mushroom pizza: so good!! Pizza is based all on preference so if you like thinner crust and woodfired, you'll like it here. If you're into doughier deep-dish, you should look elsewhere. 

The service was amazing, recommending the apps and wine choices. Wine carafe and chestnut beers were delicious also.
author: Ashley Nicole C.

description:
Not worth it, there are so many better alternatives out there.

The NOT SO GOOD: On a busy night, they seated us 15-30 minutes later than their original estimate of 45-60 minutes.

The BAD: the hostess was not friendly, let alone apologetic. Even worse, she sat the 6 of us in an area that was obviously fit for 4. Instead of politely explaining the situation or offering us an option to wait, she forcefully explained that they"usually seat 6 in this arrangement." It only took a quick look around the restaurant to realize that this wasn't true - every other configuration had far more space than us.

The ANNOYING: there was a surcharge of $1.50 pp added to our bill. We had assumed it had something to do with 'healthy SF' or some other such thing that restaurants are doing to pass their costs directly onto customers in an hidden way. Out of curiosity, we asked for an explanation of the charge and were given an ambiguous answer. Our takeaway is that the owner purposely keeps the charge vague, so that he/she can manipulate the accounting.

The OK: The food is average (sub-par when price is taken into consideration.)

The GOOD: our actual server was very nice and attentive.
author: Felipe H.

description: wow - what a perfect place to have dinner! greatest food i've found til now, will come back for sure. fabulous menu, you get a real italian food here - price is on a higher level but it is definitely worth it :-)
author: Harald K.

description:
I had the farro salad and the moto pizza with pepperoni. The food was really good. Tables were a little cramped (it's San Francisco, I know) but the prices were about what I expected. 

Service was great! At one point the lights went out for no apparent reason then came back on a couple minutes later. 

My college friend recommended this place to me, and I am glad he did. If I'm in that neighborhood again and have a hankering for fancy pizza, I will go to Ragazza.
author: R A.

description:
Carb-heaven!  Crowded place but there was only a short wait before we scored a couple seats at the counter.  Note: I love counter seats when you can see the kitchen in action.

House-made ricotta cavatelli to start and was probably my favorite dish.
Bianca pizza: onion crema, shaved garlic, preserved lemon, aged provolone & wild arugula.  It was very light and the ingredients definitely complimented each other. 
Brussels Sprouts pizza: w/ caramelized onion, thyme, bacon & smoked mozzarella.  Added a farm egg on top per our server's recommendation and the yolk helped add some sauciness to the pizza.  

I'm a fan!
author: Minh T.

description: Fantastic pizza with a unique crust. Crisp yet chewy, stays crisp for a good long time. That's to say nothing of the inventive and delicious toppings. Overall a lovely experience at this place.
author: Adam K.

description:
No wait on a Monday evening. Mind you, we try to eat dinner early on the weekdays (weekends on the other hand have no rules!) so it was great to be seated immediately. Halfway through our meal is when people started trickling in. 

We ordered:
- Fried Arancini w/ smoked mozzarella & "angry" tomato sauce 
- Hand Pulled Fresh Mozzarella w/ marinated farro-carrot salad & nepitella  
- Moto pizza w/ tomato, Calabrian chilies, portobello mushrooms, red onions, sausage & mozzarella 
- Tiramisu for dessert

The above was plenty enough for two. The arancini was slightly disappointing as it was smooshier than I would have liked. But the "angry" sauce was quite good. Pizza had a nice crispy crust (served piping HOT) and had all kinds of nice flavoring. Hand pulled mozzarella salad was different than what we had imagined but we surprisingly enjoyed it although quite frankly it is a type of salad I'd much rather prefer to eat for lunch. 

No-nonsense service which is what I prefer. 

Total including drinks was in the ballpark of $80.
author: Esther A.

description: Amazing pizza, love the crust. Toppings make for nice presentation. Meatball appetizer is nothing special and overpriced, among some others. Get the pizza and some drinks, you'll be set
author: Steve T.

description: delicious food with attitude. would not seat us 2 until our friend arrived, so made us wait outside in cold when they had over 10 open seats. Noni Lina (and my mom) would probably have said, "come on in, have a seat, stay warm, what would you like to eat and drink while you wait"? then they crowded us 3 into a small table that barely fits 2, so we couldn't even fit 3 entrees onto the table; so we ordered (very good) salads and a delicious but small pizza for 3, six slices; I  left hungry, not like any Italian friends house I have ever been too. (its played up that way with pics of Noni on the wall)  sorry Noni, I know you would do it differently...
author: Alex S.

description:
My husband and I saw this place on the restaurant week list and thought we'd give it a try since we had an appointment in the lower Haight area that week. We arrived around 5:30 pm. We were the first ones to arrive, so we had our pick of seating. They have a few seats in the patio in the back of the restaurant which is lovely, but we opted for a table by the window in the main dining room since we had the place to ourselves.  

I ordered the special restaurant week 3 course pre-fixe menu:
-Lacinato Kale & Little Gem Lettuces w/ avocado, farro, radish & green goddess dressing (normally $10) -- so interesting and tasty; you could definitely make that a main course if you're wanting something lighter for dinner.
-Hanger Steak w/ gorgonzola butter, Martin's spigarello greens & smashed potato (normally $25) -- wow, wow, wow! Everything on the plate was so delicious! The steak was tender and had a bit of heat added. Smashed potatoes were perfection - soft inside and crispy outside.
-Chocolate Pot de Crème (normally $7) -- Yum! Excellent way to end the meal. So creamy and light. 
It also included a complimentary glass of Lambrusco Rose, Vino Spumante Brut (normally $12) - Nice touch.
The special restaurant week meal was just $40 - a $14 savings overall!

Everything was excellent and perfectly executed!  Service was also wonderful -- our server was very welcoming, knowledgeable and fun to chat with. Although the restaurant started to get busy by the time we were ready to leave at 7:00 pm, we never felt rushed. Overall a lovely experience. One of my favorite restaurants in SF. We will definitely be back!
author: Kathy B.

description: Color me surprised!  Fresh ingredients all around. The roasted fennel soup was bursting with flavor--maybe the best soup I've ever tasted. The pastas were delicious. A fresh variety of locally picked mushrooms with a hint of chili on one; another with pork sugo was magical.  Even the pizzas surpassed expectation--go for the artichoke one.  The chef here is incredible.
author: Dan F.

description: I really love this place.  My husband and I have come a few times for pizza and wine on the back patio. Every time we've come the food has been amazing and the servers/hosts have been so kind! We usually order the Moto pizza and then one other menu item that catches our eye.  Last time we had the octopus, and it was so good! Ragazza is definitely a favorite spot in the neighborhood.
author: AC R.

description:
Ragazza is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. 

For starters, the quality of their food is so amazing. They have made a commitment to only serve food that is in season and, even though that means they'll take some truly delicious things off of their menu, the seasonal choices they make are top notch. It's very clear that their kitchen staff really understands food and how ingredients go together. We always order waaaaaay too much food and aren't sad about it as the leftovers make great meals for the coming days. My favorite item on the menu is the brussell sprout pizza. Add an egg to it and you're good to go. Also, the arancini is so yummy, particularly the sundried tomato pesto. YUM.

Apart from the high quality of the food, the service is top notch. The wait staff is fantastic and very educated about both the food and wine. The only dark spot to their incredible service is their manager who was very rude to our server and (indirectly) to our group. That being said, our waitress was a consummate professional and smiled through it, treating us with respect and like we were her only customers. 

If you're ever in the mood for Italian food, or just a damn good meal, I can't recommend Ragazza strongly enough.
author: Kyle M.

description: Love the pizza here! They always use fresh and creative ingredients. My favorite is the the one with figs and pork belly!
author: Ivy J.

description:
Yep, good italian style pizza, great service, I'm a fan. The tables are a little small, the service is slow (not bad slow but there is one waiter it seemed for the room, in fact-sometimes I like slow)  

Rice balls were great, but a little pricey for 3. Pasta was good, but the star of the day was the pizza.  We had a sausage with the fried egg, and the Miss figgy.  MMMM, mmmmm.  

It was my birthday (well, truth be told, the day after) and we were taking my best buddy back to the airport for a 10pm flight.  We told our waiter and we got a pot du creme (complete with candle) for my b-day - always love that.
author: Amy W.

description:
so I'm at 100% parisian, and this place gets 5 stars in ambiance just for reminding me all these cool bobo restaurants we have in Paris full of hipsters, where you have to wait an hour or more to get a table.
It is loud, trendy, you eat close to your neighbor's table... and I love that!

BUT the food let me down...
I had crazy expectations, because of what I read on yelp and chowhound, because of the wait, because it looked cool... but the taste wasn''t there!

Arancini-- bland, only rice and 'smoked' mozza (that was not smoky at all), no ragú that you usually find in them, instead they were in a spicy tomato sauce ( more like canned crushed tomatoes with a hint of chili)

Pizza Moto (sausage, chili, mozza, mushroom) bland as well, the sausage was underseasonned, and there was so little cheese that they shoudn't even mention it. the dough was good, but that's all

Pizza amatriciana(bacon, tomato, pecorino) no mozzarella on this one, supposedly pecorino, but honestly I'm sure it was parmesan, and very little bacon. dry, salty, meh

Overall pricey, service was busy friendly (always better than in Paris ;) ), food is super disapointing, far from what you get in Europe. But the ambiance was awesome and we had a great night!

I won't go back, because there are so many places to try around...
author: Tal S.

description:
The service was fine. The atmosphere in the garden was lovely.  The food, however, was extremely over-priced for very mediocre fare.  

For us, the biggest problem with Ragazza is the lack of seasoning.  In our party, we had the focaccia (which was not focaccia, but rather poorly salted, crusty bread), a Margharita pizza, the bucatini with meatballs, and the cavatelli carbonara.  There was no flavor development in the sauces, and we probably went through an entire jar of Parmesan cheese trying to impart some seasoning to our food.  One member of our party commented that the meatballs tasted as though the meat had been freezer-burned.  The pizza crust was perhaps the one redeeming part of the meal.

The lack of flavor continued into the dessert course with the pots de creme (more like a mild, milk chocolate pudding), a tiramisu which seemed more store-bought than house-made, and an affogato with a generous portion of espresso, but a skimpy portion of ice cream.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
This place is always packed, but worth the wait if you have the time! For a party of five on a Wednesday night, we waited close to 30 minutes to be seated.  

Each pizza is large enough to feed two people, with about six slices per pie. We ordered three pizzas and an appetizer to split among the five of us, and found ourselves with a bit too much food at the end.

For an appetizer, we ordered the Arancini, which comes with 3 pieces in an order. You can easily add another piece at $3/pc. Though not the main part of the dish, the tomato sauce is delicious! It's quite thick, but seasoned so well. The arancini were fried perfectly, and had a nice texture. 

As for pizzas, we went for the Amatriciana, Cherry Tomatoes, and Wild Nettles. Of the three, the Cherry Tomatoes pizza was my favourite! The toppings were so fresh, and complemented the pizza well. The Amatriciana is also delicious - a more unusual combination of flavours for a pizza. My friend commented that this pizza felt heavier in a way that you wouldn't want to eat a lot of it at once. The Wild Nettles pizza was the most disappointing. I felt like it was way too salty, and the pancetta made it even saltier - would not order this again. All of their pizzas are served on a very thin crust, but the edges of the pizza are so soft and fluffy. For someone who usually hates pizza crust, this was perfect!

Overall, a great place to dine when you have time to spare. Delicious pizzas and a cozy atmosphere; I can't wait to come back!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Oh me, oh my, someone hose me down because I'm way too excited about this spot.  They have a rotating seasonal menu with the right balance in each dish, fantastic service that is educated about the menu, and enough aromatics to make the salivary glands kick into high gear simply after waking in the place.

And they serve Rosé.  

Yup, they serve the official beverage of 2014 at Ragazza, so you better keep your pants on.

Wild Arugula salad, Rigatoni, Potato pizza, are all nomtastic.  Not sure what to get?  Ask the servers.  They are honest about the menu and ask questions to help qualify what they think would be a good recommendation based on your tastes.

Keep in mind, this place doesn't take reservations, so if you're hoping to get a table at 7:00pm, you could be in for a short wait.  Just pop over to The Page for a pre-dinner drink and time will go a lot faster.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Who knew there was such a yummy pizza place tucked away on Divisadero and Page? 

Let me set the scene:
It's Friday night, about 6:30 pm. I'm in lower Haight, hanging out with a gal pal. We're hungry. 

Our options? 
- Bean Bag Cafe... Good and affordable, but not quite right.
- Acme Burger... Also good and affordable, still not doing it for either of us.
- Ragazza... just around the corner and a four star average rating on Yelp.

Why not give it a try? 

Although it's small inside, they make the most of their space Hostess found us a table almost immediately and we were given food + drink menus. Of course I had a glass of wine. Not everything is available by the glass, but they also offer small carafes if you're planning on staying awhile OR sharing. 

As for food, we split the potato, bacon and goat cheese. It sounds gross, but potatoes on pizza really is delicious. As long as the slices are thinly cut and spread sparingly across the pie, it's quite tasty. A regular pizza is more than enough for two hungry ladies, too. We even had a leftover slice, which my friend gladly took home.

We were in and out within an hour, just enough time to get comfy, but not too comfy. You sit pretty close to everyone around you at Ragazza, so unless you're really into eavesdropping or letting others listen in on your conversation, an hour is all you need. 

It appears as if they take reservations AND groups up to 5 or 6, so consider them for a night of unexpectedly gourmet food in the area.
author: Abby S.

description: I was planning on getting pizza at The Mill but they were sold out. We randomly headed down Divisadero and lucked out by finding this neighborhood gem! Really amazing Bianca pizza (onion crema, preserved lemon, garlic, and arugula) and tiramisu! Nice thin, crisp pizza with just a bit of softness in the crust. 1 pizza, 1 dessert, and carafe of Barbera was less than $58.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Once you eat pizza in the motherland - with the floppy cracker-thin crust, a smear of real tomato sauce, gritty anchovies, bitter olives, caper berries, a dash of mozzerella, all served up by an impossibly charming, flour-dusted boy named something like Fabio, or Paolo, or Antonio - after that, Papa Murphy's never tastes the same again. So, what's a girl to do when she returns to her homeland in search of the Paolo does Pizza experience?

Report to Ragazza, where Italian pizza purism meets Western gourmet adventurousness. Just take a gander at all those drool-worthy photos with the runny egg yolk over wild nettles...pork belly and rapini...potato and smoked bacon. You can't go wrong with any of the pies, but make sure you order the under-photographed kale and farro salad to kick things off. It's gotta be my new favorite kale creation in the whole bay area, with carrots, avocado and a zesty green garlic dressing. I was skeptical of the $9/18 price tag, but the portions are insanely large, most definitely family sized. 

The puttanesca pizza was calling. I loved everything about it's fishy pungency, but wish I'd known it didn't come with cheese. I felt like a deprived vegan for a sec, but the toppings were quality and just about made up for the lacking queso. 

And don't you love a pizza even more when it's washed down with a carafe of Chianti? There's a couple reds priced at $22-26 per carafe, filled to the brim, and easily equaling 4 glasses. Affordable wine in SF? Hellooooo.

Amazing gourmet grub, prompt and unfussy service, moderate prices, an intimate dining room perfect for date night (with a back patio for the less frigid months)...I must say, Ragazza leaves a tantalizing taste in both my literal and proverbial mouths.
author: Nique F.

description: If you are craving some Neapolitan style pizza, this place is top choice. Be prepared to wait a bit cause they don't like customers.
author: Tymn A.

description:
I've had wonderful dinner experiences here in the past, but their crazy seating app, or the person trying to manage it were such a mess the last time we tried to eat here, that we ended up walking away. We were quoted 25 minutes, gave our number and were told we'd get a text. Twenty minutes later we got a text saying our table was ready, walked back and were told curtly that it was not ready, then heard the same interaction between the hostess and a few more parties. 

We stood there another 15-20 minutes and when the hostess finally got to us, I asked her for a minute because we were right in the middle of a pretty serious discussion, and she rolled her eyes and gave our table away, as though asking her to wait one minute after what she had asked of us was some great offense. We left, and it may be a while before we try again.

My previous experiences were probably 5-star worthy but this really soured me on Ragazza. Technical difficulties can happen, anyone can get flustered, but to compound this with rude service is really unfortunate, because an opportunity to shine was wasted.

Mini Update: a really thoughtful follow-up from the owner's wife makes me more comfortable bumping this up to four stars from three...and the food really is spectacular!
author: Quinn S.

description:
Two girls, two pizzas, and one tiny table made for an interesting dinner. I view Ragazza as a hidden gem along divisadero! I skipped right over the starters and pastas on the menu and went straight for the pies.

I'll have to recommend what was recommended to me - the Amatriciana. Pancetta and pecorino cheese is enough to get me to order this pizza. Topping it with a sunny side up egg just makes me want to order two! No, i did not order two of the same pies although i was tempted to add multiple eggs to this one ($2 for extras).  At first I was a little disappointed when it arrived to our table. The egg was smack right in the middle?! Then again where else would they put it? I knew i had to figure out a way to get just a smidge of egg on all slices. Lesson learned - add more eggs to the order!! 

Let's just put it out there that there can never be "bad" pizza. Whether it be frozen pizza, deep dish, Golden Boys, thin crust, you name it..  I just have to give 5 stars to Ragazza for mixing it up a little bit and providing great service and even better pizza combos!
author: Samantha L.

description:
Move over, ZA. Long story shirt, Ragazza raised the bar for thin crust, almost-Neapolitan pizza. Wow, what a wonderful surprise right around the corner from Nopalito.

I ordered an Amatriciana pizza with pepperoni and it was to die for. The beet salad was rather nice if only a tiny bit over dressed.

You could do a whole lot worse than quaffing pizza at Ragazza!
author: Jay D.

description: My family and I arrived for an early dinner expecting a wait. To our pleasant surprise we were seated immediately and provided a high chair for our one year old. All of the servers we engaged were terrific and made excellent recommendations for both the food and wine. The pizzas were large and very thin crust offering enough to serve 1-2. Olive oil cake with strawberries sounded like an interesting choice for dessert but our server recommended it and we were not disappointed! Though this is not the cheapest option for pizza in the area I would say it's definitely the classiest and you will absolutely get what you pay for there.
author: Joshua W.

description: I had high hopes for this place since my friend highly recommended it. Came here last Friday and there was a little wait. We put our name down and waited outside for about 20-30 minutes. It got chilly so I walked back in and noticed that the couple who signed in behind us got seated already! What's up with that? The hostess told me that we would be next. From then on, it was just downhiill. Because we were skipped, our order was placed behind a large table so it took nearly 40 minutes for our food to come out. AND....our pizza was overcooked and dried out. We had the AMATRICIANA which was supposed to come out with an over easy farm egg on top, but it was practically a FULLY fried egg. The fact that they would even serve us this pizza with a fully cooked yolk was a joke. The manager checked up on us and he apologized for the bad egg and brought us a fresh one. Th bianca was good, I thoroughly enjoyed it. All in all, our experience wasn't all that great. They gave us a discount on the bill for the problems, which was a nice gesture, but not enough for me to come back. There's way too many good pizza places in the City to eat at!
author: Lynn V.

description: The best combination of good and affordable food in a laid back, cozy setting. It's a go-to date night spot and seems to get better every time. No reservations but with so many bars nearby, put your name in and they'll text you when it's your turn. Can't complain about that! Highly recommended
author: Karlie K.

description:
Had dinner in outdoor heated patio. Great ambiance!

Food was amazing. This is a legit Italian restaurant. Coming from NY, this place brings me back home where great tasting food and wine completes the night out in the city as you "break bread" with friends and family. But this place is definitely SF with awesome, fresh and seasonal ingredients you can expect from a legit SF.

I've also travelled to various parts of Italy. This place definitely brings the vibrant flavors you can expect from Italy. 

Come here with friends, order their best selling food and share "family style", enjoy with their wine or bring your own, and you will have an amazing experience! Eating here will for the moment take you out of your typical routine night. This place is not just about food. It's letting your palate take you places and experience goodness of every bite.
author: Leleh M.

description:
Good food, friendly staff, very interesting menu. We had the arancini starter, which was perfect in every way, and another featuring spigarello, a relative of broccoli, white anchovies, and lemon, also wonderful. We ordered also two pizzas, one with "squash" (which we assumed was yellow squash but turned out to be zucchini), ricotta and lemon, and the other an amatriciana; both were very good, with a perfect crust and well balanced toppings.

The staff, while reasonably attentive seemed a bit overwhelmed by the numbers although when we walked in the place was not yet full. The kitchen also seemed to be experiencing some issues with through-put and we were not the only ones with big gaps in our table service as a result. The one real downside to the whole experience was the extremely loud table next to us, which was only three people but sounded like six. By the time we realized the situation the tables around us had filled up and we were trapped; we were prevented from having a normal conversation in what is actually a pretty small restaurant. 

Nonetheless, I am sure we will go back and hope to be able to raise a star or two next time.
author: Ken K.

description:
Ragazza is an absolutely fabulous restaurant with friendly staff and a warm comfy atmosphere. The food is scrumptious! We had a party of 8 people for my wife's birthday last night and as anyone who's ever had to deal with organizing dining for a larger group in SF knows, these events are typically a logistical nightmare..... then came Alisha to the rescue. 

In an efficient and friendly manner, Alisha put together a set menu and got everything organized perfectly in the gazebo in the back-yard. The back-yard is gorgeous, and the gazebo had a warm, intimate vibe. We had the nicest server who made sure everyone's needs were perfectly met. The Kale salad was the favorite of the group and the pizzas had enough variety to please everyone - chewy, blistery, perfect crusts!

We found the pricing of the food to be very reasonable for the quality of the food and service. Apps + salad + pizzas + desert for $35/head.

I would definitely recommend anyone who needs to make arrangements for large groups go to Ragazza - they make it easy and delightful.
author: Danoosh K.

description:
Good neighborhood spot with a great vibe. They don't have as many pastas as I was expecting - they are mainly a pizza place. Would get takeout from here - and saw quite a few people walking out with boxes.

Dungeness crabs are in season and we got a crab salad, an arugula salad with delicious pomegranate seeds, nuts, and a yummy cheese, a margherita pizza, the short rib sugo cavatelli, and the baked rigatoni with butternut squash (the last one was a bit sweet for our liking). 

The food was good - of the items we ordered, the pizza was our favorite, and the service was great. Next time we'll be more adventurous in our pizza ordering.
author: Ruchi M.

description: Wonderful pizza and service. We usually sit in the back with our kids, which can be a little awkward when they try to play in the hotel garden, but it's always a good time for both the adults and kids.
author: Kal R.

description:
- Sucks: waiting 40 min when told it'd be 20; and seeing another couple that walked in a few min after us, finish before we'd even ordered (so lame). when seated there were 5 cleared tables. I think the hostess forgot about us in the back patio :(

- Sucks: service. They were busy, by the time we were seated in was 9:15. Another 20 min til we got some water... On a Monday night. c'mon.

- Blah: squash rigatoni wasn't impressive. Pizza overly salty in certain spots.

- Food was decent, but for the price point I could've ordered from little star or delfina, walked for pick up and made it home in the same time. 

+ wine and salads were good

+ cute restaurant, ambiance, and great back story to the mama chef

I'm complaining (clearly) and spoiled by lots of good spots. I was too hangry and displeased before I even ordered. I don't think I'd warrant a second chance for how much I ended up spending.
author: M C.

description: I came here specifically to try the Amatriciana Pizza (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/9acPdpguULGPbChPwpS3aw?select=97N3us2WmoFviP4RuEBJbQ#GfhsVkNJ4NOyH-PK7294Mw) since it's on the 2012 7x7 Big Eat list. With Tomato, Pancetta, Chilies, Pecorino, Oregano & an Egg ($16), it sounded delicious! We stopped by on a Friday night and picked up the pizza to-go, and the restaurant was still packed at 9pm. The crust got a little hard on the way over to my friend's place 15 minutes away, but the pizza was still tasty and we gobbled it up. It was definitely on par with other places known for their pizza, like Pizzaiolo in Oakland. Parking in this area is tough, but Ragazza does take-out if you want to grab and go!
author: Amy D.

description:
Called on our way over to the restaurant and they put our name the list so we didn't have to wait. Food was absolutely delicious! This was dinner for two.

Appetizers:

Arancini (fried ball of risotto)
This was ok, not amazing. Slightly spicy tomato sauce went really well with the risotto.

Heirloom tomatoes
HUGE plate of tomatoes! A mix of small halves of tomatoes and huge slices. The tomato sauce was the best and the tomatoes taste really fresh.

Main course:

Amatriciana pizza
SO good! Loved the super thin crust and the egg in the middle was a perfect sunny-side up. Added prosciutto but really the pancetta (bacon) that comes with it was good enough. Pancetta was wonderfully crispy.
author: Tiffany E.

description: Food and wine are great. Wish they took reservation though since it's hard to wait for a table without unknown wait time when you have a toddler.
author: Irene C.

description:
I've walked by this place at least 50 times, so when a friend suggested we check it out, I jumped at the chance. I've never seen it without a line out the door, so my friend said she'd try to make reservations. No dice. We planned our attack: We would meet around 7:00 and hope for the best. Worst case, if the wait was too long, we'd just stroll down Divis and find something else.

I arrived first and was slightly disheartened when I saw several people standing outside. Well, the wait-gods were on our side. We couldn't have had better timing - several tables were readying for departure and they could seat us in about 15 mins. Win! They have a system where the hostess enters your name and number in the computer, after which you receive up to 3 texts: (1) your estimated wait time, (2) 10 minute warning, and (3) get here - your table is ready! I only received the first, as we were seated almost immediately. We did wait briefly in the heated patio out back. The setting made us feel a jacuzzi in the corner was in order.

As for the food.. I began salivating upon being seated. Everything smelled fantastic. Since I was mid post-holiday cleanse and am generally g-free, my selection was limited. And yet, they had options. I had the chicken breast with polenta, cooked to perfection. My friend (who was just over a stomach bug) had the Amatriciana pie, and let me tell you - it looked beautiful. How I envy pizza eaters. Managed to enjoy every last bite of my meal while fighting off the urge to indulge further. Our service was good, food excellent. I will be back, once I can have me a glass of wine.
author: Allison B.

description:
Came here on a monday night- we waited... an hour? for our table and sat at the bar. I thought it was pretty cool watching the pizza's being baked and especially when they would reach in and crack an egg over one... kind of like dinner and a show. Damn I miss Medieval Times..

We started with wine and I naturally asked for a "big loud red" was pleasantly surprised with their barbera. 

We got the arancini as an appetizer but it was served at the same time as our pizza. The arancini balls themselves were really light on the flavor- yet the salty creaminess of the mozzarella still came through. The bright and angry tomato sauce had such a great flavor and together they were a good pair. 

We then split the Moto. It was pretty spicy but it a really complimentary way- the pie focused on the spice and not the cheese, of which I'm not sure there was much of/ it could've been missing and that would've been fine. The crust had good flavor, not under salted, chewy and blistered the way only Italian flour and a wood burning oven can produce. 

It took a long time to get the check, which only further backs up my point that this is truly a "date" place. You get left alone, you generally can hear the person next to you... though by 930 that was fading as people got more and more drunk and loud. But it's pretty cute and romantic in my opinion. And their wine packs a punch (at least mine did) So basically only come here with someone you WANT to spend time with- don't come here on a blind first date.*

*That is not why I was there.
author: Emily D.

description:
I came to Ragazza as soon as I heard they serve a Nutella Pizza (two of my favorite things in one? Yes please)

The savory pizza's here are great! My friend and I split two pizzas: the pizza with sausage + egg and the Amatriaciana (pancetta, egg, and chillies). Both pizzas were tasty, but the Amatriaciana was definitely the winner. I particular felt that the crust is pretty perfect. Also any pizza can have an egg added to it, which I feel always jazzes up the flavor. 

I'm glad the savory pizzas turned out to be amazing, as I ended up being quite disappointed with the Nutella Pizza. There was way too much dough and not enough Nutella! The cream on top was a nice touch, but not enough to salvage this.  

The place is tiny, but you can call ahead and put your name on the waitlist which is a big plus. 

This is definitely on my list of the best pizza places in S.F., along with A16 and Beretta
author: Ashwin S.

description: Since I live close by, I gave this place another shot. I have discovered that the antipasti here are pretty delicious and the vegetarian pasta we had was tasty enough (not perfectly balanced but enjoyable). I still haven't re-tried their pizza given my not so tasty experience last time. Bottom line, if there is no wait, I like this place for grabbing a light bite and some wine. If there is a wait, I would just go to wine kitchen instead.
author: Erin C.

description:
Good pizza, if you can get it, they're usually sold out of most pizzas on the menu.

The restaurant is way too claustrophobic, and the wait is way too long. I use Post Mates instead.
author: Lola P.

description:
Hands down the best gourmet pizza I've ever had.  My foodie friend was visiting from New York, and she said we had to go here because she couldn't find anything like Ragazza in NYC.  I was like, how different could pizza be?  Wow I was wrong.  The balance of flavours is perfected here, it's the Umami Burger of pizzas.  These thin-crusts aren't going to fill you up like a hearty deep-dish Patxi's, but your tastebuds will be glowingly satisfied after.  Great for a casual, elegant dinner.  These are the two pizzas we got and they went superbly together:

* Moto (Calabria chillies, portobello mushrooms, Italian sausage, mozzarella):  So good.  Perfectly seasoned, a bit spicy for me even but the meat and mushrooms were filling and really hit the spot.  This went really well with the gorgeous red wine we ordered too.

* Zucca (butternut squash, ricotta cheese):  This one was sweet and creamy, perfect to counter the spiciness of the Moto.  It also had a slight delicate almond flavour.

The pricing is reasonable:  two girls can share a pizza for $8 / person.  We ordered 2 pies just to get variety, and I got to take half of each pizza home  :)

* * * * UPDATE * * * *

Sat out in the gazebo this time.

Arugula and Nectarine salad:
Delicious shaved fennel and hazelnuts

Summer Corn Pizza:  4.5 stars
So we cheated and added pork belly. But seriously ricotta cheese on pizzas is genius.

I gotta come back for the Fig and Pork belly pizza and the mozzarella and melon salad next time!
author: Letitia L.

description: ordered pick up, received a cold pizza. Pretty disappointing.  The pizza tasted alright but I'm sure it would have been better hot.
author: John B.

description:
Our party of two was seated quickly before the dinner rush in a tightly packed table nearly rubbing elbows with the party next to us (which happened to be quite rude..). 

The food was fresh and well-flavored but the problem was that the chicken breast was very undercooked. When I pointed this out to our server, he didn't seem to care (hello, this is raw CHICKEN) and nonchalantly asked if we'd like dessert. Declined, since we were in a rush due to the slow service / food.  

Overall, not a good way of handling an undercooked chicken entree. The service was lacking. I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Helen S.

description: The wild nettle pizza was delicious. They precook the bacon to prevent sogpie, which I really appreciate. The dough is good, not perfect, but the toppings really make their pizzas shine. Well worth the stop.
author: Jim C.

description:
I honestly don't understand how this restaurant can be rated so high on Yelp? 

Our family came because of the reviews, and was disappointed several times over the course of the meal. 

We arrived with a sleeping toddler and we laid him down on the long bench at our table. After much finger pointing and mumblings behind the counter, a very rude waitress/manager came over and said "he can't lie there, he will block people trying to get into the next table". 

Are you proposing to wake up a sleeping baby just so people can get through? Have you ever woken a sleeping baby? 

We were seated along the wall, and the toddler was lying well within the confines of our table. Of course, if people do come by (which did not happen until we were done with dinner), we will certainly move. 

Enough about the service, let's talk food. 

-Fried Arancini: the fried risotto balls were good, but the tomato pesto the came with it was too acidic and sour. The sauce completely overpowered the subtle creaminess and flavors of the arancini. Good idea, poor execution.

-Baked Rigatoni: We were looking forward to this dish, and expecting a hearty, home-style pasta dish. The rigatoni tasted find enough, but we found whole burnt pieces of sage to be inedible. 

-Wile Nettles pizza: Tasted fine to me, but it was the least popular dish for the dinner, not sure why. 

-Amatriciana pizza: The pie looked great, with a half cooked egg on top, the presentation was excellent. It was well-liked by everyone, including the sleeping toddler who woke up because of the commotion earlier. 

Thanks for nothing, Ragazza.
author: Toshinobu K.

description:
Wow. I have fallen so far off the Yelp Review circuit...this review is far, far overdue.

I went to Ragazza on a first date many, many moons ago. While I'll spare you the details of the date, I won't spare you the details of this incredible place that you absolutely must try!

Tucked away on Divis, this place is cute, quaint, and quiet. Amazing ambiance for a date- provided you want to be able to hear each other. If you don't care to conversate, (is that a word?) seek a louder venue. 

Other than the wait time, (its a popular spot) the service is awesome. 

We had both a pasta dish, pizza, and an appetizer and they were all delightful...if only I remembered what we ordered! 

I will absolutely be back and continue to recommend this place to others!
author: Annalise F.

description: A great place to get pizza. You have the choice of gluten free pizza crust. The pastas, the salads, the pies, everything is amazing. Very good value for the great quality food you get. I highly reccomend this place.
author: Diorys P.

description:
Ragazza is tucked away on Divis, so you have to know what you are looking for. They don't get a ton of fan fare either, especially compared to the SF darling Delfina, but their food is five star and has had me coming back for more again and again.

All of the pizzas are great, my personal favorite being the Moto because I love housemade sausage on a pizza. It's also a little spicy with Calabrian chilies, precluding the need for my normal Sriracha. Also featured are big beautiful portabella mushrooms, red onion, & mozzarella. My only complaint on some of the other pizzas that feature bacon is that they actually put too much bacon....but is that really a complaint? I don't know.

Lastly, the warm pulled mozzarella with sage, olive oil and heirloom tomatoes is seriously the stuff dreams are made of. I am addicted. It may be seasonal though, so get it while the getting's good!

Only drawback to Ragazza is that yes, it's busy pretty much all the time. I typically order to go and pick it up since I live in the neighborhood. If that's not an option, or you are looking to dine out, expect at least a 30 minute wait. Because the place is so small inside, that wait will typically take place outside or at another bar. Luckily, they take your phone number and text you so you will be able to go get a drink at The Page or Vinyl while you wait.
author: Serena Q.

description:
Came here with the girl and two good friends. We shared 3 pies: 

1. Margherita - tasty, huge basil leaves and light on the mozzarella but still excellent.
2. Mariquita Farms - this was very cheesy and heavier, but man that smoked bacon was really good. Hint of sweet and savory. 
3. Miss Figgy - quite possibly the best one of the three here. Figs, onion and pork belly is such a good combo...sweet and savory again.

We also had a salad: Wild Arugula w/ Black Mission figs, fennel, goat cheese & pistachios  - excellent.

Bottom line this is one of those places where I am both excited and hesitant to try anything else because what I had was all so good and I want it again. On the other hand, everything else looked really good when I would see things going to other tables. 

Will be back.
author: Derek S.

description:
One of my favorite thin crust pizza places in the city! I earned a Dukedom for this place, and I can't believe I haven't reviewed it yet. For shame... but better late than never!

Ok peeps, this place is STELLAR. Everything from the food to the service is great. Let's dive into this deliciousness!

PIZZA:
*Amatriciana (5 stars - $16, +$2 for extra egg): Runny egg on yo pizza? Say no more! This pizza always comes out perfectly. It's full of flavor (tomato/pancetta/chilis/oregano/egg), and the crust is always baked to a tee - really crispy without being burnt. I usually add an extra egg when I dine in, but if you get it for take out, just cook up an extra egg for yourself and put it on!

*Moto (4 stars - $16): The ingredients on this pizza are a bit more traditional (tomato, sausage, mushroom, chilis, onions), but it's still one of my staples. The only reason why I ding a star is because the crust on this one is sometimes inconsistent. It's not as crispy as the Amatriciana, but sometimes it's softer than other times.

*Heirloom Tomatoes (4.5 stars - $20): Bacon + lots of veggies (tomatoes, arugula, basil)! OM NOM.  The pizza crust always comes out really crispy, like the Amatriciana. And I LOVE all the fresh veggies that top this pizza. I feel like the bacon makes the pizza a tad bit too salty during some bites, but for the most part, this pizza is delicious.

Ragazza often has some other seasonal specials on their menu, which I also recommend! But most of their pizzas (Amatriciana/Moto/Margherita/etc.) are usually always on the menu.

SERVICE:
Everyone is really friendly here and fairly attentive. And even though I don't like revealing this secret, I suppose I will for my fellow Yelpers' sake... sighh... I hear lines can be long, but usually if you have a good idea of what time you want to go, you can call in advance to put your name down. And they usually have a table by the time you arrive.

I genuinely love this place. It's perfect for a casual date night or for a party of 4 (more than 4 can get a little tough, I imagine). There's a good variety of wine, appetizers, pasta (though I haven't tried any yet!), and pizza for everyone to choose. If you haven't tried this place... GET ON IT!
author: Jennifer L.

description: OK ok ok you already know about the Moto pizza (it was spicy and great) and the wild nettles yada yada yada.  But let me say something about the mozzarella appetizer: it's PERFECT.  Usually I like to hate on "mozzarella dishes" because they are under salted.  This one wasn't.  And it was warm.  And with perfect amounts of fennel and dressing.  And these toasted crust thingies that are like the magically perfect edges of a wood fired oven's thin crust pizza.  It also had some asparagus and prosciutto, which, to my surprise paled next to the mozzarella.  DO it.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Its ALL good !  Yep.  Small place.  Scored a table on Sunday night at 7:30 with very little wait.  Timing was good I'm guessing.  

Ordered:
Warm Olives - perfect - fresh nice
Arancini rice balls. Stuffed with mozzarella and a great flavor but even better in the dense sun dried tomato sauce they were siting atop of .
Little Gem salad.  Everything I love in a salad in perfect proportion.  And a totally great green goddess dressing I have forgotten how good it can be.
Pasta - house made Cavatelli - A bit overcooked but the creamy , cheesy sauce, guanciale and other ingredients made it disappear faster than david blaine.

And the pizza...
What most people are getting and a good reason for it.  A great dough/crust.  Puffed but still dense. A solid crisp back to front but still tender enough eat without a tug of war.  Excellent flavor all by itself.  The necessary sign of a great pie.   Nicely charred on edges and bottom. That means a perfect cook.   Great range of toppings including the usual trendy ones but a few with a twist as well.  Got the Wild Nettles and the Amatriciana pies.  The Amatriciana had a great sauce but it was spicy.  But so good I ate it anyways despite knowing heartburn might follow.  

Now this is not as good as Pizzeria Mozza crust in Los Angeles,  or maybe Delphina is a bit better as well.  But this is a close cousin and damned near tops in pizza land.  

Price is of course trendy pizza out of this world, but they are good sized and if you have any bit of decorum or nice waistline you can share with an ap and still be happy.  But you will be happier if you get a whole one!

Deserts all sounded great but we passed.

Total bill for 4 with a 4 glass carafe of wine was $120.  

So many new great pizza choices, so little time.  What to do?  Pizza for breakfast!!
author: Bruce M.

description:
Great pizza spot in the city.  I had read so many things about Ragazza that I needed to check it out and was not disappointed.  We got there early for dinner on a beautiful night so was able to enjoy the backyard patio which felt like I was eating in my friend's backyard.  The service was good and the food was even better.

We started off with a small little gem salad (definitely enough to share between two people) and then ordered two pizzas because we wanted some to take home.  We got the popular Amatriciana which was awesome and the Bianca which was really good too.  Dessert was a little disappointing so I'd skip that and stick with the good pies.
author: Blake B.

description: We've been here three/four times and I have yet to write a review! They food and service are both fantastic. They tweak their menu regularly, based on ingredients, so you only taste the freshest and best. The only thing to recommend would be a better wine and beer selection. They are a bit limited and it's nice to have a good glass with good food.
author: Zara S.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and have been wanting to try Ragazza for a while now. The one slight drawback is that it can be very difficult to get a table without a long wait. But that's what you get when you serve amazing food in a tiny restaurant. Comes with the territory. 

My boyfriend and I shared the Moto pie. Their pizzas have a super thin, crunchy, delicious crust. The kale salad was an unexpected favorite. We kept saying "wow, this looks pretty average, so I don't know what they put in here to make it taste so amazing!" I'd come back here just for that.
author: Rachel Y.

description:
Ragazza has made it's way into my top 5 favorite date places in SF.

Took the GF here last week and we had an incredible time.  We sat at the bar adjacent to the kitchen and had a great time watching food being prepped and talking with the kitchen staff.

Overall our service was great, although the hostess is a bit short and snappy at times. I understand given the no rez policy and the typical long waits on weekend things get hectic, but at the end of the day you need to be a bit less snappy with your customers. Your biz exists b/c you have patrons, not in spit of them. Our server was a gem and she took care of us in incredible fashion.

On to the Food. We had the arugula salad and the Moto pie. The Arugula salad was fresh and had peaches that were an incredible compliment to the dressing and bitter flavor of the arugula.

For our pizza, we had the Moto and the Marquita.  My fav was the Moto. The chile flavor and sauce were a spicy surprise and had me looking for more slices after we polished it all off.

I'll be back and can't wait to have another slice of the Moto.
author: Justin O.

description:
We were searching all over the city for a small, quiet venue with great food and a cozy ambiance for our small wedding party of 20. We were referred here on our way out of town, sent an email and received an immediate phone call from the owners while they were enjoying their vacation.

Ragazza has a beautiful private courtyard in the back of their space with a completely covered tent. The weather was perfect for us, but the radiant heaters would have kept us cozier if we had needed it. We let them work their magic with the menu but they were still able to accommodate some minor requests and everyone left our party happy and stuffed. We had course after course and everything was delicious. The service was incredible, nothing was for want.

If you're looking for a place to have a quiet party and enjoy your company and great food, Ragazza is the best in the city!
author: REBECCA P.

description:
What we devoured: 

Moto: 4 stars! It had tomato, calabrian chilies, portobello mushrooms, red onions, sausage & mozzarella on top of thin crust pizza with bubbly/crispy crust. Highly recommend this one.

Potato: 3 stars. It had smoked bacon, leeks, thyme & dolce gorgonzola and we added an egg on top (+2$) I thought this was just alright... reminded me a bit of a breakfast sandwich. 

Good service and we got our food quickly.
author: Emily C.

description:
What a great dinner!  Came here on a sunday night and there were a total of 6 of us.  Any more people would be too many.  We had to wait for 30 min (apparently there is always a wait here though, but we just went across the street to The Page for a beer and before we knew it, it was our turn).  

The pizza was amazing...the Amatriciana is definitely a must get.  It comes with one, but order additional eggs with it.  The brocolli rabe was a little too brocolli-tasting for my taste...perhaps not cooked through enough.  Enjoy with a bottle of wine and your golden!
author: Justin L.

description:
I have only gotten take out here as I feel my stony countenance is unacceptable in their environment. This is the type of place that I go to for pick up because I do not feel hip/elite enough to go and dine in.  

Well on to the pie.  Really good. authentic. great ingredients. The Moto pie is recommended  as is the Rapini Greens pie.  Pricey but if u value a good thin crust pizza, it is a nice once in a while treat!
author: Chelsey G.

description:
One last stop on the SF Neapolitan pizza trail for this visit to the Bay Area: Ragazza. Terrific pizza. Nice menu of antipasti and a couple of non-pizza entrées as well as intriguing pizzas. Hip vibe. Good time overall.

Pizza was delectable. We had wild nettle with portobellos and pancetta. The crust was puffy at the edge, blistery and had a crisper shell that other Neapolitan pizza I've eaten; it also had a toasty note that reminded me of Asian rice crackers. The toppings played well together, though the slabs of pancetta concentrated the saltiness and were tricky to bite off gracefully (if I were cooking, I'd break the pancetta into smaller pieces - and look for a less-salty pancetta).An arugula salad with pear and goat cheese was top-notch -- terrific ingredients and excellent flavor balance. We splurged and had two desserts: affogatto was full-flavored and delicious, and BiRite Brown Sugar Ginger Caramel Swirl ice cream was divine. The only thing we had that was disappointing was a bottle of primitivo - it was uncnaracteristically thin and just a little sharp (not "off," just not a very good wine).

I'm not much for "hip" places, but this was OK, although our server could have been a little warmer and more engaging. The room is cute. The noise was not too bad, the music was good, the dim lighting was mostly negotiable. I am greatly in favor of reservations, but we came early so didn't have to wait. And ultimately, the food ruled.

Although a little different than other Neapolitan pizza, this was exceptional and is now tied for 1st place in my Neapolitan affections. I'll be back next time I'm in town...
author: Comensal A.

description: 4 maybe 5 stars for the patio atmosphere ...4 maybe 5 stars for the service...3 stars at best for the food...btw...10 stars for the house wine !!!
author: Martin C.

description:
I really don't understand how this place is rated so highly.

It was a forty-five minute wait at 8pm on a Thursday, which we were fine with.  We just went to a nearby bar while waiting on the text.  When we did receive the text, we walked over to learn that they made a mistake and the table hadn't freed up, the customer had just gone to the restroom.  So we head to wait outside in the freezing cold for another 10 minutes. Which is fine...if the food was amazing.  And sadly, it really wasn't.  

Too salty.  Had the lamb meatballs and it was almost inedible.  The pizza we ordered was the "Wild Nettles."  I took the bacon off, and it tasted like I was eating cardboard.  My bf only had a slice because the bacon was too salty.  A slice of pizza each later, we really didn't want the pizza anymore.  Sad because we were pretty starving.  

The service was sub-par. 

The redeeming quality of the place had to have been the cozy atmosphere.  It was warm inside, which I appreciated! 

Not sure that I'd ever go here again, though.
author: Ghizal A.

description:
Tastes exactly like Gialina, same type of thin crust pizza. 

My favorites are still Zero Zero, Flour and Water, and Mozzeria. The flavors there are just tastier, and the dough just more chewy.
author: Jess C.

description:
Having pizza back to back to back in the same week does give you perspective about which ones are good and which ones might be just hype.  Earlier in the week, I had Zero Zero, then a couple of days later I had Pizzeria Delfina.  A couple of days from then is now, and now is Ragazza. 

We had the Ricotta Cavatelli w/ braised pork sugo & Parmigiano Reggiano and the Wild Nettles w/ portobello mushroom, pancetta, red onions & provolone with an egg.  

The Cavatelli had good flavor and texture.  The pork in the sugo stood out pretty well.  The prortion was pretty small. If I ordered this pasta for myself and only for myself, I would  still be hungry aftewords.  A good plate tho.

The Wild Nettles pizza was good.  The flavors complimented each other well.  They forgot the egg with our pizza.  So they had to fry it on the side, and put it on top.  I got a feeling that I was cheated somehow.  I wonder how it tastes with the egg baked in.  The crust was good, but not Zero Zero or Delfina good.  

Maybe if I didn't have the other two places before my rating might have been higher...but its all about perspective, and I just thought it didn't stand up to the other places.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Really good food. My husband and I shared the Amatriciana pizza with an extra farm egg. It was yummy. We also shared a lamb ragu pasta dish that was also very good.

The wait was very long, in my opinion. About 50 minutes, and we arrived at around 8:45pm on a Saturday night.
author: Faith C.

description:
Dear Ragazza,

Don't call to tell us you have room to seat us and then proceed to make us wait around for another half an hour. And then shove us into a tiny little corner that clearly is not meant for our party's size just to try to make up for your error. That pissed me off.

I was not pleased by the hostess' service, nor decision making. Clearly there were tables that opened that could have seated us, but you decided to let not one, but 4 or 5 other groups seat before us - most of which who were walk-ins. That pissed me off.

Just based on how we were treated, I don't expect to come back. But I will speak honestly about their food:
- Pizza: good selection of interesting toppings; I ordered a margherita to benchmark and I thought the crust was pretty good. Needs more cheese and perhaps a less sour tomato sauce though. For their pizza with the fried egg - tasty but perhaps a bit salty.
- Pork belly: pretty decent. Only had a little piece of pork, but it seemed fairly tender.
- Tiramisu: not too shabby
- Nutella Pizza: this would taste better if it were thin crust.

Again, based on the wait and service, I can find other places that will serve me equally or better pizzas without the hassle - getting pissed off doesn't really make me enjoy my meals more.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
I have been to Ragazza a few times.  I really like the thin style pizza and cozy environment.  Note that it may be too cozy for some.  They seat you REALLY close to others and you will hear your neighbors conversation.  Also, the wait can be up to an hour and half so don't come starving.  
As for the food, I have only had the pizza, which is great and always came out to the table once it left the oven.  
Now, the two star deletion goes to the hostess.  I have NEVER heard anyone who is in customer service speak to their patrons that way.  She was rude, arrogant, and sarcastically aggressive.  When our table was ready she walked us to the dining area from the back and instead of seating us, she passively jetted into the kitchen.  We had to ask which table was ours.  If I was the owner/manager at Ragazza she would be gone.
author: Kra C.

description:
OMG This place has pork belly pizza!?!?  I came here hoping to grab a bite and was put off a bit like the long wait time.  I ended up getting a drink and coming back later.  My friend and I got the kale salad and the pork belly pizza.

The salad was not bad.  I'm not generally a huge fan of kale, but I liked how this had an assortment of ingredients.  

The pork belly pizza.  Great taste of pork belly.  The pizza is above average, but I think that in the italian pizza category, Pizzaria Delfina is the definite winner.  This crust, although thin, wasn't as tasty as delfina's.  

Otherwise good service for the most part, although at times it was hard to get their attention. Wine was good too!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
My pizza didn't have cheese on it. This was very unnerving. It didn't list cheese on the menu, but I made the incorrect assumption so it WAS my fault, but a pizza without cheese is...odd.

I sampled a dining companions pasta with pork belly that was absolutely phenomenal, and their warmed olive appetizer and Salumi plate were also very tasty. not a big beer selection but this is more of a wine place anyway.

They have a nice patio out back to wait for a table which we found very pleasant,. but we were disappointed to be told a 30-minute wait and when we checked in again, were told our table had been given away to a VIP and we ended up waiting a full hour. Not very festive for a birthday dinner. :(

It was a little spendy but very good food so in my opinion worth it. Parking is ridic though, stick with MUNI.
author: Cristina B.

description:
Excellent neighborhood pizzeria plus.  

I'm writing this as part of a roundup on the best pizza in the city, so I'm going to focus just on the pies.  However, definitely order some of the appetizers; they are quite good.

Anyway, the pizza here is made neopolitan classic; thin, chewy crust cooked hot enough to scortch the bubbles. Nice dough, and a very interesting assortment of toppings, including things like swiss chard and corn with ricotta salata.  However, it's not 211; while their pizza flavor cominations are interesting, they don't always balance well, and can be too salty, smoky or way too much arugula.

Still, definitely one of the top 10 pizzas in the city.  Also, decent wine list.
author: Josh B.

description:
