San Francisco is lucky to have a ton of great thin crust pizza joints. In any other city I'm sure ragazza would be among the best, but by sf standards I'd say it's squarely in the middle of the pack. Tony's is still my fav by far.

Kale salad: a hearty winter salad, pretty good
Chicken liver pate: pretty average
Moto pizza with farm egg: pretty forgettable toppings-wise, though there was nice chew in the crust. A bit too crackery in parts though
Olive oil cake: kinda a let down, basically pound cake with whipped cream

On the plus side - service was fast and friendly, you can call ahead to get in the waitlist and track your progress through an app (convenient).

If I lived within a few blocks it's a nice neighborhood pizza place, but I wouldn't go out of my way.
author: dana n.

description:
This is actually the first yelp review I have ever written. I work in a service based industry so I know how important having good customer service is and how online reviews can really make/break an establishment's reputation... that being said, I feel like my experience is worth sharing so that others don't make the same mistake of coming here with a large party. 
Due to poor communication between the manager and their staff I was forced to pay a $50 fee for 'private' use of their back patio. The only problem is that they seated/served other parties outside while my group was there and then refused to refund me the $50 fee after being told on the phone several days prior that they would. Their managers emails have been short and condescending. Seems like a common trend for him based off reading several other reviews on yelp. Large parties - take your business elsewhere unless you feel like putting up with this type of bs! Such a shame that a restaurant with great food and a great ambiance can leave one with such a bad taste in their mouth due to poor management.
author: Jamie Z.

description:
DROP AN EGG ON IT. 

Five simple words. One simple egg. A lifetime of happiness. 

Seriously that's like my life motto. DAEOI is my version of YOLO. So I was really happy to see that this was a restaurant that very prominently dropped an egg on their pizzas. We stopped here before heading to a show at the Independent, and were hungrier than first world citizens really have a right to be. 

They don't take reservations so we called in 20 min before to put our name on the "waitlist". They pegged us at a 35 min wait and to their credit that estimate was spot on.... sort of. 

We were seated in 35 minutes, alright, but our waitress was nowhere to be found. When she did show up she disappeared the moment she saw we had not fully decided our order. I'm used to ladies running away from me, but it was her job to at least stay in my immediate vicinity while I tried to order. She reappeared some 10-15 minutes later, just as our stomachs grumbled for her head. 

I wanted to take a star off for her, but she was balanced out by the great hostess that night. She noticed we weren't being served and tried to help us out. She also smiled, which was super great and a marked improvement over our waitress. She and the waitress basically existed in a perfect equilibrium with one another.

Anyways, the FOOD:
We skipped the antipasto and got right to THE GOODS. Two pizzas for two small people. We don't mess around. We ordered: 

Amatriciana - tomato, Olli pancetta, chilies, pecorino, oregano & farm egg  
 
Potato w/ smoked bacon, leeks, thyme & dolce gorgonzola 

And they were excellent. They hit all the spots I needed hit and some spots I didn't know I had. AND THEY DROPPED AN EGG ON IT! Excellent. We finished that up right quick.
author: Salman Q.

description:
We live in the neighborhood and have come many times over the years.

The food varies from good to great, depending on the season and the dish. The tomato bacon pizza in summer is divine.

The service here used to be consistently warm and friendly, and we really miss the previous hostess. But for a while now they've had a frostier group, many of whom seem to not like kids. 

We definitely liked it more two years ago. Food's generally pretty good though.
author: L. K.

description:
It was my first "big kid" experience in San Francisco and ended up staying at the hotel next door, so my attention to Ragazza came and went in my haste to explore the area. After a long day of walking throughout the city, I decided to be lazy and wander over for a slice. Um. Wow. 

My friends and I focused on pizza, particularly the white pizza with arugula and lemon zest. This may have just become my new favorite pie of all time, and I am no stranger to really good pizza (I did live in New York for a long time). The atmosphere was warm and delightful - such a treat to experience the outdoor gazebo during springtime. 

I don't think you could go wrong with anything on this menu, so go ahead and dig in! As for me, next time I stay in SF, I'm going to need to stay further away so I don't eat every dinner there.
author: Allison P.

description:
We got here about 8:30 on a Wednesday night. We were told it would be about an hour wait. After an hour, we checked back in, and they still were not ready for us. After about an hour and a half, we got a table. It took almost 10 minutes for us to receive menus and give our drink order to the server. It took another 15 to order our food.

I ordered a chicken breast dish. It listed the chicken and the vegetable. It DID not, however, list the grain that was served it the chicken. I wish I had known there was a grain involved, and I wouldn't have wasted food. The chicken breast was not the usual boneless, skinless chicken breast. It was bone-in, and had a leg attached.

This was definitely NOT my favorite meal while in San Francisco.
author: Karina H.

description: Amazing pizza, great service, outstanding dessert. Definitely deserves all five stars
author: Callie T.

description: My husband picked up the Amatriciana pizza to go.  When he got home, I expected it to be cold so I wasn't disappointed that it was..  Even cold, the pizza was pretty amazing!  The crust was super-thin & crispy, not the least bit soggy.  It had just enough spice.  The egg was perfect.  My husband and I killed it pretty quickly.  I can just imagine how delicious it is when it's hot.
author: Rose A.

description:
I was looking for a place in the neighborhood to hold a dinner for my birthday party and a friend suggested Ragazza. I had always wanted to try it, but just hadn't gotten around to it. Let me tell you, that they didn't disappoint. Everyone that works there made the whole process seamless and gave absolutely incredible service. 

If you have a large group you can reserve the gazebo in the back garden that comes with a prix fixe menu for $35/person (minus drinks). What a steal. We were all stuffed by the end of dinner and there wasn't a bad item that came out. You get an app, antipasti, salad, pizza (3 kinds) and dessert. The heirloom tomato and fresh mozzarella was my favorite dish. All of the pizzas were delicious. 

This is a great spot that I will be going back to again and again.
author: Brianne E.

description:
the only good thing about this place is the hard working staff, the food is horrible. To all the so called foodie people, lasagna is suppose to have pasta not just a thick sauce without any seasoning. a whole pork belly pizza had total of 5 small pork belly on it, chicken pate was dry, no wine glass, they charge extra for an order of bread. 

go back to basics, learn how to make a real sauce, make real italian food.
author: arash m.

description:
Don't sit at the bar unless you WANT your hair to smell like campfire smoke. Plus, you just look at the food coming out and being placed in front of you (going out to other tables) and its pure torture when you are hungry. 

Now for the food. I'm pretty happy that I've discovered this place. Good pizza. Get any pizza with egg. You wont be sorry. The crust is crunchy so dont go here if you dont like that. 

The baked butternut squash rigatoni was on the sweet side. I usually prefer my pasta savory, but still, it was a good dish. 

Oh and get the affogato for dessert. An espresso shot with Bi-Rite almond ice cream. Delish! 

Great restaurant overall. Usually with a wait-- so come early or late. NOT for big parties as the place is somewhat small. 4 stars and not 5 simply because my hair smells like smoke and needs a wash, but maybe if i sit not at the bar next time, I might review again and give it 5 stars.
author: Cicely T.

description:
My favorite here was the pulled mozzarella and tomatoes topped with brown sugar and sage. The brown sugar made the tomatoes taste super good and it was a nice sweet and salty blend with the mozzarella cheese.

The brussel sprouts "pie" topped along with onion, thyme, bacon, and an egg was only okay. It was missing something. I think maybe because there was no tomato sauce as base. So, I was definitely a little disappointed.

But that doesn't stop me from going there again another time to try their other pizzas...."pies"...;D
author: Annie H.

description:
Hey, I enjoyed this place. we had to check it out since we were staying next door.
I had Polenta and the County Line Greens. OK, so worth it. The county line greens were out of this world and you get so much for the price and it was tasty. Loved the polenta too. They put mascarpone on it, but they put a little too much on it, but it was still good.
Hubby had traditional Italian Pizza. I tried it. I loved it. He likes american pizza better. Not me.
I would go back, it is a nice Italian little spot.
author: Cindi W.

description: Great wine, and great service. One of the pizzas we got was excellent (egg arugula pesto bacon) but the four cheese one was extremely disappointing. The chocolate mousse like dessert was incredible!
author: Rohan S.

description:
I'm already a huge fan of Gialina's, (that was the place that made me love pizza) so, when i heard the chef/owner was opening another restaurant, i knew we'd have to check it out. 

We got there around 9 on Sat. night, and the only seats were at the bar. I was less than thrilled about this, but didn't want to wait 30-40 minutes for a table. 
As it turned out, a table opened up just as we got our first pizza, but we were ok with our seats by then. 

We shared: margherita (always a staple when we go out for pizza) and the amatriciana, (recommended by our server.) 
It had a little heat (chiles), Parmesan cheese, perfectly crispy pancetta and an egg. I had egg on pizza a few years ago, and I'm a big fan. 

Our server was friendly and nice, and our food came out in a reasonable amount of time. 

As i knew i would, I loved it all! I also had what was possibly the best rose I've ever drank. 

As I recently read from a (somewhat) well-known reviewer, "Ragazza may quite possibly have the lightest crust in the city." 
Agreed, and bravo to the chef/owner. I love that she uses local purveyors, and seasonal ingredients. 

This place was packed the entire time we were there, and although that makes the wait longer for me, I'm thrilled to see a small business owner like this one doing so well.
author: Amanda G.

description:
I've been here twice.  The food is decent.  I recommend the butternut squash pasta and the Amatriciano pizza.

On the food alone, I'd give this place 4 stars.  However, the wine is definitely overpriced ($30 for a carafe?) and there was a $1/person "service charge" on our bill.  After speaking to the waitress, I was told this was the "Healthy SF" surcharge (which was obviously UNCLEAR from looking at the bill).  I'm getting tired of SF restaurants nickel and diming us.  We consumers deal with inflation too.  Restaurants should feel free to pass along a price increase if they'd like.  I find that much more tasteful than some random surcharge that wasn't made clear BEFORE the meal.
author: Toby C.

description: First off the food was great. My party was seated, given drinks, appetizers and food very quickly, however that's the last we saw of the servers until 20 minutes after we were done eating. We had made it a point to make eye contact with two different waitress' to bring a check and or have a box for extra pizza however it took us cleaning the table ourselves to get the check and box. Ended up leaving the boxed pizza in the back for a while longer before we could leave for good measure. If you have a lot of time to kill, by all means this is your place.
author: Maranda C.

description:
Eat pray love.....pizza pizza. Treat yourself everyday to their pies and you'll be happier for it!
... hey new lamb sausauge pie omg!!!!!
author: James B.

description:
Some say that I'm una ragazza lasciva (a lascivious girl), but in the middle of the week I was simply una ragazza affamata (a starving girl.)  

My friend and I ducked the paparazzi that were hounding us (yes, hunger makes me delusional), and decided on pizza and wine to fill ourselves.

We checked in with the hostess around 8:30pm on Wednesday and were told we had a thirty minute wait (don't they know who we are! see, still delirious.) We tricked the paparazzi by getting a quick drink at NOPA, and the bella ragazza soon phoned and said our table was ready.

Trying to maintain a low profile is hard work, so we decided to treat ourselves and go all out.  This resulted in a dish of crispy pork belly with figs and balsamic, a summer bean salad, and two pizzas: the clam pizza and the heirloom tomato pizza with bacon and basil.  We also ordered some deep Italian red wines, and the pours were plentiful.  Needing to be alert for the dangers possibly awaiting us, we ordered some espressos to stay awake after such a comfortable dinner.

I really liked both of the pizzas.  It had been awhile since I've had pizza, but I'd say that they're more generously sized and satiating than both Beretta and Pizzeria Delfina. Unfortunately, I've never ever been to Glen Park so I can't compare it to Gialina.  The heirloom tomato's crust tasted like there was bacon inside it, and if this is so, it is genius! The clam pizza was excellent as well, and if you are a seafoodphobe, it's not overly fishy, and the clam is minced so small that it covers the entire pizza.  

The meal (plus the leftovers I had the next day) turned me from una regazza cranky to una ragazza felice.

If you take me back, I may give you my autograph.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Top 100 bay area restaurants & top 50 pizza restuarants so I had to try. I was seated right away at the bar & the servers were extremely friendly and attentive. During rush hour, I believe it's about a 30 min wait. I suggest putting your name down and then grabbing a drink at Vinyl Coffee/Wine Bar down the block :) Ordered the Amatriciana - tomato, olli pancetta, chilies, pecorino, oregano, topped with an egg. Friggin delicious & all the ingredients harmoniously blend into a foodgasm. Super crunchy thin crust too! I could have finished the whole pizza myself (9 slices) but I decided to portion control. It's one of those meals where you can't wait to eat the leftovers!!!! Highly recommend it!

There's an outdoor patio for private events. I would definitely check that out!
author: Lisa N.

description: I had great squash soup and a good pizza but I was very surprised to see that they have a foie gras pizza on their menu.  In all good conscience I could not give a restaurant a good rating when they serve food that inflicts torture on animals.
author: Gloria J.

description: Rodney is a true host. Professional and sharp. The food and wine was superb. Def try this place!
author: Christopher S.

description: I came here earlier tonight with my good friend and we ordered the Swiss Chard pizza. It was really, really good. The only critiques are that the pizza became somewhat soggy (but still okay bc of its deliciousness) and we did feel a bit of a rush to quickly eat the pizza so other patrons could be seated. Otherwise, a great pie and if you come on the early evening side, you can probably get a seat right away.
author: Mel G.

description:
Yummmmmmmm. Was there for their opening night meal and was carried away into a wonderland of delectable tastes.

The little gems salad had a rich creamy goddess dressing. The pies (pizzas) were a great size for their price, and the ingredients blew most other places out of the water. From the cheese selection to the sweet and spicy sausage there wasn't a single bite that didn't beg me to indulge more.

We ordered a pork roast as another main dish and the meat fell easily off the bone and into our mouths. I've never tasted such a soft, succulent and flavorful pork roast. Not to mention the creamy bed of polenta underneath, which complemented the savory pork perfectly.

The kicker was a rich chocolatey dessert, chefs choice. From now on I'll be hanging out here a lot more often, especially if the chef chooses dessert for us.
author: Chris S.

description:
Delicious pizza. Got the vegetarian margarita pizza with added Calabrian chili and onions. It was delicious.  Also got the Bianca- with onions, garlic, wild arugula and a hint of lemon- minus the provolone. It was one of the best pizzas I have ever eaten. 

If you like artisan pizzas that are light on the cheese, you will love this place. I will definitely come back.
author: Neel I.

description:
Pasta, Pasta, Pasta!

So I am a sucker for fresh, homemade pasta and I had heard many a good thing about this place... all of which, I learned to be true.

First thing I was warned is the no reservations... so my husband and I hopped on straight after work and found ourselves to get a table for two right after another couple and family were seated.  Perfect timing!

Their pasta is fresh and soooooooooooo delicious!  Good size and so hard to share after a few bites.  Yum!  The pizzas are equally delicious.  My favorite was the wild nettles w/ portobello mushroom, olli pancetta, red onion & aged provolone.  Fresh mozzerella, fresh pasta, and homemade ricotta... what's not to love?

Service was great- attentive and helpful.

My only con is that parking is always rough unless I come right after work and that the table gets crowded really fast with our drinks and food, but overall I like the atmosphere and space.  

Great eats, great price, great place!  Definitely worth a visit.
author: Christine K.

description:
I pride myself on being a pizza guy. It's silly and maybe a bit more than slightly juvenile, but pizza is an art form that is very under-appreciated in the world we live in. A good slice is neither flimsy, nor too firm. Neither too thick nor too thin. It has just the write proportion of sauce to cheese to toppings and to that crust should feel like reaching the finish line of a long race.

As you can probably tell by my star rating, Ragazza does a great job with its pies. The crust is crunchy but never hard and aways tasty. The sauce is of the sweeter variety (every pizza needs red sauce to be considered actual pizza, in my opinion) but was enjoyed by me and every large party of friends I brought to Ragazza. 

My pizza of choice is the Potato Pie, but without Potato and with red sauce. It's to die for. It's a creation of my own and while I do get some funny looks from the waitresses, I've never been denied. Coming in second place is Amatriciana which is topped by a satisfyingly runny egg and some lovely meat accoutrements. 

The salads are highly recommended, too, and the beer and wine do their jobs as well.
author: Nate A.

description: This place is rediculous. They don't take reservations so get there early. Also get the white pizza....soooo good. Go here. Now.
author: Kellie R.

description: Great food, excellent quality ingredients, exciting menu options that really intrigues me to explore. Beautiful presentation, friendly staff, comfy ambience, BIG servings. And it's definitely more Italian cuisine than just pizza, i highly recommend truing the smaller plates, i saw several people ordering some pizza/flatbread, they looked amazing as well. So definitely explore the menu. Parking needs a bit of a luck, but worth it.
author: Lulu W.

description:
Very good pizza. Solid Margherita and the Triple P is a flavor bomb! Crust was slightly soggy in the middle but not bad. Crust on the outer areas of the pizza was outstanding, nice and airy with just the right amount of char. 

Service was okay. Nice but a bit slow. We came during dinner rush so that's somewhat expected. 

The only downside for me was the beer list. We're in the midst of a craft beer renaissance but you definitely couldn't tell by light lager lineup here. Even sticking to Italian beers, there are much better options.

Overall though, great place!
author: Matt W.

description: pretty, pretty, pretty, good.  Kale salad was really good as was the garlic soup.  Amatriciana pizza was the winner by far.  One of the better pizza places in the city, no doubt
author: Scott L.

description:
Not thrilling. We ordered the Amatriciana. The pizza crust was overcooked and tasted charred. I asked for no chilies on my pizza, but the server didn't mention that they were in the sauce as well. So we ended up with a very spicy,hot pizza even though I asked for no chilies. 

The server was friendly although a little frazzled. She replaced our pizza with another dish, the Ricotta Cavatelli. It wasn't thrilling either, but it wasn't offensive.

To top off the night, their computer system went down, and they were using old style credit card slips. They wrote down the wrong total for my card, but quickly fixed it when we pointed it out.

Overall, it wasn't a great experience. Likely, I won't be back.
author: MIke S.

description:
Started out with 4-star potential. 

-1 star for the bitch at the front door who snapped at me and then ignored me while forcing me to wait "at the end of the line" just to tell her that we were there (we already had a reservation and just wanted to tell her we arrived, that's it ...) 

-1 star for being so loud you can't talk 

-1 star for serving wine that tastes like vinegar; returned first one, got a different one, same thing, just drank it 

-1 star for a menu that seems to basically be a copy of Gialina

-1 star for pizza that had no discernible cheese in it 
 
I guess that's -1 star in total ... I'm being generous with the 2 star rating.
author: Eater S.

description:
Hey San Francisco,

F*ck all of you for keeping this place a secret from me for so long.  

Cat is out of the bag (and she's hungry for pizza).

Kisses,

Julie
author: Julie H.

description: I am lucky to have Ragazza so close to where I live - I LOVE this restaurant! The pizza bianca is my FAVORITE, and I also love the arugula salad. Nice affordable wine selection and I love that they have carafes! There is also a cute little heated patio/gazebo out back that's a fun place to eat. It's a little annoying that they don't take reservations, but on the upside - they will call you when your table is ready, so I usually just go over to the Page and have a drink while I'm waiting. It's worked out very well most of the time.
author: Jinja R.

description:
A nice variety of dishes here, but pizza is their main focus.  (They had an eggplant lasagna when I went that looked delicious.)

All the ingredients were delicious, and the dough was excellent.  They serve a thin crust, which isn't overly thin - just right.  And the edges are right in the middle too - they don't go all the way to the edge so you have a little bit of the crispy, unadorned part.

I have to say, though, the night that I went, it seemed like the toppings didn't quite come together.  They change them, but perhaps too frequently.  Probably stick to a few (per season?) and experiment a little, but stick to what works.
author: masa s.

description:
The Ragazza hostess, a blonde named Kate, ruined our Ragazza experience and we never even made it to a table.  I now never need to make it to a table at Ragazza.  She was just plain rude and soured my experience, along with three friends.  Our story...

I had enjoyed Ragazza a year ago and wanted to introduce friends to the restaurant since it's in their neighborhood and serves some good food.  Also, Ragazza had made the Big Eat in 7x7 Magazine since my last visit so I was excited to finally try it again.  I was told to call ahead to put our name on the list as they don't take reservations.  I called as we left my place and "Kate" told me that we needed to make it there within 10 minutes or she would give the table away and we would have a 45 minute wait.  She already seemed short with me and I hadn't even met the girl.

My friends beat us to the restaurant and called me to see if we were close as the table was ready - we were one block away.  Within the block, Kate gave the table away.  I went in to check and see when we would next sit and see if there was a chance a table was still available.  Kate told me, and I quote, "You called at 7:15 and I told you to arrive in 10 minutes and now it is 7:29" as she pointed to her little clock on the hostess stand.  With that, she asked if we still wanted to wait, I said yes, and she walked away.  

Why she couldn't have been slightly friendly, or slightly apologetic, or slightly empathetic, or slightly understanding?  No idea.  I understand restaurant policy with a wait list.  That was not the problem as we were late and would have easily understood why the table was given away but she was completely rude.  It's time for Kate to go.

Never again.  And in addition, the food is nothing incredible.
author: Chad S.

description: I dig Ragazza. Came here on a Friday night with a group of 5 and didn't have to wait more than 10 minutes to be seated. We split an assortment of appetizers (arancini, mozzarella, meatballs) and 2 pizzas (Margherita and Bianca). The margherita was the favorite pizza by a landslide. If you're looking to skip the Pizzaria Delfina wait and not travel too far, Ragazza is a solid choice.
author: Lauren C.

description:
We had:  warm olives appetizers, focaccia with olive oil, asparagus with mozarella, bucatini pasta, potato and bacon pizza. All were beyond fantastic!
If you want a pleasurable dining experience, run, don't walk, to this awesome italian restaurant.
author: Jonsey B.

description: Honestly, I messed up. I came here and did not order the pizza, which was, I know, an epic fail! But I did enjoy the gorgonzola stuffed dates! Yum!! I also had the fresh mozzarella and bean salad. It was very good. For dinner I had the pasta with lamb ragu and my fiancé had the roasted chicken. The dinner was truly very delicious. Next time I am in SF I will for sure try the pizza.
author: Nicole S.

description: I was staying at the Metro Hotel next door and after walking around and trying to figure out what I wanted I ended up here, what a great place to end up. Waitstaff was on their game, knowledgable about the menu and guided  me to the right pizza choice. The egg on top was so good. Great local wine choices and for San Fransisco the price was great. Definitely sit out back in the heated patio and enjoy all the things this place has to offer.
author: Jason H.

description:
I HEARD ANGELS CRY when I ate the beet dip from their antipasto plate. 

The sage brown butter rigatoni and olive oil cake were a total revelation as well. 

Thoroughly enjoyed everything I tasted and the overall quality was superb. Great Great flavors and they were very accommodating to vegetarians. 

The wait was definitely long (1 hour) but we just went to a bar across the street in the mean time. They called you once your table was ready so it worked out perfectly.   

As some people mentioned the hostess' welcoming abilities were questionable but nothing so serious as to discourage me from coming back.
author: Cassandra L.

description: My boyfriend and I were really happy with Ragazza. Both our pizzas (Margherita & Porkbelly)  were delicious. We split a really tasty salad that must've been a special (farro and anchovies I think.) Overall it was a good experience and we'll be going back.
author: Dayna E.

description:
Many years ago, my husband and I sat in the garden in the back on our second or third date. I still remember how pretty and quiet the garden was, and how unusually warm it was, for a San Francisco evening, to be outside, dining in a dress. 

Years later, the space has transformed into Ragazza, a little gem specializing in Neopolitan pizzas.  It is extremely busy, for a good reason: the pizzas are delicious.  My summer Squash w/ oven roasted tomatoes, white corn, Nostrano salumi  & farmer's pecorino pizza was full of flavors and the dough was thin and chewy, just the way I like it!

My husband had Amatriciana pizza which he liked also.

The arincini was okay. It's hard to mess up pan fried rice balls, but I have had better. 

What impressed me the most was the hostess.  She not only had to welcome the patrons, put them down on the waiting list, answer the phones, call patrons when their tables are ready, but she also managed to clear tables when the waitstaff was busy, all the while moving around the small space with a smile. I don't know how she does it. I would have been tearing my hair out by 7pm. 

No reservations accepted, so arriving early is key. The wait time went from 15-20 minutes when we arrived around 6PM to 45 minutes when we left before 7PM.
author: Candice B.

description: I've been to Ragazza many times before and it has been amazing! It's One of my favorite places to go for dinner in NOPA. Tonight's rating is for the pizza- not the restaurant.  Although the pizza seemed to be prepared correctly, the flavor was all off. Basically, I've come to the conclusion that pork belly does not belong on pizza.
author: Louise L.

description:
Okay so I don't write reviews much these days. But this experience made me hop on the ol' Yelp and give these peeps a shot out. I got double charged a huge amount on my card after a dinner a few weeks ago. I got ahold of the Regazza staff and not only were they super quick to reconcile the situation and issue me a refund check for the full amount, but they also sent me a gift certificate and apologies. I work in the service industry and I have to say cudos and well done. That's my kind of restaurant.

PS: I also have a pizza problem and will order from there several times a week, so much in fact, that I will make my partner go in and pick up for me while I stand outside because I get a little embarrassed that it is my fourth straight night of ordering their AMAZING pies.

Well done, Regazza, well done!
author: o. c.

description:
Our server was fantastic--she could not have been nicer or more attentive.  
Honestly though, I wasn't too into the food.
The arancini were bland and served with a sauce that lacked flavor.  It was thick and looked liked it had been reheated one too many times. Strangely, the sauce packed a lot of heat though.  
The Pizza Amatriciana was ok--it too packed a punch with the heat from the chili oil?
I thought that the crust was way too thin.  It was as thin as a sheet of paper except for the crust.  The sauce again was very thick.
The bill included a Service Charge for each diner.  After inquiring about the charge, it was explained to me that it was the Health Tax that some restaurants add to their bills to help pay for their employee's health insurance.  Our server explained that the owners prefer to use that wording, "Service Charge", rather than calling it what it is really supposed to be used for--strange...I hope their employees are actually getting this money to help with insurance.
author: Thomas D.

description:
This place does not take reservations and if you want to eat dinner at a sane hour, there's almost a guarantee of a 45 min wait. Nevertheless, persevere for inside is the world's best pizza! Ragazza's pizzas are spectacular. If you haven't been here before, you almost have no choice but to order the Moto or it's vegetarian cousin the Atomica (this name isn't on the menu but the waitress will know it and you'll get brownie points for knowing the secret lingo). Beware that the pizza isn't heavy, so plan on scarfing down an entire pizza if you are hungry. Even if you are aren't hungry, eat it all because there isn't much more to life. 
The wine selection is pretty great too and the decor is the right mixture of quirky, charming and hipster (hello Edison bulbs!).
author: Ramnath B.

description: One of my absolute favorites dinner spots in SF. I have been here numerous times and can't say I've ever had an unpleasant experience. The food here is amazing and so consistently delicious- not a statement I use much at all. I've tried different dishes and every single one is damn good! Some of my favorites- burrata, kale salad, beet salad, cavatelli pasta, Bianca pizza and asparagus pizza (which was seasonal). The only thing I wasn't crazy about was their Nutella pizza dessert, the bread is way too thick so I deducted one star for that. It's a small intimate spot so sometimes you might have to wait a bit. However, totally worth the wait!! Love this place!
author: Emilia R.

description:
Maybe 3.5 stars
So this review is for take-out only. I was really in the mood for good Pizza. I placed an order for the margarita with spicy calabrien chilies. 

Pros -
* The pizza is actually pretty decent. Thin crust, light on the cheese (I actually prefer it this way). It was still crispy by the time I brought it home, instead of soggy as thin crust pizzas usually get. The taste was excellent. 
* Decent size. Filling for one person.. 

Cons
* Its expensive. My bill was $17. That's a bit much for a personal pizza. 
* The box they put tha pizza in is clearly too small for the pizza. They end up breaking apart the slices and stacking them somewhat. Not cool. 
* They totally forgot to pout the calabrien chilies on my pizza and I had paid the extra $1.50 for it. I didn't realize until I was already home and didn't want to go back :(. 

Overall, I would probably not get takeout from here again. It seems like a place you go to enjoy the ambiance and pay for it.
author: Vrushali P.

description:
Oh how I hate these restaurants that don't take reservations. I don't really want to hang around waiting for food.  Unless it's free.  New restaurateurs, please take note, the no reservation fad is over.  Please.

Very busy restaurant and lots of keen customers.  Chilly service throughout. Smiles through gritted teeth sort of stuff.  They were very busy but the hostess seemed confused a lot of the time.

The chicken pate was not enjoyable.  The very sweet cherry liqueur/sauce didn't really work for me and the pate itself was very loose and not really a classic pate.

The arancini were very good.  Crispy on the outside and a strong tomato based sort of pesto which I really enjoyed.  The cavatelli was kind of odd.  Really under seasoned it had an odd sort of creamy cheesy mix.  It kind of tasted a bit like soured milk/cream.  I don't know, it wasn't quite right.  The tomo pizza was the saving grace and it was an authentic tasty, thin crust pizza.

One pet peeve is to do with the wine. If I order a 2010 Barbera D'Alba then don't bring me the 2012.  I don't know enough about the wines to know if one is better than the other but the wine list should reflect what you actually have in your cellar.  The menu is a piece of paper with the wine list on the back, which was pretty small so hardly a massive effort to keep it current. There is no excuse for not updating your wine list to reflect your actual stock.  It's just lazy.

Would I go again?  Maybe, if it was empty and I didn't have to wait.  But the food, wine and service just wasn't good enough to make me stand out in a San Francisco street for more than 3 minutes.
author: Steven R.

description: Don't get me wrong. I love the food here. But. We wanted to sit. Three out of four people of the party were here but they wouldn't seat us. We told them that we were planning on eating and ordering wine right away but still no dice. Oh and btw no wait, empty tables. I understand restaurant policy, but when it's a neighborhood place that you go to once a week, you would think they would be neighborly and seat you so your starving out-of-town guest won't go hungry.
author: deborah k.

description: Great pizzas!! Have been there a few times and it's just been super. Ordered Bianca the last time I was there (a couple of days ago). Mmm mmm mmm...
author: Aman K.

description: Wow - absolutley loved my experience here. Showed up and was seated pretty quickly - great ambiance with just the right lighting and black and white pictures of old italian people up on the walls. The pizza was thin, crispy, and awesome. The yogurt dip and olives were two of the best starters I've ever had. Our waitress was super friendly and even staggered our pizzas so we'd be able to eat them warm. Highly recommend.
author: Jerry G.

description: Pretty good neopolitan pizza! The crust is pretty crispy for neopolitan pizza. It's a little spendy for pizza, but not outrageous considering it's SF. There's also a great heated gazebo out back. I've been there twice, first time the service was excellent. The 2nd time, not so much. Ingredients are fresh, and they put some thought into what toppings work well on a pizza. Personally, I prefer a crust that is crispy on the bottom but also has a little bit of "oven spring". As a result, it didn't leave me plotting for my next return, but there's no doubt I'll be back.
author: Alison H.

description:
This is not pizza.

After a long day of work, walking around a ton, we decided we just wanted to take it easy and have pizza for dinner. Since Little Star was closed and the delivery time for Patxi's was 2 hours, we decided to go with Ragazza because it was close.

What a mistake. We ordered a margarita pizza. It was bread with tomato sauce pushed around on it and 6 leaves. It was so ridiculously thin. There was no way this was going to make a meal. $13 for that? Completely not worth it. I wouldn't have paid for that pizza.

You would think, "OK, so it was skimpy, but I bet it tasted good, right?"

No. It tasted so mediocre I couldn't pull one ingredient out of it. There was no taste. It was just food. 

This place is over-hyped for the atmosphere, but what's the point if the food sucks this bad?
author: Jenny J.

description:
Seriously unique and great pizza.  It is truly amazing how thin they get their crust, yet it holds up to all the tasty toppings.  The way they crisp the pancetta strips before they bake in on the pie really made the Amatricana for me.  Deep crispy pork flavor that kept the pie super thin since it was cooked separately and flattened, but once baked became one with the crust.  And what a crust it is!  

We also had the fresh asparagus and citrus pie, which came with a nice runny egg on top (both pies had eggs, actually).  The roasted asparagus was so tasty and went so well with the citrusy egg.  I'm convinced you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  We loved the Faro salad, which changes regularly and the fried risotto balls with mozz were an obvious hit.  

This is great pizza, super unique and dare I say probably better than Delfina!  There, I said it.
author: Jon S.

description:
Everything about this place was just great.  Even though, the roast chicken dish we got was still raw in the middle, the problem was corrected without a bat of the eye.  The second round was amazing.  The Bianca pizza was awesome (although a wee bit salty...but still worthy of 5 stars)

Even though I had a hiccup of an experience, I still thought this place was great.  I'll be back!
author: Matt V.

description: Appetizers were ok (arancini was good), but I didn't care for the pizza or desserts.  Also my party got the prix fixe menu and we all thought it was super expensive for the amount of food we got (and for pizza!).   I think each of us could have ordered the same food a la carte and spent a lot less.  The margarita pizza had almost no cheese, it was just a very thin dough with tomato sauce, olive cake was dry and the tiramisu was mostly cream.   Anyhow, I was not impressed...likely not coming back.
author: R X.

description:
My experience here was nothing short of amazing.  i loved everything about it.

the salumi plate was delicious, although i could have used more meat.

the brussels sprouts was the lardons were really, really tasty.  the sprouts were nice and singed.  the fattiness of the lardons really worked for me here.

the pizza....omg, the pizza.  first of all, a pizza is only as good as its crust, and the crust at Ragazza is exceptional.  the Warren Pear w/ caramelized onions, gorgonzola, Prosciutto di Parma & arugula pizza was off the hook, unbelievably, slap your mom in the face, crazy good.  all of the flavors were distinct and were simply singing on top of that delicious crust.  

the atmosphere is unpretentious and is the type of place you feel at home.

our server was extremely knowledgeable and personable and most of all, she was REAL.  had some nice convos with her, as it turned out she had mutual friends with someone in our party.

i would recommend this place to anyone in a heartbeat and i, myself, cannot wait to go back.  this place is better than Zero Zero, and i have yet to try Flour + Water, so we will see how it ranks once i tackle that feat.
author: Christian C.

description:
I can't help but love this place. Cozy, friendly, and great za. 

Starters: Fried Arancini w/ smoked mozzarella & "angry" tomato sauce - I just wish there was more of them :)

Pasta: House-Made Ricotta Cavatelli w/ pork sugo & Parmigiano Reggiano  - soo good. 

Za: Amatriciana - tomato,  pancetta, chilies, pecorino, oregano & an egg - best one I've tried yet. 

Moto- tomato, Calabrian chilies, portobello mushrooms, red onions, sausage & mozzarella - I just wish they put the calabrian chilies on whole (it's hard to tell they are even part of this pizza... which is the main reason I ordered it) 

Dessert: They have some great dessert options... but I would skip the Nutella pizza... too much and no real wow factor.
author: Shannon H.

description:
I was not very impressed with Ragazza. It's cute points of interest are some neat photography on the walls and some competent assembly of the dishes, but there were some major problems when I was there beginning with the WILDLY INAPPROPRIATE service. 

Let's tackle that. Our server was annoyingly, boisterously friendly with the table right next to us (and by right next to us I meant 6 or 7 inches in this small place), awkwardly inept with us, and flat out rude to the poor group of girls on the other side.

Despite the acoustics being pretty well designed to allow you to hear your date in such a small crowded place--there is some sound dampening on the ceiling--we couldn't have a conversation because we were either listening to her talk about her tattoos at the absolute top of her voice to one side or listening in shock while she ridiculed the choices the other girls where making, gave them condescending speeches about how much they were ordering, and chided them for not refilling their own water glasses.   

To us, she was thankfully just inexplicably tongue tied--stuttering out responses and needing to be told twice that we were not interested in dessert. /awkward turtle! 

Okay, the food...

...is actually pretty decent, but ultimately not something you have to have. It's generic Italian cafe fair that you can get at any neapolitan pizza joint. These are increasingly dime-a-dozen affairs. 

And this is NOT must have pizza.

We ordered the soft polenta--which was well executed--and the amatriciana pizza. I love the idea of turning a classic sauce into a pizza, but this one lacked all of the sumptuousness you'd expect in amatriciana. The pancetta they used looked and tasted like classic American bacon to me--though that's obviously a semantic point. And amatriciana's not usually made with pancetta anyway.

For options in the area consider: Uva--for equally apt Italian and a better wine selection--or Nopalito--for awesome organic Mexican...with totopos (nachos) and grass fed beef empanadas that you really should try. THE SERVICE AT BOTH HAS ALWAYS BEEN EXCEPTIONAL!
author: Luke M.

description: Just not what I was expecting given the reviews.  The waiter forgot our salad and the restaurant wasn't even busy yet so couldn't really figure out why that happened.  We came here pretty hungry and the pasta portion was ridiculously small.  It was also the only pasta option on the menu.  This is an Italian restaurant!!!  We asked one of the food runners if there was any bread and before specifying that it could even be something that was part of an appetizer, he immediately said no and looked at us as if we had three heads.  The waiter also didn't seem to have any idea about the wines.  Of course his suggestions were the most expensive ones and both weren't that great.  I had asked for a tasting of the second because the first was horrible and instead was brought an entire glass of another subpar wine.  No way this was a normal serving of wine either.  It was a small glass and a small serving.  The wine was also warm as well as the water.  The restaurant was busy by the time we left and me and my guest were scratching our heads asking why.  Sorry but this is on our NEVER AGAIN LIST!
author: Jaime V.

description:
My date and I were craving heirloom tomatoes, and we were not disappointed! We enjoyed both an appetizer and a pizza loaded with delicious, seasonal tomatoes, along with a wonderful bottle of Primitivo. 

Would've been a perfect night to dine on the back patio, but for some reason they were seating out there? 

I'd definitely go back :)
author: Jenny H.

description:
We came here on a Saturday night at 6:15 and waited less than twenty minutes for a party of 3 to be seated. We are vegetarian, as was our dining companion, and we got straight to business-- ordering three pizzas and nothing else. We knew we'd order the Margherita and the Zucca, but were vacillating between the Bianca and the Brussells sprouts pies. When we consulted our server, his response was unhesitating and emphatic-- the Bianca. The pizzas came out one at a time-- first, the margherita, which was standard though not particularly stand out. Two of us felt it was much improved with sprinkling of red chili flakes. The Bianca was next, and was an immediate favorite -- lemony and salty and delicious. The Zucca was last and was a slow favorite. Layers of thin squash disks with flavors of sage and almond gave this pie a slightly "sweet" taste, reminiscent of a brown butter sage pasta dish. At the end of the meal not a slice was left and we were all quite satisfied.

Overall, Ragazza was an enjoyable experience. The crust was fantastic and there were a number of vegetarian options for us. The margherita was a little flat but the remaining options were good, but not amazing. We would consider coming back but there are many other places to try first.
author: T K.

description:
We ordered Fried Arancini,  Arugala and Beet Salad, and Amatriciana pizza as a to-go order. The arancini had an unidentifiable sour flavor and the sauce was both oily and pasty.  Deep fried dough topped with oil is a poor combination.  Unfortunately, the amarcini aren't much better on their own.  The Amatriciana pizza is topped with pancetta, chilies, an egg,  cheese and is inedible.  Although it was cooked fairly well, the pizza was exceptionally greasy from the pancetta and far too salty.  As if it weren't rich enough, it is topped with an egg.  The salad was good, but certainly not enough to bring us back.

One star given the price ($40) and 2/3 terrible food.
author: Andrea R.

description: Nobody should be served a pizza that sat in a take-out box long enough to turn tough and tepid and then was served to on- site table customers who had been waiting. But it happened. Marvelously placid waiter Mathew managed to salvage the evening. Still, an outstanding heirloom tomato salad isn't quite enough to bring me back again. Too bad. Blame the kitchen, not the wait staff
author: Carolyn K.

description: The pizzas here are some of my favorites in the city.  Pretty much every pizza is yummy, but if you need a suggestion, may I suggest the Bianca pizza, adding speck and an egg.  The preserved lemon in the Bianca pizza is completely new to my pizza taste buds.  It provides a refreshing citrus after-taste from the salty and fatty (but sooooooo delicious) drippings from the speck.  One pizza is enough to share between two people, but if you crave more deliciousness, try the Niman Ranch Pork Belly with Peach, Bean, and Bell Pepper Salad.  The pork belly is salty and crispy, which is balanced by the sweet and tender peach slices.  The fragrant peach slices themselves can make you appreciate summers so much more...yes, even in S.F.
author: Ally W.

description: I've come here a few times before as I live close and have always had good experiences. However I dined here yesterday and ordered the chicken which ended up being completely raw in the middle. Luckily, I noticed it before eating it. We sent it back and it took awhile for a new one to arrive. Of course chefs make mistakes from now and then but we did not receive a single apology and paid full price for everything. A mistake like that could've cost one of their guests food poisoning, I was shocked they didn't seem to care, as if it was a regular occurrence. I was disappointed in the service.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I'm usually not a review writer on Yelp, rather use it for it's help in choosing restaurants and looking at menu's. Upon looking up Ragazza.. I see a nasty review of one of my favorite hostesses in the city: KATE ! and felt compelled to write. I have been to Ragazza a handful of times, and Kate is there 5 days a week, always friendly and (even though it can be painstakingly long), always on time (to the minute or sooner!) with her quoting times. I'm always greeted with a smile from her!

Buyer beware: THEY DO NOT TAKE RESO'S OR HOLD TABLES PAST 10 MINUTES - FOR ANYONE! 
The wait can be long (up to 2 hours), but Kate (and the rest of the staff) are always extremely courteous, friendly, timely and professional. 

Waitstaff aside, the food is AMAZING!
Highlights:
Kale salad with farro, avocados, and green garlic dressing. Fresh and the perfect summer salad.
Pig Plate: always interesting variety of cured porks and pickled veggies. Delicious!
Fried Arancini: risotto balls with mozzarella in a spicy tomato sauce? Yes please.
Amatraciana: Ragazza's signature pie. Spicy red sauce, pancetta, and the farm egg. A must try.
Wild Nettles: Unlike anything I've ever tasted! The bitter greens with the pancetta is unbelievable. 
Seasonal pies are also something to look forward to, as are the ever-changing roasts. The menu is constantly being updated.

Note** Sit at the bar. A fun way to see all the action and get a sneak peek of all the food as it comes out before going to tables.

Again, amazing food, stellar service, and the sweetest hostess in San Francisco.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Pizzas here are great  The entrees are pretty good too. Id like to see a couple more options for starters...

Service goes up and down here... most times no one looks happy to be there. But I used to work in service, and I know how that goes. Cant deduct for that.

Last time, had great service by a very nice blonde woman. And my meal was delicious, had 1 good sized pizza, and 1 pasta entree and 4 or 5 beers for a pretty good price.
author: Scott G.

description:
This was our first real dinner out in the city and It was a great choice!

Ragazza is your classic tiny italian restaurant. a dozen or so tables crammed together. easy visibility into the kitchen and a couple of barstools, where we happened to sit.

They had a decent wine menu with some reasonably priced house wines. Most of the wines had a Carafe option which is always appreciated when you're looking for more than a glass, but less than a bottle!

In terms of food, we had some tasty Foccaccia, although paying for it was a little odd (granted, it was only $1). I went with the house-made Cavatelli which was delicious! My wife went with the Miss Figgy pizza and that was pretty amazing as well. Sitting at the bar also allowed us to ogle many of the other dishes as well, nearly all of which looked extremely tasty!

Service was solid and timely. I would've liked a more expansive array of pasta dishes, but I think they tend to focus on the pizzas, so it's understandable.
author: Scott W.

description:
I loved it!  I'm already a fan of Gialina in Glen Park but it's nice to have a closer location with pasta options!  
We started w/ the Little Gem Lettuces w/ blood oranges, farro, fennel, gorgonzola & hazelnuts.  The salad was really fresh, dressing was light, and overall refreshing.  Then the Moto pizza - tomato, Calabrian chilies, portobello mushrooms, red onion, sausage & mozzarella.  We decided to add an egg atop and it was so good!  Lastly, a pasta w/ pork sugo - wow, to die.  Homemade pasta, delicious sauce!  

We've heard about the long wait so we decided to go at 5pm on a Sunday evening and there was no wait and  we got prime parking & seating at the window.  Our waitress was interesting...I'll leave it at that but the food was great!  Dessert options looked delicious but we were too full.
author: Meredith K.

description:
One of the best overall dining experiences I've had in a while!  3 friends and I had an early dinner here on a Friday night.  Beat the crowd, only had to wait 15 minutes for a table. AMAZING.  We ordered the Kale and Arugula salads to start.  Both were delish, particularly the KALE.  I literally wanted to hog the whole bowl to myself, the garlic cream dressing was dreamy.   

Next up...our PIZZAS. We went with the Asparagus and lemon pizza as well as the potato, bacon and goat cheese with Egg on top.  Both were ridiculously good.  

To top it off, the service was amazing. Our server was super friendly and never left our champagne glasses run dry, topped us off with our bottle every time she walked past our table.  LOVE!
author: Gohar J.

description:
They close at 10:30 I think, and my roommates and I came in around 9:45. The server at the front was kind of rude and told us that we couldn't be seated because it was too close to closing. Hmph. So we went to the back to place an order to go for the Amatriciana pizza. The servers in the back were all super super nice. I guess we just got the front hostess on an off-mood.

It took about 10-15 minutes for them to make our pizza, and we took it home. When we opened the box, I was surprised to see an egg on the top! Anyways, they had cut the pizza into these squarish pieces, which I thought was cool.

The pizza....was unbelievably amazing. OMG. So so so delicious. Some kind of herb they used that I am attracted to...mixed in with a little bit of spicy kick from the peppers, and the pieces with the egg were just fantastic. Thin crust pizza so you don't even feel bad eating a lot of it! I don't even think there was that much cheese on it and I still loved it! I was so full already because I had eaten dinner with my roommates at another restaurant, but I couldn't resist stuffing my face with approximately half of that pizza. I am a fatty.

Random fact: They have cool giant fork and spoon art installations on the walls. I like the giant fork.
author: Melody L.

description: Great pizza and vibe. Don't love their seating policy but can't argue with the food quality!
author: Sheida N.

description:
Everything here is delicious! I know it's about the pizza, but the salads are consistently inspired and amazing.

Tedious wait when busy.
author: Mark P.

description: I came on Valentine's day for dinner and the staff provided great service. The food was delicious - had the dates, lamb rack, pizza with egg on top, and house-suggested carafe to match. Great environment to relax in with a nice outdoor patio.
author: H C.

description: Pizza is amazing here! I would recommend booking if possible! Unfortunately we had to wait almost an hour (3 of us) and my partners pizza was served really late as there was a problem, but their service made up for this! They took the delayed pizza off the bill and gave us champagne to make up for the wait time! Great vibe and outdoor patio looked like It could be hired out!
author: Annabelle W.

description:
Oh my beloved Ragazza, let me count the ways I love thee:

1. Egg on a pizza. No matter which pizza you get, get an egg on it. If you get the Amatriciana, which comes with egg, order another egg. Dip into the gooey goodness, and then fight with your fellow diners as to who gets that last, sopping wet piece in the middle with the remains of the egg left on it.

2. Stellar wines. Most of it is in Italian, and I don't know my Italian wine regions, but with organized headers like "Big, Bold Reds" who can go wrong? The wines are always good.

Side note: I once sat next  to a table of chicks that ordered their white wine with glasses of ice, and then praised their waitress for not chastizing them for ordering their wines with glasses of ice.

3. Butternut squash rigatoni. My heart was almost broken tonight when I came in and they no longer had it on the menu, but I suppose they have their reasons. Maybe butternut squash is out of season? Maybe they continually make it and then eat it all themselves before their patrons come in for dinner? (It is that good). Whatever their reasons I know it will be back someday. Just like Rose to Jack, I won't let go. It will be back  (I hope!)

4. Their salads. And simple decor. And chill waitstaff. And dessert (that you never need). Even the tap water is delicious here.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Dear Yelp Journal,

I have a secret.  I gave Ragazza my kale virginity.  My first time was so good, I think I might be kale whipped.  

You might be wondering, "How did this happen?"  Well, after a happy hour get together with friends I hadn't seen in months, we were drawn to this restaurant because we were starving.  We had oysters and wine, but who gets full off of that?  We searched high and low for something with big portions, but calorie deprivation quickly drained all energy and we finally stopped in front of this restaurant.

The line was long, too long.  It was obviously very popular and the night was getting chilly.  We were told the wait would be 45 minutes.  We thought to move on, but quickly turned back around when we realized we were so hungry that we were unable to walk any further.

We sat outside on the bench and read the menu in the cold while we waited for a table for four to open up.  Their menu seemed really good and I was of course browsing yelp reviews to see what people suggested.  We had made up our minds by the time we were sat.

The restaurant is definitely cozy, but it's also really busy - indication that there is good fare to be had.  We had the kale salad and a beet salad.  I definitely liked kale salad more, but I love my beets.  Very funny with my friend smearing the goat cheese everywhere to my lactose intolerant friend's dismay!  We also had two pizzas, one with the egg and one with the potatoes.  We also had our waiter select a bottle to be shared - a perfect wine for the perfect price.

Everything was incredibly delicious and it ended up being the perfect place for the four of us to get together.  The one drawback to this restaurant is actually the parking situation in this area is atrocious.  If parking weren't so difficult, I would be here frequently.  So if you live in the area or can walk, I would definitely suggest giving this place a go.
author: Wilson K.

description:
Completely worth the wait. 

My friend and I waited 1hour and 45 minutes to get a seat in this restaurant. It's understandable considering how small the place is and how popular it is. (esp. on weekends!) The service was superb though. Once we made it inside the lady at the front cheered for us (because we actually waited that long and because we finally made it out of the cold haha). 

But I have never been more proud of a decision than this. We ordered bread with oil and vinegar as an app and then ordered wild nettle pizza with pancetta. So delicious. The flavor combination was awesome and the pizza was actually quite big. Therefore, the price we paid for this meal did not feel bad at all. I just wish it wasn't so crowded so I could come here more often (...or like, every day). One of the most interesting and fun dining experiences I've had. So a word of advice: patience is definitely a virtue at this restaurant, have fun with it.
author: Idk A.

description:
Bianca pizza is the best pizza I've ever put in my face.

Fresh pulled mozarella to start out a perfect meal - ended by desert of nutella pizza - yes - nutella pizza.

Do yourself a favor and get here immediately. They don't take reservations - so I suggest calling when you're on your way - and drinking at the Fly across the street until they give you a call.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
The wine was pretty overpriced even for my completely barbaric palate.  It tasted like a $10 bottle that they charged $40 for, which is something that really annoys me.  You expect markup at restaurants, but to have it be so blatant just made me feel like they thought (correctly) that they could get away with it.

The pizza was good, notable mostly for being paper thin.  Like there was no structural stability at all to it, which I suppose is novel, but novelty for novelty's sake doesn't really mean much besides calling attention to when it really doesn't work.  We had the margherita, which was basically a mouthful of basil so if you hate basil stay away, and the Bianca, which was a interesting mix of onion crema and lemon and other stuff.  It really was a unique blend of flavors that really worked well together.  We also had the Moto which tasted like any other not-terrible sausage pizza.  Except, y'know, thin.

But at the end, I came away thinking that I paid mostly for air and a really packed restaurant that may make claustrophobes slightly uncomfortable.  I guess if you really hate carbs because you're one of those types that can't seem to balance diet and exercise, then yeah I guess you'll get less carbs.  I'd stick with the more interesting items on the menu, since the "normal" ones don't seem to offer anything that elevates it to a memorable status.   

Recommended:
Margherita
Bianca
author: Norman S.

description: I came hearing how amazing the pizza is. Pizza dough was good but nothing fabulous. Toppings were super super salty!!  The pasta dish we got was also insanely salty. The kale salad was ok. I wish they used another type of greens the kale was tough to eat. I left needing lots of f water and an upset friend who I brought to the restaurant.  She was uoset about the mediocre service.
author: Karen T.

description:
One of the best pizza places in SF. 

My one experience ordering an "entree" was disappointing (four just-OK little seared scallops atop a mound of fava beans for $24), so I stick to pizzas and antipasti. Love the beet salad. 

Waits can be very long any night of the week.
author: Jimbo H.

description: Our party of seven was seated at the outside gazebo with a holiday party and a reservation. The food was amazing, the owner was lovely and visited our party several times and Tink, our waitress, was warm, funny and full of great recommendations. I highly recommend the warm dates with gorgonzola (4 to an order) and the kale salad, which came as a generous portion in a lovely Heath bowl. I highly recommend the Bianca, and the Chanterelle pizzas, as well as the outstanding butternut squash rigatoni. Fantastic.
author: Susan L.

description:
Been here twice and a great experience both times. Good pizza, decent wine prices, nice atmosphere. A little crowded-- you can expect to sit pretty close to the stranger next to you, and there's not room for much on the table. 
The fig pizza was original and delicious-- definitely try it.
author: Will A.

description:
Had a nice dinner here in this cute, trendy little pizza joint. 

We split 3 pizzas and 1 bottle of wine among 4 people and that was enough- miss figgy was my favorite, but I also really enjoyed the summer squash. They are thin crust and packed with flavor. With so many great pizza places in SF, its hard to say which one is the best, as pizza is hard to mess up. But the ingredients in these pizzas and the flavors are really top notch, I would definetly give this place a try (or two). 

Dessert here was also outstanding which bumps them up a notch- Ricotta Cheesecake w/ Amarena cherries- drool.
author: Christy D.

description:
Service: 5 stars by far. So attentive, but not too attentive. Honestly, couldn't be happier with the service.

Food: 2 stars
We got the Moto pie - tomato, Calabrian chilies, portobello mushrooms, red onions, sausage & mozzarella. Maybe this was the wrong pie to get, but I just was not impressed. There was definitely some flavor missing. 

I will give the food another chance, because I really want to like it!  Maybe I need to  try another pie.
author: Monica A.

description:
Unprofessional hostess. Perhaps she hasn't been trained? She didn't manage our expectations correctly and then when she messed up, we received an apathetic response that didn't have a hint of customer service. We were told it would be a 1 hr to 1 hr 15 min wait. We were fine with this and were told we'd get a text when our table was ready. The table became available in 30 minutes and the text said that it would be held for 10 minutes. We immediately texted a response that we were on our way and would be there in 10 minutes. We practically ran to the restaurant. 

When we arrived in 10 minutes she had given away our table. She said "You should have texted me" to which I replied "I did." When she looked on her app, she saw my response. At this point, there were no tables available and she said it would be another 30 minutes. No apology, no "let me buy you a drink." Nothing. I suppose this review won't matter because it looks like the food is quite good, but we won't be back. 

We headed over to Nopalito and their customer service was excellent.  We even had to wait for a table (again!) but it was tolerable because they know how to manage expectations and are professional.
author: Heather D.

description:
YES. 5 stars and pretty psyched to post em' up here for my neighborhood joint, Ragazza. 

I have to be honest, I've been getting a little tired of the usual wood-fired pizza craze, but Ragazza really made me lift a brow. Their pizza crust is chewy and perfectly fired w/out being burnt to a crisp, like many wood-fired pizzas fall prey to. The sauce is tart, but still sweet and the selection of different pizzas vast enough to please all the different palates. I've had their margherita, wild nettles (w/ portobello mushroom,  Boccalone pancetta, red onion & aged provolone) and their brussel sprouts pie (w/ applewood smoked bacon, thyme, red onion & smoked mozzarella). I've been happy with all of them and have actually craved their pizza many-a-time. Just writing this review is making me salivate!

Their arugula salad (w/ beets, fennel, Cypress Grove goat cheese & pistachios) is fresh, baked rigatoni (w/ butternut squash, brown butter, sage & fontina) yummy and their Lemon Verbena Panna Cotta (w/ blackberries) dessert right on point. All of these were delicious and I love how their Panna Cotta makes for a nice, light finish to the dinner. Ah and to top it off, their Nero d' Avola red wine is fruit forward & generally very likable (ordered a bottle on one occasion, and glasses another time).

The space is tight, but if you call ahead and put your name down on their waitlist (they don't take reservations), chances are you won't be in for an excruciatingly long wait. I love their simple cozy space w/ its classy, Italian decorations (even the bathroom) & their holiday trimmings (they had mistletoe up!!), and most of all, I appreciate their ceiling's sound tiles that absorb much of the potential noisiness one would typically get an earful of. I agree w/ some of the reviewers- the wait staff is pretty stand-offish & could be a little friendlier, but the hostess has been a total sweetheart & super accommodating.

Love this solid spot and I'm looking forward to coming back again and again.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Four-and-a-half stars.

Came here on a Wednesday night. We did not have to wait and snagged a two-top towards the front of the restaurant facing the sidewalk/street. 

We ordered:
+ Mariquita Farms Romaine w/ green goddess dressing, fennel & radish: The salad had a freshness about it. Crunchy romaine, just the way I like it.    
+ Asparagus w/ green garlic, preserved lemon, a Rancho Elias egg &  fresh mozzarella: The jackpot to the pizza?! The middle, where the egg, mozarella, lemon, and asparagus mesh. Mouth explosion. Also, the right amount of crispiness for a thin-crust pizza. Yum!
+ Carafe of Nero d'Avola: Just the right amount of wine for two. 

Our server was attentive and there was a right amount of white noise from where we were sitting (front).
author: Ileana H.

description:
so quintessentially divis. 
no trouble at all cozying up to the bar in a completely packed house on a monday night. the heat of the blazing pizza oven may be killer to the hard working and kickass cooks in the kitchen, but it set the house to a warm, ambient, delicious toasted cheese-scented environment. 
the crust on this pizza is delicious. i could swathe it in some green olive oil and be happy...
you can't miss the 'moto' pizza. it is perfection. 
ragazza is a haven for locals who just want a romantic, luxurious, delicious, and low key dinner composed of ingredients and skill of the highest caliber. 
loved it.
author: Libra J.

description: The pizza was good, but the service was not worth it. After waiting well past the time we were quoted the hostess pointed out a table that would be ours as soon as it was cleared. So excited when that finally happened only to have it given to someone else, the worst thing was this was not the end of our seating nightmare. I don't care how good your pizza is or how busy you are, don't lie to your customers. Don't rush to this place, you'll be left waiting.
author: Stephen S.

description: Excellent in many ways, Ragazza is a neighborhood favorite. This means you'll likely wait for a bit. Pop down to Vinyl for a wine while you do. Pizza is wonderful, rest of the menu somewhat limited.
author: Jan M.

description: Delicious pizza. The pizza looks big when it arrives but extremely thin so I wasn't exactly stuffed when finished. A tad pricy.
author: Colin B.

description:
Big fan! You will have a tough time finding a better selection of delicious thin crust pizzas in SF than at Ragazza. The crust is thin, crisp and a perfect platform for the toppings. It's all about the ingredients here, not a thick bready pie. 

Our table of four shared everything. The salumi plate had two of my favorites, speck and lardo. The Fried Arancini was good but I expected more kick from the "angry" tomato sauce. The Pork Belly pizza was delicious, as was the Potato with Smoked Bacon (I did not eat healthy that night). The menu only had three pasta items on it that night and they were out of one, which shows you that they really focus on making a good pizza, so if you are looking for pasta I would probably try somewhere else.

They don't take reservations but they held a table for 5 minutes for us when we called on our way over. It's a small place so you should expect somewhat of a wait, especially on the weekend, but it is worth it. There is also a back patio but more days than not in SF it will be too cold to want to sit out there because there are no heat lamps.
author: Frank J.

description:
We had an amazing meal here a few weeks back. Our server (totally wish I remembered her name) was so freaking awesome and everything we had was totally delicious (the desserts were mixed reviews). But, all else was stellar.

Fun time, great food, can't wait to come back!
author: Art A.

description:
Went here on a date recently. I called 30 minutes beforehand and asked them to put me on the list, then when we arrived at 7pm we were seated immediately (it was a Wednesday -- perhaps the weekend would be different).

The food was incredibly delicious and the service was great. We got two appetizers (the little gems and the cherry tomato caprese salad) then split a pizza, which was more than enough food for the two of us -- we didn't end up finishing any of it.

Unfortunately, there is one downside: it's a small place and the tables are pretty tightly packed, so it can be loud. Probably not the best spot for a first date where you're trying to get to know someone. Still, definitely worth going on other occasions.
author: Joe S.

description:
We had an amazing dinner here last Friday for my sister's wedding Rehearsal.  The restaurant is pretty small but they have a heated gazebo in the back that seats 18-20 people which is where we had our dinner.  I felt like we had a rocky start with dinner.  We all arrived a little after 5 and nothing was set up.  It took a while for them to get us seated, offer wine and start with appetizers.  After that though, things went incredibly smoothly and I regretted my earlier complaints.  Our server was amazing and the food was so delicious!  

We started out with some warmed olives and Fried Arancini w/ sundried tomato pesto.  The Arancini were delicious and I kept going back for more of the tomato pesto.  The second course included a Kale salad with little Gem Lettuces, farro, avocado, kumquats, watermelon radish & green goddess dressing as well as a cheese plate with and Pulled Mozzarella& Roasted Asparagus with smoked prosciutto & crackerbread.  My only complaint about the salad was that they didn't cut out the really hard centers of the kale leaves.  Other than that, the flavor was great, I loved the addition of the farro and the kumquats added a nice citrusy sweetness.  The Mozzarella was delicious and I loved the crunchy asparagus texture and the salty prosciutto.  After this course I was starting to feel a bit full, and we still had the pizza course!  

We started out with a Sausage pizza that was delicious.  The pizza crust was thin and the outside crust was just thick enough.  The pizza's just kept coming then and we also got a Bianca and a pizza topped with fava greens.  The Bianca pizza was equally as delicous as the sausage but very different.  It was topped with onion crema, shaved garlic, preserved lemon, aged provolone & wild arugula.  I loved the addition of the preserved lemon to the pizza as well as the fresh arugula topping.  Both made the rich pizza feel a little lighter and healthier.  The Fava green pizza was probably my least favorite.  I felt that the greens were a bit too bitter and that the flavor wasn't quite there.  I was officially very full after the pizza course and we still had dessert.  Luckily the desserts were shared among groups of five.  We had Tiramisu and an Olive Oil Cake topped with whipped cream and blood oranges.  Both were tasty but I think I preferred the Olive Oil Cake.  

I also really loved the wine that was served at dinner.  I wasn't sure about the red wine at first glance because it came in an oddly shaped liter bottle.  The flavor however was great.  The wine was rustic and tanniny with a smooth finish.  It was an Italian blend of Grenache and Mouvedre and I'm already trying to figure out where I can find it in Portland.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Ragazza is a must if you want to consider yourself a San Francisco pizza connoisseur.  I've been to Gialina, and for some reason, Ragazza is way more amazing.  I don't know why - maybe I'm a sucker for the slightly sleeker decor of Ragazza versus the more homey atmosphere at Gialina.

Regardless, the food we ate there was top notch.  We ordered two small salads (arugula and farro) to share at the table, which were refreshing with delicate greens and subtle flavors, as salads should be.  The goat cheese that came with both salads was smooth and mild.  Even the goat cheese hater at the table liked it.

The pizzas are quite large, maybe a little larger than your typical Neapolitan style pizza.  But don't be fooled.  They get the crust so amazingly thin on the bottom that you can easily scarf down 3/4 to a full pie.  We had the spigarello, amatriciana, and margherita.  My personal favorite was the spigarello, which is a type of mild mustard green.  Besides the greens, the pie came topped with an herby, flavorful sausage.  The cheese is supposedly provolone; it is the best darn provolone I have ever had.  Far richer and closer to fontina than anything I've ever put on a Subway sandwich.  All the pies were fantastic though.  I like to judge my pies based on the margherita, but I think the amatriciana better reflects what they do with simple flavors, and if you had to pick between those two, I'd go amatriciana.  Go and enjoy!
author: Pearl L.

description:
Mmmmnnnehh. No thanks. 

Sorry but I don't need to spend $11 on a salad comprised of 9 leaves o lettuce (seriously, I counted). A salad, an app, a pizza and corkage was just under $100. Whoa that's a pricy pizza night. 

Good pizza but not at all worth the price. If you're going to get all precious on me, the food should be really good. Not quite the case here. 

Lovely interior, very comfy and hip. Service was fair and nice, although we filled our own wine glasses after paying a $15 corkage fee. 

Would not waste a perfectly good evening on this spot. You are much better off at Pizzetta 211 or Delphina or SPQR or their better half, Gialina's in Glenn Park.
author: Sara S.

description:
We are HUGE fans of Gialina and have wanted to try their sister restaurant, Ragazza for a while now. 

The space is a little bigger than Gialina and the menu is very similar. Great appetizers, amazing pies and a great wine selection! 

Everything we ate was delicious but I must mention our server, Leah. 
She was one of the best wait persons we have ever had! Warm, friendly and she made us feel so welcome. Just the perfect balance of  attentive but not intrusive. She obviously takes her job seriously and it shows. Thanks Leah! 

While Ragazza was wonderful, Gialina is very close to home so we will probably continue to dine there but if you are in the neighborhood, check out Ragazza. You won't be disappointed!
author: Scott C.

description: Get here early, and you don't have to wait, especially on a weeknight.  I thought the pizza was perfectly cooked with a good crisp (not overly) and the sauce and toppings were quite good.  The appetizers are interesting, I had the arugula salad with beets and pistachios and it was awesome, and my friend had the asparagus and loved it.  Save room for dessert as they are quite good.
author: Dan M.

description:
Just back from a lovely dinner at Ragazza.  A hidden gem in the lower Haight on Divisadero.  I got there early for a solo dinner at the bar.  I was greeted immediately by my exceptional server, Grace, who made me feel comfortable and taken care of.   

Delicious wine (falanghina) and wonderfully fresh arugula salad with beets and goat cheese.  For the entree, I had the stand out homemade cavatelli w pork sugu and I was glad to know the meat was organic, sourced from Niman Ranch and Boccalone.
