I watched a steady stream of people come in for take out pizza and by the time I left, the place was full.  The vibe was friendly and down to earth and they served delicious organic (the meat at least, I didn't ask about the vegetables) food.

I left feeling happy and satisfied.  So glad I stumbled in, I'll be back.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Neighborhood joint, neighborhood fan. 

I've ordered take out pies many times -- ok, one pie, many times -- and it's consistent and consistently good. The potato with smoked bacon, goat cheese + thyme.

Every time I go to pick up an order, the place is vibrant and everyone looks to be having a great time. Yes, it's a small space and your neighbors are close and it's a bit loud but everyone is wining and dining over pizza! What's not to love? If you're uptight and don't like to eat within 2 feet of strangers, don't come here (also, I wouldn't recommend for a first date, serious personal conversation or romantic atmosphere).

When I did finally dine in, I had the kale salad, ricotta cavatelli w/peas and pork belly pizza. LOVED the kale salad (have since imitated it at home) and pasta. Did not love the pork belly pie... just because something is "trendy" does not a pizza make... but I also just really love the potato/bacon pie and I did not love chunks of pork belly in the same way. It wasn't that it was bad, my friend quite enjoyed it. But I will agree with some other reviewers that the bottom crust is very greasy/oily on this pie but it is definitely due to the pork belly being a fatty meat because the potato pie does not have the same issue.

Wine was great, service + receptionist have always been phone + in person friendly! 

Lower Haight Love!
author: A S.

description: I really liked their margherita pizza and wine. I've really been getting a lot of margherita pizzas lately, haven't I? Next time I'll try some of their pasta, which looked quite good.
author: Dan B.

description:
I don't usually write negative reviews but we had such terrible service from the manager of the restaurant to the point that the entire table of 15 was extremely uncomfortable. The rudeness and attitude overshadowed our best friend's birthday dinner before actually the last one we were all celebrating in SF before he was off to law school. 

In addition to the poor service, our party was split into two tables, which is fine but at no point were both tables told how sharing would work. If one table got food, were we supposed to pass around the food to the other table with another party squeezed in right by us? The efficient way to do it is to size the food for the fixed menu for the two separate tables so we didn't have to awkwardly get up and bother the party near us as we went back and forth. One of the times neither tables were told to share the one portion of appetizers and so as one table finished it the other understandably asked for their appetizer too...we were then charged for the added portion to accommodate our table...not that spending 75 a person wasn't good enough. We asked if that could be removed from the bill as a courtesy as we really weren't aware that that one small portion on the separate table was supposed to be shared by both tables and upon asking the manager noted 'are you upset that we didn't store your ice cream cake?' Earlier that night, we asked if we could have them keep the ice cream cake and the manager noted that they don't have a freezer...we went all the way home and dropped it off and then went back after dinner to bring it for our friend. There was no harm done if they don't have a freezer and we all had forgotten except for the manager who very passive aggressively told my boyfriend that he must just be upset about the cake.

All in all the worst dining experience the entire group had in San Francisco in terms of service.
author: R B.

description:
Wow. I was impressed. 

Came here on a Friday night and was seated right away. We each got a glass of wine and shared the bruschetta. My friend got the House Made Cavatelli and I got the Roasted Chicken Breast. The wine was good, the bruschetta was pretty forgettable but WOW, we loved our entrees! So very tasty, we both finished our plates! Dessert was overpriced ice cream but I have to say, it was just such a great meal. Good service and ambiance, but standout delicious food. Would return, and I'd definitely recommend.
author: Maria C.

description:
Don't bother, horrible attitude and god awful wait!

I showed up with out of town guests on a Thursday evening at 6:45PM, the blond hostess said it would be an hour wait and sent us to the bar down the block. An hour later, we came back and sat outside watching her seat everyone except us. I had seen the wait list above us and she clearly was not following it and was not managing the tables well. I made a subtle chill comment about it to her and she came unleashed! She was incredibly rude, condescending and I was so embarrassed that someone in hospitality would talk to a customer that way, especially in front of my out of town guests. 

An hour and a half wait is not worth it. The food is good but to be yelled at by a hostess is ridiculous. If you can't handle the stress or talk to a customer with respect, hospitality is not the job for you, blond hostess girl! And a note to the owners: choose your hostess well, it's the first impression people have of your restaurant and this gal isn't giving San Francisco a good one!

Go to Gialina in Glen Park, the sister restaurant instead. The menu is almost exactly the same but they have a welcome neighborhoody attitude and the wait isn't as insane. Or better yet check out Pizza Nostra in lower Potrero Hill, rarely a wait and they are actually happy to have you, you'll even meet the owner or her husband.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Fresh arugula salad with goat cheese, pistachios and beets. Wild Nettles pizza. Side of rapini with capers and crispy breadcrumbs. A Pilsner. Seat at the bar. Don't bother me, I'm eating.

(Btw, I'm not that much of a fatty - all of this was split between 2 people.)
author: Vi H.

description:
It was good.  The place was cute.  The garden was pretty. Some dude even hit on me while I was waiting for the bathroom (there's only one, so the wait can be long).  In theory, this should be my new favorite joint.  But it's not.  

Maybe it was the hour and a half wait.   Maybe it was all the hype.  I dunno.  I liked it, but I'm not sure its better than some of the other awesome Italian-style pizza places in the city.
author: Renee D.

description:
Like the ambiance of this restaurant a lot. Very cute, clean, and simple decor. We came on a Tuesday night at 7:30pm and there was no wait. My friend has been eating at every good pizza place in SF for the past 2 years, and Ragazza was one of his top 4.

We had:
- Kale Salad w/ avocado, carrots, farro & green garlic dressing
Delicious! Loved the faro and the green garlic dressing. Very refreshing. I could've eaten another one.

- Margherita- tomato, fresh mozzarella & basil
Was ok. There was a bit too much pizza sauce and not enough cheese. Still good, but not amazing.

- Amatriciana - tomato,  pancetta, chilies, pecorino, oregano & an egg
Loved the spicy tomato sauce a lot! Was delicious. Love the egg on top. I ordered another to-go for my boyfriend. Thin crust pizza was great. Didn't like that the crust was a little droopy. With thin crust, I feel like there should be a little more structure to the crust.

- Flourless chocolate cake
Tasty. Not the best I've had, but I liked it paired with the thick cream on top.

I would come back again.
author: Gina R.

description: Worst customer service I've experienced in a long time. It was freezing like the North Pole, windows open, fans blaring,  back door open and when we asked them to at least turn down the fans they were rude and said no. Other people there were bundled up  in coats.
author: Jorge D.

description:
Food was decent, nothing special; it was served more warm than hot and we ate pretty quickly, but it was cold before we were done; hostess regularly came by and asked, "Is everything wonderful?," in a tone/way that came across more as teen-hippy than professional; and it struck me as poor value. 

Plate of ravioli, a pizza, a glass of wine and iced tea for $53 without a tip. Even keeping the tip lower than usual to reflect lower-than-usual quality, that's $60 for not much mediocre food and unprofessional service.

As mentioned, this place does pack 'em in, which said at least as much to me as the reviews here. Maybe I had a relatively bad experience for whatever reason(s), but in this city and in that part of the city, I am more than a little surprised that people put up with this; I've experienced too many other places 'round here that have substantially better food, service and prices.

One and done.
author: bob h.

description:
Happy to see the Metro Hotel restaurant turn over to a high quality pizza place.  

(I always loved it when this was the Metro Cafe, but have not gone for years when that changed hands and the cuisine changed.)

Regazza -- nice high quality thin crust pizzas.  Can never have too many of these.  Very popular so plan on putting your name in a good hour in advance.  

The area I will particularly call out is the salads -- really high attention to detail here, especially the Farro salad.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I'm so glad that I finally went to Ragazza...it's delicious!  Got there at 5:45p on a Saturday night and were seated right away.  

We had the arugula salad, orecchiette with pesto, and the Moto pizza.    Everything was very tasty, especially the pasta. 

I will definitely be back soon.
author: Janelle F.

description:
I hate to write a negative review, since I really wanted this local spot to meet up all the hype. However, there were just too many pretty basic things that were wrong... 

Firstly, the "No Wait" queueing system doesn't work. We were quoted a wait time of up to 75 minutes (fine given that we arrived at 7.30 on a Saturday). The problem was that the system doesn't update properly and kept saying that there were 11 people ahead of us. Honestly, not a big deal, but a bit annoying.

More importantly, one entree came out about 10 minutes before the other. If you are having dinner with another person, I'd expect the food to come out together.

Thirdly, the pasta was under seasoned  and slightly over cooked. 

Finally, the parmesan that we asked for was provided in a shaker, just like in a $3 slice shop...

Hopefully things get better since I'd like to come back!
author: Sunil G.

description:
Ragazza pizza was pretty good.  If you're looking for cheap and quick pizza, this is not the place to go. If you're looking for more like del fina type pizza, gourmet, interesting combinations, fresh ingredients, you will enjoy this place.

one downside to the pizzas we got: we thought they were a little bland. would love for explosions of flavor via the topics and/or the cheese. hell even the sauce. don't think it really came through last time.

can only speak to the food since we took it to go. definitely want to go back to try out some other pizzas, see if i enjoy those more.
author: Sandy K.

description:
Not that this place really even needs another multi-star review - but wow... absolutely everything was delicious. 

Loved the entire experience and will definitely be back. In particular, I really liked the balance of flavors in the wild nettles pie and kale salad. The Barolo wine was perfect...
author: Amarar S.

description: great atmosphere, but unfortunately no options for the gluten free crowd, which is a huge bummer.
author: l c.

description: Solid 4 stars. Really nice service. Amazing salads.... like... amazing. The pizza is solid. I am a fan.
author: Jayne M.

description: Tasty bread, uninspired pasta. Baked rigatoni was way too sweet and the cavatelli was spicy but nothing special. Maybe we just ordered the wrong dishes, but I don't know what the fuss is about.
author: Lauren W.

description:
I picked up two pies for Friday night takeout date night. Very tasty! They survived the ride home well, too.

I ordered the Margarita and the Atomica (Moto with no sausage - portobello mushrooms, delicately sliced red onion, calabrian chilies). $13 each. Both were delicious and better value than expected. The Margarita had plenty of fresh basil and flavorful sauce. We love LOTS of red pepper flakes on our pizza so we were thrilled with the Atomica's use of calabrian chilies for an awesomely flavorful pie. The crust is very good - chewy, crispy, lighter than it looks - but not quite deserving of an "excellent" rating.

I had a glass of vermentino at the bar while waiting and found it a great spot to watch all the action in the kitchen and the different dishes flying out to various tables. Quite a production! The restaurant itself is very cute and cozy - we'll be back to dine-in next time and try some of the non-pizza items. :)
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Being Gialina's sister restaurant, I had high hopes for Ragazza to turn out to be another favorite pizza place I'd be happy to frequent.  While I thought the pies were delicious, the service was not up to par.  The hostesses demeanor was off-putting as she told me I needed to wait outside for my friend before I could be seated.  While it's understandable in most cases, especially if it's packed, the place was not even half full.  To make matters worse, the restaurant was bustling by the time we were about to leave, yet, a patron was seated as she waited for her party to arrive.  Regardless, it was more the hostesses attitude than anything else.  This is something that I know would not happen at Gialina.  While a bit chilly, I was grateful that it wasn't raining, otherwise, I would've hightailed it back up Divisadero to Little Star.

It's very reminiscent of my experience at Pizzaiolo in Oakland, where good service is the missing element to what could be a great restaurant.  I'd be willing to give them another shot if I so happen to be in the area again.
author: Marsha Z.

description: I've had some of the most pleasurable pizza/Italian inspired food of my life at Ragazza. The staff and management are some of the nicest, most professional people I've ever had the pleasure of dining under. I don't know why people wait for this experience if they can't fully appreciate it. There are plenty of mediocre restaurants in the immediate area that will seat you right away! Well worth the wait!
author: Daniel W.

description: Appetizers & pizzas were outstanding.  Great selection of beer & wine.  Service was great, very friendly & attentive.  Well worth the wait on a busy Friday night.  Go across the street & grab a cocktail & they'll text you when your table is ready.
author: Johna W.

description:
I stopped by on some friend's recommendations and was thoroughly impressed!  The wait staff was amazing and so was the food!  
1 -- Amatriciana: you can't go wrong with an egg-topped meat pizza
2 -- Wild nettles pizza: I was incredibly blown away by this (this is coming from a strict carnivore), though I don't think they serve it on the menu anymore/this time of year....wah wah
3 -- Red butter lettuce: amazing antipasto to share
4 --Tiramisu: meh...on the dry side for my taste, but still delicious if you still have room in your tummy!
author: Ben T.

description:
Pizza was good, crust was delicious, service and ambiance where both swell, but I have one big peeve. Virtually every pizza with a red sauce was spicy. If you're going to name the pizzas then list the toppings, make sure to note that the Calabrian chiles are in the sauce, and not just a topping like everything else. I had assumed I'd be able to move them aside, but alas, my date had to eat an entire pizza himself, minus the one crust piece I took.

Best part of the meal? Dessert. I am a sucker for good panna cotta, and this one was perfect. I pretty much inhaled the entire thing myself while my date was in the bathroom. Whoops. Oh well, he was full from all the pizza anyway.
author: Amanda S.

description:
This place is delicious! I heard about it before. All good feedback. Sometimes this is exaggerated. But not this time. I am a fan. Great pizza, authentic crust and all! The pasta was Al Dente. 

The location is great, and a cool atmosphere. 
Go try it.
author: cyril l.

description: Having eaten here twice, I really don't understand the high marks by fellow Yelpers. I've tried all the signature dishes on offer and they are all mediocre at best. Nothing stands out. Why anyone would eat here instead of Delfina Pizzeria baffles me. DP is 10x better.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
On a return visit, I gotta say this place still rocks.  Sitting at the bar, you get the best seat in the house as you can see all the action in the kitchen and see pie after delicious pie come out of the oven.

First of all, the service is as friendly as ever.  Love the laidback feel of the place but the dishes come out reasonably fast.

This time around, we ordered the wild arugula salad with beets, goat cheese and hazelnut.  Love this combination of peppery, sweet and creamy goodness.  The side of Corona beans with kale and breadcrumbs was really good as well.

Also liked the pork sugo with strozzapreti ("priest stranglers) pasta although not as much as the pizzas.

While I loved the wild nettles pizza from before and was interested in the sunchokes w/ salume pizza, we went with the asparagus pie with green garlic, mozzarella, farm egg and truffled pecorino.  It was good but I felt it lacked a little in flavor (maybe a savory topping).

Still, can't wait to go back.  Next up to try: the amazingly-looking chicory salad w/ avocado, housemade pickled vegetables and the sunchokes pizza!

--------------
update (Sept 2011)

Went back for dinner and it looks like there are a couple of new pies (maybe based on the season and fresh ingredients that are available).

The wild nettles is still my favorite.  The additional fried egg is a must for this pizza as it adds a really pleasant creaminess that helps to balance the nettles.

The heirloom tomato pizza with smoked bacon and arugula was my second favorite and had a nice fresh taste and satisfying crunch from the bacon.

The moto pizza (With chiles, mushrooms, sausage and red onions) sounded amazing ... but turned out to be just so-so for me.  Perhaps the sausage made it saltier but the flavors here weren't as complex and innovative compared to the other pies.
author: F. P.

description:
Don't you love it when Plan B turns out better than Plan A?

The latter was Saffron a few blocks away. Our original destination, we soon were out of luck upon seeing a sign saying they were closed for a few weeks. Gone on holiday? Enjoy.

The former became Ragazza. From the same people that brought us the epic and still remembered three years later Gialini (http://www.yelp.com/biz/gialina-pizzeria-san-francisco#hrid:o8h4yOIbvHRF1k5IRhz2kw), this new addition to the 7 x 7 pizza scene is outstanding.

Start with a salad. The mixed greens, pomegranates, persimmons, goat cheese and pistachios salad is colorful, flavorful and fantastic.

Split a pie. We went with the basic margherita with tomato, mozzarella and basil. There was nothing basic about the outstanding taste.

Complement with a side. You might want to go with some of the best roasted squash I've ever had.

Grab a few drinks and toast it all.

I'll make it to Saffron someday. I will most likely leave still thinking about Ragazza.
author: Jason B.

description:
My hubby is Italiano...from Italy....so he's super critical when it comes to pizzarias.
I thought we ought to try them out...having heard great things about Gialina.

The antipasto was delish!  He was happy with the pizza, so ok, the picky Italian in him said the crust was a little greasy (well, it was for me too).  But overall, the food was great.

Service?  Well....the lack of it or should I say hmmm...our waitress was uninterested, not one smile, as though we are disrupting her beloved afternoon nap.  We had a few slices wrapped as a doggie bag....well, ok, partially our fault for forgetting, but she handed us the check (after we tried numerous times to get her attention) but did not bring the bag along with the check...

Nope, great food is nice, but not without decent service....
author: Barb L.

description: Ordered the pizza with an egg on it, a bottle of white wine, and the antipasti appetizer. Delish. The place is small however. Prices are mid-range. Waitress was very nice and helpful.
author: Nadia L.

description: Great quality food, great service and all around cheerful vibe. Area is a little busy, but what do you expect on Divisadero? I highly recommend! Great for date nights. :)
author: Gabe E.

description:
I'm a (relatively) recent NYC transplant to SF and have been looking for great pizza since my arrival. I like the food at Tony's Pizza Napoletana but the scene is a bit too Mulberry Street (not a good thing these days) for my taste. A16 is very good but a bit too fancy and heavily oiled / salted for my taste. Delfina is terrific, no doubt. I dig the scene and the Chicago style pie at Little Star up the street from Ragazza but it's a totally different beast. There are probably 15 - 20 other places I've tried, many of which are good but none really stand out.

Went to Ragazza last night and was blown away by the pizza. We sat at the bar in the back, which was a good decision because we got to watch the guys and gals in action. It was a thing of beauty, other than the ridiculous huge red Ragazza patches they have on their chef coats.

The pizza was the best I've had in SF, definitely rivaling some of my NYC favs: Lombardi's, John's, Grimaldi's and even Roberta's. Very thin and crispy crust, beautifully adorned with, in the case of the Moto, a well balanced red sauce, coarsely chopped mushrooms, some chilies, just the right amount of cheese and a 15 - 20 morsels of sausage that were hot enough to announce their presence but not overpowering.   

The little gem salad with kumquats was OK - a bit overdressed and undersalted. We usually skip getting new plates between courses but actually asked for one this time b/c of all the salad sauce (seems like a better choice of words than dressing given the viscosity and volume) remaining on the plate.

The cannoli was also just OK, despite the promising description from one of the gracious servers (from the Bronx, woot). The shell was a bit lighter than the ones I'm used to from Ferrara's but the mascarpone-based filling, while light, lacked a bit of flavor IMHO. I'm not an expert on these, though, so Ragazza's might have been the real deal.

Will be back and try a few more dishes. I wouldn't be surprised to give them a full five stars next time given the attention to detail and earnestness of the team that I observed.
author: Mike B.

description:
finally!  A restaurant in the NOPA area with good italian food!

Although everyone raves about Ragazza's fabulous pizza (which it is- I fell absolutely in love with the buttery thin crust!)  I must say, the pasta was pretty damn yummy!  We had the short rib pasta and butternut squash pasta- both were amazing!  The short rib pasta was very filling and very generous with both the pasta and meat.  The butternut squash pasta, though, definitely blew me out of the water!  SO SO good, I felt like I could have that dish as an app, main dish, or dessert... I highly suggest this seasonal dish.

The service was very friendly and the atmosphere was inviting.  I will definitely be back for more!
author: Clarissa P.

description: Terrible service ... think of how you are treated at the DMV.  If you want the experience of yelling over dinner & watching the staff on their smart phones while being ignored, dine here. You're better off just going to 7-Eleven and eating their food.
author: Carb Q.

description:
A terrific addition to the neighborhood.  Good comfortable vibe, easygoing, yet still very polished.  Waitstaff very professional and helpful.  
Pizzas are good, interesting combinations, crust was too thin, very little substance/texture and taste.
Delicious contorni.  Appetizers very pleasing, too.
Wine list edited and good.  I appreciate that.  
Dessert dismal.  Cannoli was imitation, an imposter from an earlier decade.  A pizzelle cookie rolled around thick custard.  Had been hoping for a homemade cannoli, after all the rustic touting.  Truffle cake was whipped ganache, dry and flaky.  Not appealing.
author: Darryl C.

description: Good I had only ever had their pizza, but we went and ate inside this time! Wish they had the items that everyone liked on yelp available! (Meatballs/ pork belly) Service was pretty good bedsides we waited 20 min for our desert to go! But accidents happen waiters are human too and forget!! Pizza was good as always!
author: Nick N Parker S.

description:
Yum!

Nettle pizza was divine as was the calamari starter.  Service was professional and helpful, but gave us our space, too.  Good and good.

Wasn't too impressed by the funghi pizza, though.   It lacked a certain kick.  It's pretty cramped in there as well.  While I get that this kind of comes with the territory in pizza joints, it did get a bit hard to hear the conversation at our table.

I'd go back, for sure.
author: Bria L.

description:
I take back what I said. Ragazza rocks. I had the nettles pizza recently and it blew my mind. 

Always seems like there's a wait so I just got take-out and the best part was that the pizza didn't get soggy like it usually does when you get it to-go. 

Stoked that there's a good pizza spot in the 'hood.
author: Alli J.

description:
I am a huge fan of chantrelle mushrooms and was pleasantly surprised to see a chantrelle mushroom pizza on the menu. It came LOADED with the mushrooms, which was an even greater pleasant surprise! Excellent pizza. The arugula salad with beets, goat cheese and pistachios was amazing also. 

They are working on obtaining a license to serve outside on the patio/garden area. If they succeed, this would be a great place for warm days/nights.
author: Yevi A.

description: With charming servers, creative and delicious pastas and perhaps the best traditional pizza in SF - this place is a win.
author: Jenn D.

description:
I have a confession. I am a pizza junkie. I seriously could eat pizza every.single.day. 

I was a little hesitant to try Ragazza after a less then spectacular experience at Gialina's (the sister restaurant in Glen Park), but after deciding enough time had passed, and heard great things about Ragazza, we decided to give it a go. 

We went on a Wednesday night, called ahead to put our name on the list (since they don't take reservations) and wandered down to the cute new cafe/wine/beer place on the corner of Divis/Oak (which replaced the cafe that replaced the little liquor store where I used to buy alcohol underage with my awesome fake ID). 

So, after a small confusion with the hostess (she wrote down we were a party of 2, there were 4 of us), we were seated at our table and prepared for our pizza journey. Two of my dining companions had been to Ragazza before, so I just followed their lead - except I was insistent that we order the Heirloom Tomato Pizza (seriously, do it before it disappears from the menu). 

Our server was amazing and attentive. She knew her stuff and kept making sure we were still doing alright. 

The pizzas were great! My only complaint was that the bottle of wine ran out too quickly! Otherwise, an all in all great pizza experience. Here's a play by play of what we ordered: 

Anti pasta- Arugula Salad w/ peaches, Cypress Grove goat cheese & pistachios $10/$20 
****Thoughts - Salad was good. Great flavor and generous hunks of goat cheese. It did however, need more peaches! 

Pizzas! 
Moto- tomato, Calabrian chilies, portobello mushrooms, red onion, sausage & mozzarella $16 
*****Thoughts - This pizza was good. Not my favorite, but had good flavor. 

Amatriciana w/ tomato, Boccalone pancetta, chilies, pecorino, oregano & an egg $16 
*****Thoughts - ORDER THIS NOW. Thank me later. My favorite pizza of the night! Such a great combination of flavors and the egg puts it over the top. 

Mariquita Heirloom Tomatoes w/ applewood smoked bacon, mozzarella, basil & wild arugula $19 
****Thoughts - My second favorite of the night. Especially when you got the perfect bite of all the components together with the ripe heirloom tomato. HEAVEN! 

Escarole w/ caramelized onion, Nostrano salume & Val d'Aosta fontina $17 
***Thoughts - I don't know if I would order this again. It was good, but needed a bit more salt/seasoning. It would be standout if it had a good pungent cheese instead of fontina to give it a kick start.
author: Landon W.

description:
Dude, there are hellsa thin-crust Neapolitan-style pizzas in SF nowadays... HELLSA.  No complaints here cuz I really love any type of pizza, but a lot of the places have so much hype that it's hard to get a reservation or they don't take them. I'm becoming quite impatient when dining out and don't have energy for the long waits. Hopefully with so many new places, it'll be easier to get a table at these spots. 

So even though Ragazza's a welcome addition in my 'hood, I didn't think I'd make it this early on since they don't take ressies (reason why I never made it to Gialina). Well, we went at early bird time at 5 pm on a Sunday. There was still a good neighborhood feel and there were couples with small kids. I have no idea what the wait or crowd is like later in the evening. 

Overall, the food was delicious.  Everything was seasoned really well. We started with the salume plate, breadcrumbed sardines, and pork belly with figs.  We thought some of the salads were priced really high, but we got some arugula and other greens with our antipasti (the large salad the other table ordered was huge, served in a big salad bowl). I'd skip the salume plate since the amount of actual cured meats was minimal (check out Una Evoteca's selection of carne a few blocks away instead). 

I loved the potato and bacon pizza (don't forget to add egg on yo pie!) cuz really what's not to like about those toppings? Taleggio cheese gives it a good salty kick so no Parmesan necessary. I love all types of eggs and egg yolk as a pizza dip is no exception. I thought the crust was just a tad dry, but there were no burnt/black areas except for the big bubbles on top which I love. The next time I'll probably just focus on the pizzas and skip the starters. They usually only feature one pasta dish. Ragazza will probably be a take out pizza spot for me on fancy dinner night.

Note: no gluten-free pizza or pasta options
author: Mimi L.

description: The pizza is to die for.  I got the potato goat cheese one and it was different, but tasty.  Small place, but cozy.
author: Mike M.

description:
Ragazza's pizza continues to impress --pork belly w/red sauce and chard outstanding, also rice balls w/"angry tomato" fantastic. 
The quick wits of our server Grace diffused a sudden altercation from the street into the restaurant-- felt like I was back in Fair Haven at Grand apizza.
Anyhow, high quality pizza not laden w/mozzarella--
Attractive, upbeat atmosphere too w/nonas pictured on the wall.
author: Jack G.

description:
First of all, let me just say that I don't normally judge a place by their bathroom. But Ragazza's restroom was just the most awesome bathroom space - it was small, but decorated with these great vintage picture frames that I totally wanted to steal. 

Moving on.

We got an early dinner before going to see The Flaming Lips over in Oakland, and boy, was I glad we had an excuse to go early. At 5:45pm we got seated immediately. By 6:15pm there was a 45 min wait for 2 people. Luckily, they take phone numbers (and the Page is right across the street!). Worth the wait, I say.

Food: 
- The beet & arugula salad (with goat cheese) was light and delicious.
- The wild nettle pizza had a golden crust and I loved that the nettles weren't wilted, but crispy. 
- The crust on the margherita was thinner than the wild nettle pizza -- I later found out that it's the same crust, but the pizza crust comes out differently with different cheeses and toppings!

The ONLY issue was that they brought out the wild nettle pizza first.... and didn't bring out the margherita until we were done. I like to sample one slice and then another, instead of eating 4 slices of one pizza and then moving on to the next. It didn't ruin the meal though.

Wine:
Now, let me address this wine situation. Yes, the by-the-glass is pricey ($7-10), but we got a bottle for $22. You can get 3/4ths of a bottle (500ml) for $18! I think that's totally worth while. If you are worried about getting a small pour, pop for an extra $9 and guarantee that you'll have enough wine to guzzle throughout dinner.

Dessert:
Ricotta cheesecake was unnecessary (I was so full!) but I had to try it. Mmmmmm. The portion wasn't too big, but it was definitely sweet.

Overall, the service here was great (we overheard servers having to deal with customers being grumpy about waiting...and they were very nice about it). The food was delicious. Go early, get a quartino of wine, and enjoy!

P.S. Those pictures on the wall and in the bathroom? They're the owner's family!
author: Hannah L.

description:
So I thought Delfina's pies were my favorite until I tried Ragazza. Wow! The crust is slightly thinner than Delfina's and the sauce is fantastic. Amazing flavors on the sausage pie.

I've never sat down to eat at the restaurant - only had take out. So I can't comment on service. However, it is a bit small and loud. My little takeaway from picking up our pies inside.

Sorry Delfina, I'm officially cheating on you. ;-)
author: Scott N.

description: Like it because: it's on Divisadero Street in a cool little storefront; near enough to my house that I could easily order to go; only got one pie which I liked OK (the "Moto") but feel that I need to try others to get the full sense of the place - the food didn't wow me. But really I had to review because of the NUTELLA PIZZA - which is really my kind of dessert: HUGE serving - nutella spread on puffy baked bread, topped w a dollop of mascarpone. Couldn't finish it, which is rare for me with a dessert. Will try again for sure.
author: Judith S.

description:
Always happy to welcome a new pizza place into the hood!

I'll start by agreeing with all the comments about the wine pours being very small. I was surprised to see how little was poured into my glass, and almost asked about it (but I didn't want the waitress to think I was a lush). It's nice to see I'm not alone (either that, or we're all lushes... huh). But I usually have a glass of wine when I'm out, and I've never had that feeling of being shortchanged before.The wine was good though!

As for the pizza, it was very good. We had the margherita, and I enjoyed it. However, it was the first time in my life that adding an egg on top of a pizza didn't improve it... I'll probably go without next time. Made the center way too soggy, but that usually isn't an issue with most pizzas.

There will always be some growing pains, and I look forward to coming back again.
author: Veronica B.

description: Pretty good pizza. Less impressed with the appetizers. The meatballs in particular were actually sort of cold when we got them. Cardinal sin.
author: Misha T.

description:
I LOVE this place! The food is always fantastic!

The farro salad, chicken liver pate, and the Mariquita Farm fava greens pizza on their current menu is wonderful.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I am changing my review from 3 to 5 stars.  After I posted the review below, less than 24 hours later I got a reply from Ragazza, apologizing for the incident, confirming that yes, neighbors can call and put their name on the list. (yahoo!).  Thanks so much for the prompt follow-up, we will definitely see you soon!

***************

We have eaten here several times, and it's always been great.  The food is definitely 5 stars.  On last trip, however, the service left us cold.  As we live a few blocks away, we called to put our name on the list - there is usually always a wait.  We've done this several times before, and they were accommodating because we lived in the neighborhood.  This time, however, the hostess replied that they don't put names on the list unless you are present.  We explained that we were 3 blocks away, and that we had previously called and were able to put our name on the list.  The hostess retorted "I don't know who would have let you do that, but it was not us" and hung up on us.

Maybe it was a very stressful night, maybe the hostess was new.  I love the food, so we'll try again.  We hope the service has improved.  It is OK to say no to our request. But perhaps less rudely.
author: Karleen O.

description:
The heirloom tomato arugula pizza here deserves a 4 star. The quaint little garden in the back was a pleasant surprise. I would have definitely recommended this place to my friend If it weren't for the disappointing and unnecessarily rude service and attitude from the hostess. 

We got here around 7 on a Sunday night and ordered a few drinks and appetizers while waiting in the back garden. 5 minutes later we were told that our table was ready. After being seated for about half an hour, still no sign of the wines we ordered. After nicely reminding the hostess, I was given an annoyed look followed by: as you can see we are very busy and you guys were the last to be seated. (seriously, in those words) I was a little taken back by the response and proceeded to explain that I was just checking that they transferred our drink order from the backyard. Guess I wasn't allowed to question that because, yes, it was all done...or so we were told. Another 15 minutes goes by and still no sign of our drinks. We brought it up to our waitress (who was nice), and she explained that she never received our order. 

We ended up waiting another half an hour for our pizza. The whole dinner took 2 hours, and actual eating time was about 20 minutes. Our waitress was nice enough to compensate with a complimentary pita bread appetizer with fresh figs, cheese, and beets - which was delicious. With that said, the wait and bad attitude from the hostess was uncomfortable enough to keep us from going back.
author: Nattie X.

description: This place has amazing pizza, cheese and wine.  Order the mozzarella cheese appetizer and the pizza with some veggies and cheese on it (forgot the name).
author: Peter Y.

description: I can't Believe this place has four stars. The food here is ok but the Manager( the bold guy) is a jerk with no respect at all. SERVICE IS BAAAD.
author: Hamik G.

description:
Wow!  This was some of the best pizza!  I had the yummy brussel sprout pizza, delicious arugula salad, and some really amazing Italian wine.

The staff was awesome!  Totally hip and friendly people.  The atmosphere was loud but cozy.  The wait was long, about an hour, but it is in a great location to go have a drink, in the neighborhood,  while you are waiting.
author: Lily B.

description:
I attended a preview dinner and thought is was perfect.  I had no idea what to expect.  I was frustrated from looking for parking, but my friend had already ordered the corn/moz/tomato salad and had it waiting for me.  Refreshing and well balanced.  Then i started noticing the decor.  Its a very comfortable place.  The wood tables are warm on your forearms, the lights are soft.

I quickly picked the squash and squash blossom pizza.  Perfectly thin, not oily.  The sweetness of the squash came through and the blossoms provided nice texture.  The caramelization on the top of the pizza was perfect.  The seasonings were perfect, not too much and well integrated.

The short ribs on pasta came cold (but tasted great), but the server noticed hesitation in my response to feedback and insisted that they redo the dish.  It came back hot and perfect very quickly.

Dessert was perfectly portioned.  The cheese cake was not tart.  It was more cake than cheese and the pine cone reduction added a bit of zing.

Perfect dinner.
author: H C.

description:
I'm not a fan of the ridiculous pizza trend in the city, but this is one that I love.  (Pizzetta 211 is the other.)  It's farm-freshy but not wimpy.  It's totally hearty and comforting.  And, the CRUST!  Delicious and maybe a little buttery?  Whatever it is, it's good stuff.

Everything was vibrant and beautiful and delicious.  We were pretty stuffed after eating the amazing other dishes, so we all shared one delicious nettles pizza for dessert.  "Amazing other dishes" = braised beet greens with bacon & goat cheese; lean? pork belly w/ farro and figs; little gems w/ shaved raw sunchokes & goddess dressing; delicata squash w/ ricotta & nuts.  All of that, 4 of us, 3 beers each = $40/each.

One gripe is that the hostess was lame.  There were maybe 6 empty tables and totally empty bar, and she said we weren't allowed to grab a drink at the bar while we waited for the rest of our party to show up. Yep, go out in the cold when the resto is half full.  Lady, c'mon!
author: Melanie C.

description:
I love small establishments like this because they excel in the quality of food and service they provide. I appreciate that the menu changes on a daily basis, a facet that guarantees freshness. Overall, the service with Grace was extremely chill while maintaining a professional vibe. The food was simple but executed in way that show cases the power of top ingredients with masterly seasoning. I chose the calamari entree which periodically appears on the menu. If its available, you MUST order it! The dish consists of four perfectly balanced ingredients: roasted calamari, baby potatoes, broccolini and a citrus Aïoli. My mouth watered with every bite. 

I can't wait to bring more friends here!
author: Moises T.

description: Went for a friend's birthday dinner here and sat outside.  Really fun, though we had to be gone by 10 or something because of neighborhood noise concerns.  The pizzas are excellent and service is friendly.  I happen to like Gialina a bit better.
author: Kevin M.

description: Pretty good pizza. Beware, the Nutella dessert pizza is not a one person dessert. Hmm dessert, nom nom.
author: Heather R.

description:
Just as fabulous as its more discrete sister restaurant in Glen Park, Ragazza hits all the right marks.  Thin crust pizza, exactly the way it should be, with interesting toppings, delicious salads, and reasonable prices. 
Make sure to anticipate a healthy wait, though.  The place is always packed, no matter what day of the week.  Luckily, there's a newish wine bar a few doors down where, over a glass or two of wine, you can attempt to forget how long you have been waiting.
author: SL N.

description: Well after a great evening of fine food and great drinks I expected to end the evening in an awesome way. I ordered the Nutella pizza, awaiting in anticipation for this delicious dish, after 10 minutes of waiting a waitress returned telling me this dish was sold out. Why wasn't this information disclosed prior to my ordering? The next thing you know the table next to us got this very dessert I ordered. Not cool.  Not cool.
author: Michael D.

description:
Wish this place took reservations!! They tend to underestimate the wait time, and they forgot about us when we went to a bar across the street. They apologized, but next time comp us some wine for the extra wait, ok thanks.

However, the food was excellent! This is your spot if you prefer truly thin-crust pizza. The tomatoes and basil on the margherita were fresh. The three-cheese was luxuriant but my favorite was the spicy Amatriciana with the unexpected egg on top - wonderful. 

The menu changes seasonally, and for winter we had the roasted root vegetables, which were sublime and not overly cooked or overly buttered, and the brussel sprouts, which converted me completely to their roasted perfection. 
The dish that had me dreaming for days, however, was the creamy bake rigatoni with squash. I know its almost spring, but bring it back BRING IT BACK!
author: Maria A.

description:
I love the owners' other restaurant, Gialina, so I was looking forward to trying out Ragazza.  Since the last time I ate at Gialina, I've moved a couple blocks from Pizzetta 211, and I think I'm spoiled now.

We had the pork belly, the beet salad, and the bean salad, plus the Amatriciana and Wild Nettle pizzas.

The greens in the appetizers were a little overdressed, so they were a bit too vinegary and salty.  The bean salad was wonderful, surprising, not too vinegary at all, bright flavors, pretty, good bite.

The pizzas weren't perfect.  The crust was just a bit too thick, so it felt too chewy in places.  The dough itself is fantastic - it has that shininess that I associate with a starter-leavened dough.  I suspect those last 2 points are related.  It was a little undercooked, not colored all the way to the edge, and it seemed as though it might have sat for a few minutes before arriving at our table - there was some condensation at the bottom.  One of the yolks had broken on the farm egg pizza, and who wants scrambled eggs on pizza?  The other egg, to be fair, was cooked perfectly for my taste.  

The nettle pizza is terrific, though with preserved lemon in the ingredient list, I expected a little more of that fragrant lemon complexity.  

The desserts were good, maybe too big.  The ricotta cheesecake  was sweet for my taste but wonderfully rich.  I wasn't as much in love with the chocolate pistachio cake.

The hostess was wonderful, but the server was condescendingly polite, going out of her way to let us know how much it wasn't a problem to fulfill our run-of-the-mill requests.  Uh, yeah, I'd hope it isn't a problem!

So, it's not my favorite pizza place in town, but I'll happily go back and give it another shot.
author: Lulu L.

description:
I like coming here for the non pizza items! I have had the pizza here but it really doesn't stand out compared to the salads and pasta dishes and there are other places in town i prefer for pizza.

The big winner has been the eggplant parmesan. it really shines because i think they are using a smoked mozzarella. 

The staff are all very friendly and if it is nice out you should check out their beautiful back patio. it is like having dinner in a garden
author: Leuwam T.

description:
I think magic happened when I ordered one of their pizzas topped with a fried egg. From that day forward, I was like, "I'm never eating a pizza without fried egg again!!!" (even though I did). BUT, Ragazza really impressed me.

The place is small, but super cute and quaint. Holla boys, you want to take alllll your honeys here. Pizza doesn't seem like it can swoon the ladies, but it DOES. Especially when there is fried egg on top.

I also had the chicken. Not in the same sitting, I'm not a FATASS. I had it the second time I went. It was equally delish.

Plus, one of the waitresses had a tattoo similar to mine. *TWINSIES*
author: Michelle N.

description: For me, a truly great thin crust pizza has to be very thin with a bit of crunch and has to have enough strength to hold up the toppings.  Ragazza's Triple-P did not disappoint!  The sauce was not overwhelming and the quantity of pork belly was just right, although I wouldn't mind having thicker pieces.  The kale and faro salad was also incredibly delicious with what seems to be a light buttermilk-lemony dressing.  I hate overly dressed salads but this was also very well balanced.
author: Shing W.

description:
I want to give this place more stars because the pizza was good, but I can't. Maybe if I come back and the pasta blows me away I'll revise it.

Pizza - 4 stars. My group of three split 2 pizzas, and it was just the right amount of food. If you like thin crust, this is it! I prefer more sauce and bread myself, but I enjoyed it all the same. 

Drinks - 2 stars. The drinks menu is pretty mediocre, at best. There are maybe 3 beers, I ordered one and it came in a bottle, without even a glass to pour it in. For shame. The cheapest glass of wine on the menu is $9. No thank you. 

Dessert - 2 stars. We ordered the ricotta cheesecake with peaches (or so the menu stated). It came with cherries instead, and no explanation. We used our expert powers of deduction and concluded that they either ran out of peaches, or changed the menu. Either way, it would have been nice to hear it from our server. 

Service - 4 stars. We came at 6:30 on a Tuesday and the place was empty - for all of you complaining about the wait - here's the time to go! Our server was friendly. I'll still definitely come back, but strictly for the food.
author: Alyssa G.

description: The hubby and I stopped in for dinner here finally. We live in the neighborhood and have heard good things. Our waitress was really disconnected which kind of sucked but what can you do. We started off with the arugula, beet, pistachio salad. Very delicious and refreshing. The beets were cooked perfectly (I hate mushy beets). Next up were our pizzas. We would live on pizza if we could but unfortunately our guts and wallets cant afford that. I ordered the Moto (w/o sausage) and the and the babe ordered a margherita pizza. They came out lukewarm which was very disappointing. These are Neapolitan style pizzas but ours just felt too thin. The kind of thin that roughs up your mouth. The sauce though was good as well as the mushrooms. Just a bit too rough and hard for my taste. I would be willing to try again (maybe was an off night for the pizza guy). So far Zero Zero has been my #1 all around for pizza in SF.
author: Bri R.

description:
Holy God . . . an hour and a half long wait?  Are you joking?  This food better be plucked from the heavens to justify this long of a wait.  Thankfully, the Page is right across the street so a few drinks and an hour and a half went by relatively quickly.

I find it a bit obnoxious when restaurants don't take reservations and the wait is this long.  I mean, really.  Why?  Just why.  At least they take your phone number and call you when a table is ready instead of making you hang out on the sidewalk.  

So the food.  The Moto pizza was pretty good.  Spicy.  Sausage-y.  Not anything mind blowing, but good, nonetheless.  Then came the ricotta cheesecake.  Which was unexpectedly fantastic although I think it was around $7 for a very slight wedge.  Definitely overpriced, but a pleasant surprise.  

Everything was fine, nothing was extraordinary.  Well, besides that tiny piece of cheesecake.  And when there's nothing extraordinary, an hour and a half is just too long to wait.
author: Jenny R.

description:
I've only been for the pizza. 5 stars, no jokes neapolitan style pizza, perfect dough/crust.

Very friendly service.

The pizza is so good I actually will crave it the next day until my next visit and then again. The salads are delicious and fluffy and the sides are pretty filling.

2 people- 1 salad, 1 pizza, 1 side, 1 bottle of wine. Now thats a date!

I'm pleased Ragazza is located where it is, divis needs it!
author: xxalex k.

description:
YES!! This NY-bred pizza snob gives this place a high five and a slap on the ass for its very solid efforts. 

The nettle/ parm pizza was delicious, crispy throughout (ahem, flour+water, here's where you could stand to pay attention!), the perfect amount of dough for a thin-crust pizza, and an unusual ingredient combo that works together really well. Little gems salad was delicious as well, if a tad pricey. 

After many misses, this location finally has a winner!
author: who k.

description:
I've been trying to dine at Ragazza since it opened, but it's been packed every night, so last night I walked over at 7pm to put my name down for 8:15.

We arrived at 8pm and were seated early!  Our server was incredibly friendly and gave us some great recommendations.  We had the polenta, pork belly/fig dish and the squash.  All three were great, but the squash was AMAZING.  I could eat that dish every night.

We had the Heirloom Tomato w/ bacon, mozzarella, basil & wild arugula pizza with an egg on top.  It was tasty, but had too much arugula .  The heirloom tomatoes were incredibly fresh.

For dessert, we ordered olive oil cake with fresh strawberries and the Chocolate-Pistachio Cake w/raspberries.  Both were tasty.

I also had a glass of rose, which was crisp and delicious.

All in all, a fun vibrant restaurant with great service.  I will definitely be returning.
author: Sarah K.

description:
YESSS!!! Finally a pizza in San Francisco that has awesome crust and isn't a dough-laden, West Coast, Round Table-esque monstrosity. Yep. I said it - I'm from the East Coast, so we have high standards for our pies.

So we randomly stumbled into this place with a friend and had the. best. pizza. evah. here. I got the Heirloom Tomato w/smoked bacon and arugula, but I also got to taste my table mates' broccoli rabe and pancetta as well as a pesto/veggie creation that was out of this world. There was enough to take home and it reheated beautifully the next day.

I would most definitely come back here either to eat or to do take out. Service was friendly and attentive, but the cons were the atmosphere - small, crowded, and loud. It just wasn't one of those places where you sink into the booth and feel like you're transported. Also, I thought the wine selection was overpriced for the quality. At $11 a glass, I expect something a bit more decent.

But I'll be back to try one of the other pizzas...this time with an egg on it!
author: Britt M.

description:
This place has the best pizza in SF.  It reminds me of Pizzeria Mozza in LA.  Some of the pizzas are better then others though.  Like the Black Mission Figs w/ caramelized onions, basil, Val d'Aosta fontina & speck is AMAZING.  The Zucca- shaved butternut squash, ricotta, ricotta salata & sage is just ok.  Even you don't like eggplant, you should definitely get the Eggplant Caponata.  

They don't take reservations and there's often a long wait.  They'll take your number and call you if you want to wander around nearby.  For people who live in the neighordhood, you can call ahead to put your number in.
author: barbara b.

description: The margarita pizza here is amazing. The outdoor back patio is great for a group dinner.
author: Marc B.

description:
Ragazza is a new SF favorite hidden beneath the relentless neon lights of the Metro Hotel. Don't let the carnie decor fool you-- this is a homegrown SF resto with local ingredients, familiar food with a twist, and a wine list of California reds that you'd expect from any SF classic. Waste no time when you arrive; order a carafe of the rose before taking a peak at the daily menu. Then decide what on the list tickles your fancy. We went with the following:

Prosciutto di Parma - Delicate, but flavorful strips of prosciutto served with a hunk of housemade mozzarella. The dish is quite common but the flavors were extraordinary. Went down nicely with the Rose.

Brussell Sprouts with Lardo - I am a huge Brussell Sprouts fan. I typically prefer them roasted to a crisp and covered in salt, but Ragazza's dish is of the savory variety. Their sprouts, served with premium backfat, were delicious. Highly recommended. 

Rapini & Escarole with Sweet Italian Sausage - This is my kind of pizza. The greens give the pizza healthful texture and weight. The sweet sausage brings back traditional pizza flavors without making the pizza too hearty/filling.

This new pizza joint really hits the spot. Its lively atmosphere, affordable menu, and eclectic wait staff make it a neighborhood go-to in our book. 5 stars

-A&L
author: AdamLowell C.

description:
Ive started 2011 out in a fantastic way. 

Adding Regazza to my new "FAVE" list.

This pace s great for a smaller party - 4 or less based on the space/table layout. 

We waited 30 min for a table w/o a rezzie so we jumped over to the new wine bar 'Vinyl' (Corner of Oak/Divis) to wait it out - great place to wait it you have to.
http://www.thrillist.com/bars/lower-haight/vinyl_happy-hour_wine_wine-bars#axzz1By7N34eT

OR you always have the Page Bar across the street as well.

The use of a mild chili in their tomato sauce give this pizza an amazing kick with out over powering. The option to order a large salad bowl for 4 (gimmicky maybe but I love it) was lovely. The beet salad is not to be missed.

Washing it down with a mildly priced decanter and you have yourself a golden night pf pizza enjoyment.

Quietly holding my breath for the beautiful and lush back patio to open for brunches in spring when its warmer!

Mangiare bene!
author: Brooke H.

description:
Well the lower Haight certainly has changed a bit in the last 5 years. We just went out to Ragazza, a new pizzeria between Oak and Page on Divis. -- it was a delight. Located where the old Metro Hotel french bistro used to be, Ragazza offers a good size menu complete with wonderful appetizers, salads, as well as some great "pies". 

The pizzas are thin crust with generous topping that can please both the vegetarian and the bacon-a-vor alike.

Ragazza is on par with the other high end pizza destinations in the city. Perhaps it's just nostalgia for the lower Haight, but Ragazza seems to have a genuine homey feel. Although it does not have the fine finish of Delfina or Flour+Water, the food is just as good.
author: Philip C.

description: When we lived a block away we went here a dozen or so times. Half the time I could have given 3 stars and the other half, 5. Food is solid, wine is good value. Pizza is good and worth an order.
author: Eric W.

description: I went here for the first time last Friday night. Arriving at 7, the wait was about 30 minutes. Once seated, the food was delicious and the service good. We had the heirloom tomato pizza and mussels, which were both excellent. 2 people can easily share a pizza for a complete meal. The beers are mostly foreign and tasty. I live the old Italian photographs on the wall as well. A good night out!
author: Vanessa B.

description:
Pizza is the boyfriend's all-time most favorite food in the entire world, so when my coworker mentioned Ragazza... we decided to drop by for dinner the very same day.  I'm so happy to report that it was the best foodie discovery I've had in a while.  

Ordered:

- Antipasto Plate with Umbrian lentils, olives, mortadella, speck, and salume nostrano - $14
- Farro Salad with cherry tomatoes, Frog Hollow peaches, sweet white corn & ricotta salata - $9
- Potato with applewood smoked bacon, red onion, rosemary & goat cheese - $14
- Add Rancho Elias Egg to pizza pie - $2
- Add Sausage to pizza pie - $3
- Tiramisu - $8

The restaurant was extremely busy, but the staff was very attentive.  We sat at the bar and we were able to take a look at all the food coming in and out of the kitchen (all of which looked SO good!)  The food may take a bit to come out, but it is well worth the wait!  I can't get over the combination of ingredients on our pizza.  I love potato on my pizza (it's a popular trend in Japan) but Ragazza slices the potato very thin so it blends nicely with the rest of the toppings.  If you've never tried egg [fried/not hard-boiled ;)] with your pizza, you should definitely give it a go. It was my first time and I would do it over again in a heartbeat. Our other dishes were just as yummy and complemented the main dish well.

There are so many places in the city that I'm dying to try, but I will make the effort to stop by once in awhile to get my Ragazza fix! 

MLOU'S TIPS
------------------

1) GET THE EGG ON YOUR PIZZA!

2) Take a peek at the garden in the back of the restaurant-- very pretty!
author: Marilou A.

description:
Ragazza is the BEST!

I don't understand how anyone could give it anything less than 5 stars. It is amazing, and worth the long wait (at least an hour on Friday/Saturday night) every single time!

The amatriciana and the bianco are my favorites. I also love that they change their menu based on what's fresh in their kitchen.

I love, love, love this place!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Food is great!  Pizzas are beyond.... Wait was minimal.  Fun neighborhood.  Easy parking. Great prices.
author: Krissa B.

description:
I have probably been to this restaurant more than 15 times.  Think its an excellent pizza - maybe one of the best in town.  Excellent crust, toppings, all good.  Nevertheless, service always seems a bit disheveled, some employees can seem a bit overwhelmed, and can sometimes be a bit cold and drafty inside.  I like the place, its convenient and good pizza.  But finally put my finger on why I never get that excited to go there.

12/31/13
This is a follow up review.  Went again the other night and had the best experience I've had at Ragazza.  Service was great, meaning the waiter/server was pleasant and helpful without seeming overwhelmed.   The woman who seated is was also perfectly freindly without overwhelmed which has often been the case in the past.  And lastly, the pizza was perfect as has always been the case.  

I'm not asking for much in terms of service when going to a restaurant such as Ragazza, just not interested in being subjected to the problems of an unhappy staff member who cannot handle the pressure of working in a restaurant.  Last experience was great - thank you.
author: Reza M.

description:
The thin pizza was delicious.
The apps and salads were great.
The service was slow but nice (very busy).

I enjoyed our meal despite being seated near a group of boisterous toddlers, which says something about the food!
author: danny b.

description:
Came in last night as a friend of a friend works as a chef and we wanted to test his skills.

He passed! 

The group was a large fan of the egg on the pizza. Amatriciana was a clear winner but I thought the Nettle pizza was really fun too- unexpected bits of flaky bits of crunch. OOOooh! Pizza 3 was the pesto and it was right up there with the rest- yum!

Between the two salads recommended to us the beet/arugula one was the unanimous winner. I was searching for the other one on the online menu to reference now but can't figure out which one it was (furthering my opinion that it was, sorry to say, unmemorable). Was it the butter lettuce one? Quite possibly. Whichever salad it is- it needs some serious pizaz! Let me in the kitchen- I could doctor it up...

I should mention that as we were sitting down to dine, a total stranger who was walking out was raving about the olive oil cake! But sadly, we were too full to try that  :(  next time...

Things to know before you go- 

you will likely wait- a long time (it's small). Cute ambiance- the brick wall is rad!

For 6 people- 3 pizzas and 2 salads was the perfect amount.

We didn't booze (though we did as we waited) and when the bill arrived I was pleasantly surprised.

Congrats on your opening- great digs, you'll do great!
author: Ash E.

description:
My friends and I love to try new restaurants, especially when they open in our neighborhood. We were so excited to try Ragazza because we have been wanting a good thin crust pizza place in the neighborhood for a long time. We love food!! We love food so much that when we travel together all we do is eat.  For us to get the true experience of a restaurant, we usually share everything. Four of us shared the fallowing.. 

1. Little Gem Lettuces, green goddess dressing, farro & local apples $18
We had the large salad and we thought it was delicious but we also felt like it was a bit expensive. We never complain about prices but we also want to get our money's worth.  

2. Pork Belly over a fresh corn salad. 
We really loved the flavors of this dish but what we got was not pork belly. It was actually a piece of meat and this was not what we were expecting. It was a bit dry too. 

3. Braised Short Rib Sugo w/ strozzapreti & Parmigiano Reggiano $14
This was delicious! In fact we ended up ordering another one. We would return just for this dish. 

4. Pork Osso Bucco w/ preserved Meyer lemon & Cavolo Nero soft polenta $21
I think we all agreed that this dish was good but not great. It lacked a depth of flavor that I normally get from Osso Bucco when I make it or have had it at other restaurants. With a few tweaks this can become a great dish. 

5. Amatriciana pizza w/ tomato, pancetta, chilies, Pecorino, oregano 
& an egg $16
We loved this pizza! It was so flavorful that we wished we had ordered 
more pizzas instead of some of the dished we had.

6. Ricotta Cheesecake with Figs. 
I wouldn't say its the best cheesecake we've ever had but it was a nice end to our meal. The cake was light and airy but a bit grainy. I think we just prefer the texture of a mascarpone cheesecake over one that is made with ricotta. 

7. It was a warm evening so the server suggested a rosé wine that went great with our meal. We had 2 bottles.... :-)

There was some misses but there was also some great dishes. We would return just for the pasta dish and to try more of the pizzas. The combinations sound delicious and hopefully they are as good as the one we ordered. We love Delfina Pizzeria and Flour+Water but we also loved Ragazza's pizza. I love each restaurant for a different reason. I think we all agreed that we enjoyed the bold flavor of Ragazza's pizza.
author: Rolo A.

description:
Finally a good thin crust in SF!  I tried the pork belly pizza and the wild nettles pizza.  Both were fun, delicious, and so fresh that they tasted like the vegetables were grown in the backyard.  The salads are a great compliment to the rest of the meal as they were light and flavorful.  Our server was fantastic!  She recommended all of the food off of my preferences and she was dead-on with what I wanted (I think her name is Leah?  Cool tattoos).  Plus I never felt neglected or stalked, that makes me CRANKY.  
The place is very busy so expect a wait, but the hostess is super friendly and nice enough to give you a call on your cellphone when your table is ready.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
My dinner date and I were totally happy with our experience at Ragazza.  We shared the following:

- Arugula salad
- Wild Nettle pizza
- Baked rigatoni pasta with short rib meat

The service was good and the food was also quite good.  We ordered a side of marinara sauce with the nettle pizza because it was a bit dry.  But all in all everything was tasty and the atmosphere was lively.

There is really not much more to say - it was a nice meal and in a good location too.
author: Kelly A.

description:
my sister and i just went tonight for my 29th birthday dinner. after paying the bill, we talked about how crazy pricey it was...and then did our own math to figured out how it was possible. turns out they overcharged us by $23! i just called to ask about it and the girl who answered my call tracked down my bill and explained that we were charged for a dessert we didn't order. no apology or offer to fix the bill, just gave me the information like that was just supposed to put my mind at ease and i would feel happy with at least having the knowledge of why i was overcharged. (but also...in what world does a dessert cost $23?! i have a feeling like thats not the whole story...) when pressed further, with a heaving sigh, she conceded to take down my name and told me to figure it out with them tomorrow. 

customer service and good business practices at its finest.... 

thanks for ruining my birthday. and ripping me off.
author: Cara T.

description:
OK. Category: victim of its own hype.

This is the kind of spot that I want desperately to love - and, in concept, I do. Small, cosy, funky neighborhood Italian joint within walking distance from my house and with nettles on the menu. Enticing, no?

But, after wondering for months what the perpetual line out the door must mean, I finally squeezed myself in for dinner. 

And it was good. No, correction: the salad was fantastic. Butter lettuce thing with green goddess dressing. Simple, divine. And my man got some huge pork dish which was tasty enough. My pizza had the novelty of lemon rind in it - a nice taste for sure, but totally outweighed by the saltiness of the pie as a whole. So incredibly salty! And I like salt. I really like salt. But this was much, even for me.

Took half the pie home, thinking maybe it would taste different in the morning. But it didn't.

Not sure I'll go back, which is a shame. 

The next time I want a reliably good and not-too-salty pizza, I'll hit Delfina or Gather.
author: kt s.

description: Great gourmet pizza, salad, and wine! Small Lacinato Kale salad is more then enough for 2; Zucca pizza is amazing (butternut squash!).
author: Ali A.

description:
This is a great pizza place. Roommate came here on a Friday night around 730 and it was amazingly only an hr wait. We put down our number and went over to The Page to grab a drink while we waited. I must say, I give props to the staff for dealing with some very push and pompous customers. There was clearly a queue where everyone had to wait. There were a number of women who thought they were better than others and felt they should not have to wait. Some tried to force themselves to the bar area (which is NOT first come first serve) and the hostess had to escort them out. They had the audacity to say "I don't get why that's a problem if we sat at the bar?" Even though the hostess said to them that the seats are also for those in the waitlist. They left storming out and pissed. Good riddance.

After we were seated, we were greeted with menus and water. I love that restaurants now give bottles of water to tables so that they're not always refilling cups. Just makes it easier for them and easier for us too so that we don't have to keep flagging someone down. My roommate and I got the tossed salad (lettuce, goat cheese, beets, and pine nuts) and Amatriciana with an extra egg. The salad was really good. I'm usually not a fan of goat cheese but I loved it this time. When ordering the amatriciana, get extra eggs! If you think the egg is amazing idea then please get at least two. The egg makes it so much more creamy and a bit more protein as well. Before biting into it, spread the yoke across the pizza so that every piece gets a bit of it. The pizza as really good and the crust was nice. Towards the edges it was a bit thick but that's ok since I could easily use that to mop up whatever yolk was on my plate.

The only thing I wasn't a fan of that after we ate our salad, we didn't get new plates to eat our pizza. I might be a tad bit anal about this part but I just don't like mixing flavors and the pizza did not go with the dressing of the salad. Overall, this is a great establishment. Great staff with great food.
author: edward k.

description: great place to eat and catch up with my friend. we shared the Lacinato Kale salad and Bianca pie with egg on top (of course!) and both were flavorful. i'm actually not a kale person (gasp) but the salad was delish! loved the ambiance, service was great. we were lucky to be seated quickly at 7 pm and stayed til closing, chatting and eating without being rushed.
author: Grace H.

description:
Since I live close to Ragazza's sister restaurant, Gialina in Glen Park, I've been there several times and had high hopes for this new venture in Lower Haight.  "Hopes", not "expectations", because my last visit to Gialina was disappointing; but that's another review.

This is a brilliant location IMHO.  I predict success -- good for the owners, good for the neighborhood.

For antipasti we ordered the oven roasted sardines and the mozzarella/prosciutto/tomato-corn salad.  Both were perfectly executed and beautifully presented.

We ordered a red wine from the upper half of the price range (Avignonesi, Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Toscana 2007 ....$49), because my handy Droid cheat sheet told me 2007 was an outstanding year in region, and I was with one of my more free-spending friends.  Bullseye!  I'd go lower end if I was ordering pizza and salad, but we had the braised short rib pasta, and this was a lovely match.

Our meal was rounded out by a vegetable dish -- braised chard with garlic and bacon.  Also perfect. 

The only reason I haven't given five stars is that one of the servers was simply unprofessional.  We interacted with four staffers in total, and three made good impressions.  But one of them brought out one of our dishes and, seeing that some other plates would have to be moved before she could set it down, held it over our table without saying a word.  Of course we cleared space for her, but she should have either a) cleared the space herself (best option) or b) asked us to make room. She looked like a sourpuss, too -- maybe a bad night for her, or maybe she's got one of those personalities unsuited to a service occupation.

Overall, an excellent dinner.
author: Francisco G.

description:
Had to wait as we were with a large group, but the hostess was on top of it and kept checking in with us which was nice.  

The food was really really good - interesting pizzas with fresh ingredients cooked well.  Our waitress was awesome, too!  

I'd highly recommend and will definitely be going back.
author: Tommy L.

description: This place is great- The food is amazing (roasted chicken, all of the pizzas), and the ambiance is lovely. The only reason I am not giving 5 stars is because the hostess at the time was kind of rude and vague with us. Their is one blonde waitress that we always get that is AMAZING. She is one of the reasons why we come back to be honest, other than the yummy food.
author: Sheryl P.

description:
The pizza here is lousy.  They don't use whole milk mozzarella or even clean their basil leaves.  My husband and I ordered the Margherita pizza and it tasted just terrible.  The cheese tasted processed and the whole pizza had a terrible waxy aftertaste - as if the basil leaves were not washed properly.  It took hours to get the terrible taste out of my mouth.  I'm not joking - it's that bad.

To add insult to injury, the staff is impolite.  Both Little Star Pizza and Patxi's Pizza are far superior and close-by.  Or if it's not far from you - the best pizza in the city is still Tony's Napoletana on Stockton in LIttle Italy.  It's simply mouth watering and amazing!!
author: Erika K.

description:
We had dinner here when we were we walking around the area. Little did I know that I'd stumble upon this place. The pork belly was amazing. I highly recommend it and would instantly go back.

All the tables around us were packed with delicious smelling food from other happy customers, so definitely try the rest of their menu too.
author: C S.

description: This review is for TAKE OUT ONLY. You can call in a take out order and specify a pick up time. Well, that's what I did and showed up 5 minutes before my specified time. Was happy to wait but I saw a pizza box with my name on it sitting on the "ready" shelf. I nicely asked the hostess about said box and she didn't even glance over and told me that it wasn't ready and to move out of the way and wait against the wall. Totally rude and dismissive. About 2 minutes later another waiter asked us what order we were waiting for and immediately found our box, which we took home to find totally cold pizza (and you know how much cold pizza sucks). Anyhow, terrible experience and I second all of the reviews about the uber-bitchy hostess.
author: Saleema F.

description:
Meh. The pizza is thin crust, which can be great. It's crispy, it's light, it's good. The outer edge gets air bubbles and puffs out. It's cool. I had a moto and a margherita. 

But on both pies, the crust is so thin around the edges that the top of the bubbles burn. About 25% of the crust around the pizza was burned (burnt?). I like crust. I'm here to eat the whole pizza. 

The margherita had so little cheese that 2 of the pieces (out of 8) had no cheese at all. Zero. I looked. They clearly don't shred the mozzarella and spread it around. They put down a few mozzarella balls and they spread out as they melt but clearly not enough to cover all the pieces.  Seriously guys, take the "sophistication" down a notch and just grate the cheese. I'm from Wisconsin.  I order pizza so that I can eat cheese.

So one pie with too little cheese. Two pies where I couldn't eat a big percentage of the crust. If you are going to go all foofy and make pies with butternut squash and  portobello mushroom and calabrian chilies, at least get the basics right. Don't burn it. Put cheese on every piece.
author: Gene M.

description:
Loved this place - wow! 

I think its really unfair to give a restaurant a bad review based on wait time - its popular, and if you dont want to wait...go somewhere else! there are 30 restaraunts on the divis corridor!

Anyway, Ragazza is a lovely little place with simply incredible pizza. Went here on a monday night so we only had to wait 10 minutes. We ordered one with an egg, pancetta and wild mushrooms, as well as another delicious, perfectly crafted pie - the crust was the best crust i've had on an italian style pizza. 

The wine was equally good - we opted for a bottle of something delicicious, light bodied and very italian without being overly acidic or astringent - a bargain at $25/bottle. 

The service was equally wonderful, our waitress was super charming, attentive, funny and cool. 

All told the four of us split two pizzas and a bottle of wine and had a $60 tab. 

Delicious, I will return very soon! Thanks Ragazza!
author: Ben B.

description: I came here famished and we were happy to have a table upon entering on a Tuesday evening. Really great value for the pizza. We got amatriciana pizza (I was also super curious about the wild nettles, maybe next time!) I particularly like the crunchy texture of the dough. We also got some focaccia bread to start.
author: Shang S.

description: Unbelievable contemporary Italian with a powerful pizza menu. Truly a standout restaurant and a great neighborhood go to.
author: WeAreAllLamp L.

description:
definitely in the top 5 list of place i'm going to miss when i move to ny...

i love everything about this place: it's cozy, the food is delicious and the service is great - i especially love alexis, keely (spl?) and the waiter otherwise known as "poor man's paul rudd"!!

the menu is always updated based on what's in-season, but you can't go wrong with a fresh salad, pasta and margherita pizza.
author: Kristen A.

description:
First time here, already loving the atmosphere :) 

I came with my bf because the wait for NOPA (down the street) was insane. 

It was a nice surprise. The pizza was okay. My favorite was the ravioli. The brown sugar that they use to make it compliments everything in the dish. At first, I was little weary. However, after reading it's reviews (an article is posted about it next to the restroom) I just had to try it. 

I also like the fact that they have a "garden" where you can dine as well. Great ambiance. 

They also have a great selection of wine. The staff was extremely friendly as well. 

Must tries: 
Ravioli + wine (any type)
author: Jas H.

description:
Came here on a Monday night and waited over an hour for a table. Our group of four got squished into a small corner table (that could only fit one pizza at a time) and the wait for our food once we ordered was kind of lengthy. Other than that, customer service and food was great!
