My favorite was the Amatriciana pizza. It was thin-crust heaven! The Potato with applewood smoked bacon and Moto pizzas were also yummy. I have heard the Wild Nettles pizza is also very popular. For dessert, their nutella pizza with mascarpone & amaretti was interesting and delicious!
author: Jen S.

description:
Excellent food. Been here 3 times and ordered the Amatriciana pizza ($16) every time. Pancetta, chilies, pecorino, egg is my type of flavor profile: bold. Wonderful, crisp dough. Wasn't sure what to do with the egg until we finally asked this last time... you dip! They slice it so dipping works really well. One of my friends thought we should've splurged on an extra egg ($2) since we were short on runny yellow yolk towards the end.

Nice Italian wine menu with different sizing options. We split a carafe of Nero d'Avola between 3 ($24 for 500 ml). Well-paired with the food.

Service was very helpful & friendly.

Other stuff I've gotten:
wild arugula salad with beets -- nice balance to the heavy dishes. Waitress convinced our party of 4 to get large ($18) instead of small ($9), and she was right.

wild nettle pizza -- unusual & yummy

fig salad -- seasonal salad from a few months. Again, good balance for the meal.

rigatoni with butternut squash ($12) -- creamy, baked pasta. A little on the sweet side for me, but the table loved it. Generous portion, good for sharing.

brussels sprouts with "spreadable salume" - decent braised version, but I prefer them roasted & crispy.

ricotta cheesecake ($7) -- solid
bi-rite ice cream -- can't go wrong
author: Jessica J.

description:
I just love what is going on, on Divis lately. I called an order into Ragazza before I left work one Wednesday night and when I arrived to pick it up the dark interior was buzzing, absolutely full up of happy couples and groups eating some seriously fancy pizza. The hipster girls working the bar and the tables all looked like lovely Italian sisters (and were all very friendly to boot), and the tiny bar had some solo diners enjoying their own pizza and a glass of red. 

The pizzas were excellently cooked and absolutely delicious with creative combinations of toppings. The three-cheese was my favorite, it was creamy and tangy, and the sweet sausage was satisfying. I want to try the nettles with an egg next time, and I'll eat in. 

The proscuitto and olive appetizer was disappointing however, the entire dish was drenched in oil. Maybe it's best to stick with the pizzas here. Remember that it ain't cheap... Stelladoro this is not. If Little Star is a good second-date spot, this would make a good fourth-date. Assuming you really love pizza (and I assume you do).
author: Lisa P.

description: Oh Ragazza, you were SUPPOSED to rock my casbah, but instead, I think I would have been better off getting lost in the supermarket.  Though my arancini had the spicy kick I crave, its somewhat gooey insides were a tad dry for me.  Add this to the fact that my pizza was on the dark end of crispy, and it's clear that an "egg-on-top" can't quite make this place into a platinum hit.
author: Michael D.

description: I just had takeout from this place. Really good food (some exotic cauliflower breaded dish, a fancy pizza, and a lima bean w/ greens salad. bottom line : food is excellent, and the server was really nice
author: k j.

description: Best meal I had this weekend. From the appetizers to the pasta to the pizza! Delicious and fresh and innovative. Friendly service.
author: Annie R.

description:
Well worth the extra work to get a table here at the last minute on a Saturday night.  The hostess was incredibly accomodating with our group, not just pleasant but genuinely nice. 

Both the appetizers we tried (lamb meatballs, hand pulled mozzarella salad) were delicious, and the tender fococcia was a steal at $1.  We shared three of the pizzas: The Moto was spicier than expected and while good, paled in comparison to the other two pizzas we ordered.  The Bianca was fantastic, I loved the addition of preserved lemon and the freshness of the arugula.  Our last selection was the Hen of the Woods mushroom pizza, which came loaded with fontina.    Heavier than the Bianca, it was earthy and cheesy and wonderful.

We tried two pastas as well, one with lamb sugo and another with butternut squash.  The former was good, but a little too traditional for me to get excited about.  However, I kept going back to the butternnut squash for the crispy sage and amaretti cookies.

Together with two bottles of wine, our party of six ended up paying about $60 a person.  A little pricey, but well worth it for an evening of exceptional food and service.
author: Shayna F.

description:
Pizza: 5-star (Love it, not large enough for 2)
Price: 4-star (pizza is $10 or more)
Service: 4-star
Atmosphere: 4-star
Temperature: 4-star
Brightness: 3-star
Table: 3-star (tables are not large enough for 2 plates)
Cleanness: 4-star
Bathroom: (don't know)
author: Yosuke K.

description: Love gialina's in glen park, and ragazza is just as great if not better. I've never been disappointed with any aspect of the food or service here! Sure, sometimes a new hostess is a little frazzled, but the rest of the operation seems run like a well constructed ship. We tend to always get the rotating seasonal pizza and a salad or app, which is a perfect dinner for two. Also, the back patio is great for a glass of wine before dinner, though we always seem to get a table with relatively minimal wait time unless we go on a weekend at crunch time (which we rarely do).
author: Todd H.

description:
My friend and I came here since the pop shop restaurant around the corner was too packed. We needed somewhere to eat fast before our show at the independent. Ragazza it was. We weren't in the mood for pizza so we had the salad and a rigatoni dish. I would have skipped the arugula salad (we got a large and it was ginormous), and gone straight to the cheesy baked pasta dish.

We had a carafe of wine and it was tasty.

All in all, good experience here!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Good crust, but the cheese and basil were a bit thin on my GF's Margherita (just a spot on each slice, instead of an even coverage pattern). 
I had the pork belly as I'm lactarded. Texture and cooking were excellent, but it seemed to be missing a sauce and flavor. I could barely taste anything, and the figs and balsamic didn't really bring anything to the table. 
They should just stick to pizza and focus on that. It's a bit spendy for what they give you too.
author: Casey J.

description: Loved this place! Hubby and I had the olives and focaccia bread to start. Delish! We shared a large arugula salad with goat cheese, fennel, roasted pistachios and pears- best salad everrrrrrr! Went on to share a pasta dish, wish I could remember what it was called, but it was melt in your mouth yumminess. Finished with the sausage, basil and tomato pizza. All in all i loved it here and will definetly return next time I'm in San Fran. Great service, great food!
author: Jenn W.

description: One of the best spots in the neighborhood (or the best). Probably as good as NOPA on any given night. The pastas are phenomenal - hard to go wrong with anything here.
author: Kelly K.

description:
I finally made it to Ragazza last night -- I'd been hearing about this new addition to the neighborhood & I was very curious. The restaurant occupies the spot that previously housed "Metro Kathmandu" (and a number of other failed restaurants) -- hopefully, Ragazza will have better fortune.

The place is small, and they dont take reservations, so the only option is to add your name to their waitlist & then go for a drink in the fairly dive-y "Page" bar across the street. For us, on a Saturday night, the wait was about an hour - then, I got a friendly call on my cell phone to tell me the table was ready.

The place was bustling on a Saturday evening, but in a casual, fairly laid-back way. It seems a lot like the sister restaurant, Gialina, in Glen Park -- similar space, similar artwork on the wall, and a similar menu (though seeming not as centered on pizza.)

We started with an Arugula Salad (excellent - zesty, with tangerines and goat cheese) and a carafe of Chianti. (I love the carafe notion -- not too much, not too little -- and something you see too rarely). We followed with a couple of entrees -- bigger than I expected -- the Amatriciana pizza (with a signature friend egg in the middle - for "dipping", our waitress helpfully explained) -- and the Roast Chicken ("diavola-style" -- meaning, we discovered, very hot & spicy on the outside.) The pizza was excellent, another staple from Gialina's - very thin crust, but big and satisfying. And the chicken was mouthwatering - juicy and tasty, complemented with polenta and baby broccolis -- definitely one to return for.

All-in-all, a great meal in a friendly, casual environment -- a good alternative to the more high-end, nearby Nopa -- I'll be back...!
author: donal c.

description:
First Impression. Will definitely come back.
Nettle pizza, yum! hit with enough bitter, specially for cool eves.
author: One P.

description:
This is the kind of place I'd want to stumble across if I were visiting some foreign city. It feels like a local gem, with great atmosphere and a casual but warm-seeming crowd. The service is attentive and very personable.

That said, those qualities are enough for me to overlook some not-as-stellar things. I didn't like the flavor combination of the fried padron peppers and goat cheese. The goat cheese overpowered the peppers, which were slick with oil but yet not cooked through enough. There weren't any real overarching element to bring the two ingredients together either, like a sauce or herb. 

I also tried the chanterelle pizza, and though the crust was one of the more amazing ones I've had in SF (perfect chew, yum yum), the chanterelles (and whatever other ingredients were on that pizza) were lost among a mass of very oily onions. 

The wine is very reasonably priced here....you can get bottles for $30.

So if Ragazza, you can dial back the oil, and let your super fresh ingredients shine through more on their own, this would definitely be five stars in my book.
author: Carolyn F.

description: Great food, friendly staff and prompt service.  Expect to wait during peak dinner hours but it's worth the wait and they text you when your table is ready, so you can go grab a drink at one of the nearby bars for a pre-pizza bevy.  The Moto pizza was delish and the beet salad was fresh and tasty.  Will definitely be going back for more!
author: Keri W.

description: I'm not much of a pizza lover but my friend is a fanatic and she was in heaven!  it's noisy and crowded but has sensational pizza so it's well worth it.  We had one of their signature pizzas, the Amatriciana, that included an egg in the middle.  YUMMO!!  We shared two desserts, the panna cotta, which was ok but not fabulous and the olive oil cake which was divine!  I read about problems with the hostess and was happy to see a new hostess who was in control and still delightful.  Good service - good food.  Terrific!
author: Mary-Ellen R.

description:
More pizza for the neighborhood, yay. We had a great experience  - friendly service, nicely priced wine options, delicious, thin crust pizza (we had the heavenly mushroom one) and a warm vibe.

Can't wait to check out the patio in the back.

Only drawback is they don't take reservations - we waited for an hour. The good news is they take your cell phone number and you can enjoy cocktails at the Page across the street while you wait.
author: Gretchen S.

description: Long wait, but well worth it! I love their pizzas w/ capers and basil. Their crust is thin, flavorful and perfectly crisp.
author: J D.

description:
3.5 stars.  Good pies, but not mindblowing.  To avoid a wait and negate massive calories, we employed the same strategy we previously deployed for Gialina: pick a random Tuesday, eat nothing all day, work out, ignore hunger pangs, head to Ragazza at 9:40pm and channel last bit of remaining energy to supress irritability from low blood sugar.  Ok, so we had to embrace a couple eating disorders for *one day* but hey, we sat down immediately and justified our caloric binge.  (Note: the place was packed at 9:40pm).

Ambiance is ok, mostly 2 tops, dark tables. Not too loud, dim lighting.

We shared:
-Baked *SQUASH* appetizer. Oh, the first bite of food all day! This was delicious, a bit sweet, baked, served with some figs, ricotta, and sprinkled with some nuts which gave it a great crunch.  Great contrast of textures.
-*MUSHROOM PIE* (no tomato sauce). Favorite item I ate here. Savory, earthy.  Highly recommend if you like mushrooms.
-*AMATRACIANA* w/ tomato, pancetta, chilies + an egg.  One word: salty!  I'm pretty sure this pie caused me to bloat up to Violet proportions in charlie and the chocolate factory. Each bite seemed increasingly salty yet addictive. Friend agreed - bloatworthy.  Good thing the mushroom pizza was "normal" salty to balance things out.

Crust: Just ok.  It was kinda too much, too thick, too poofy for the pizza. Tasted a bit bland. (Maybe the salt killed my taste buds).

Dessert: *OLIVE OIL CAKE* w/creme fraiche.  Mild, neutral flavor.  Creme fraiche was almost frozen, not sure if intended or not.  Came sprinkled with about 7 raspberries, which were teeny tiny, seemed out of season.  I still haven't formed my final opinion on this mild, yet dense dessert.

Overall, pretty good pies, reasonably priced, but I'd probably only go back if there were no wait.
author: Caroline I.

description:
The wine was good - great suggestion from the server. 

The roast beet salad was good but didn't really see much other than the arugula and the beets. 

I had the pork osso buco - BAD idea - it was tough and flavorless. 

Big G had the meatball pizza, which WAS good.  I don't see if on the menu any more, so probably why. 

I'd try it again, but hate waiting for pizza. I mean, it's PIZZA. The ambience is okay. Bit crowded, but hey, whatevs. Also, sitting by the door is a bad idea as it's COLD. They should put one of those curtain-thingies around the front door (like at Little Star), and there's no waiting area so it's outside (so hope it's not raining).
author: Mi M.

description: One of the best pie's in the city  4 sure get there fast before the hierloom pizza is all gone. Pizza Monster Approved.
author: Chris D.

description: Hot olives interesting green were good black were salty to the point of inedible. Lamb meatballs- the cinnamon did not go with Italian tomato sauce n cheese. Pizza was cracker thin with tasteless Rapini (leaves only) with a fair sausage. Extremely disappointing. It's shameful this place has good reviews for pizza. Service started out promising then fizzled to down right lazy and novice.
author: Gantsa Maven Z.

description: I have eaten there several times. The food has always been great. Some of the best pizza in town. Sides also delicious. Service fine. One star off for a surprisingly uninspiring beer selection.
author: Tucky D.

description:
Completely Overrated!!!!!

Pizza is OK, nothing phenominal.  Salads were quite good.  Wine selection was quite poor.  This place is not bad, but certainly not 4 stars.  Given the $$$, I would expect more in San Francisco.  Bummer because its right in my neighborhood
author: Crater H.

description: WOW - what a surprise hit here - nestled in a little nook that you might walk by and never even notice...except for the smell of OUTSTANDING, thin crust ala Neapolitan style pie - tried two kinds; one with home made (of course) sausage and another topped with a variety of mushrooms - both equally delectable - a surprise starter was a split fig filled with warm Chorizo, not a combo I'd think of but worked!!! - service was great too!! - only reason not five stars was a bit cramped, but that is SF for ya!!
author: Richard D.

description:
Not a single complaint about the food!!  It was absolutely fantastic!!  I would recommend it to anyone.  The staff was all great.  We went on a Sunday night and there was a bit of a wait, so the hostess recommended we head across the street and have a drink and she would call us as our table was ready.  So we did, as there wasn't much else to do around there at 8pm and it was just the perfect amoutn of time to have one drink.

There were four of us girls since the food all sounded good, we decided to order each course and share.  We had wine, appetizer, salad, pasta, pizza and dessert and we ate it ALL.  And they were health portions, so I can say that everyone was happily stuffed!

I will take my husband there for sure!  I even texted him a picture of our pizza because it looked so delicious and he was definitley jealous!
author: Kristen A.

description: Sharon, Alisha and the team at Ragazza went above and beyond to make sure we had a wonderful evening last night. It was our first night away from the baby and we couldn't have picked a better place to enjoy the evening.  Everything we ate was delicious- Wild Nettles ravioli antipasti, Kale salad, Margherita pizza and the Nutella pizza. Service was attentive and the wine recommendations were excellent.  We can't wait to go back to our neighborhood gem. Thank you!
author: Seeta N.

description: I love these thin crust pizzas.  The amatriciana is my favorite.  I would give them five stars except that I hate the noise.  Happily, they do take it, so you can enjoy your pizza in the peace and quiet of your home.
author: Gisela S.

description:
Great authentic thin crust pizza with a gourmet twist. Loved the "little gem &  Radicchio" salad - simple but amazing. Atmosphere and style is crisp and timeless. Service was right on.

Great addition to the hood, can't wait for the garden patio to open and brunch to be served.
author: Jeff T.

description: I'm not generally a pizza fan but this place has the thin crust pizza packed with flavor that I'm attracted to. They have many interesting combinations of toppings that I haven't seen elsewhere. If it's your first time, get the Wild Nettles pizza. The kale salad is a great starter. I just wish the wait wasn't so long but you can get a drink across the street while you wait.
author: Samantha S.

description: Amazing food and great service. One of our favorite places to eat in SF. Gets very busy so get there early.
author: Keith D.

description: Great neighborhood takeout place if you want better than your average pizza fare. Restaurant atmosphere isn't great for the prices though. Prefer the white pizzas - pancetta added to the Bianca is my favorite.
author: Sandra S.

description:
such a cute place. my date was telling me that all the pictures on the wall are of the owner's family. that little touch brings a nice cozy feel to the restaurant. came here on a friday night at 8ish. we were told that the wait was going to be 1hr and 15min! yikes. we put our name down and figured we'll just wait it out. we walked down the street to have a drink and an hour later we were seated at a nice little table for two.

we shared the rigatoni with butternut squash and the shiitake mushroom and smoked mozarella pizza. both dishes were great. the rigatoni had a great cheesy and buttery flavor to it and the squash was a nice addition to give it a seasonal feel. the pizza had a nice thin crust. the smoked flavor of the mozarella almost made the pizza taste like it had bacon on it. delicious. =) it was the perfect amount of food for two. just enough to feel full but not too full that we can't even walk out of the restuarant. we also ordered a carafe of white wine that was recommended by our waitress. unfortunately i don't remember the name of it. but it paired very nicely with our food. 

food was yummy. service was great. i would gladly wait an hour for a table. or i'll just show up after the dinner rush. =P
author: Linda N.

description: I looooove love love this pizza and the staff is great. They also own Gialina in Glen Park if you're ever over there.
author: Leigh D.

description: Ah, Ragazza you evil temptress.  I somehow cannot resist your offerings and every time I visit I find something more I love about you.  Nothing says a lovely meal with friends more than sharing.  Ragazza is about that.  Share your apps, your salads, your pizzas, your wine.  The food speaks for itself, and even though I am a devoted Gialina lover, Ragazza offers a larger menu and it has an amazing gazebo that is good for group dining.  I LOVE eating outside and their gazebo feels like you are transported to a secret garden somewhere in the Italian mountains.  Large group dining is a pain in the butt in SF (except if you want to spend insane $$$) and Ragazza has rescued me twice in this department (see their web-site for reservations for the gazebo).  DInner for our staff of 8 was seamless and lovely. We all had plenty of food (even enough to take home to hubby) and the price was crazy good.  So whether you are a party of one or of 20, this is one of my favorite places in the city to have a meal.
author: Monika S.

description: I really liked the pizza here!  My boyfriend got the pasta, even upon hearing that they were more well-known for the pizza, and after trying some of the various pizzas me and our friends chose, he confirmed that the pizza is a better choice.  The selection does not seem very high but each pizza is so flavorful and unique (like a fried egg on top!  Sounds strange, but it was delicious!).  I would love to go back.  They also offer large pizzas, so though it may look a bit overpriced, it is definitely worth it.
author: Rebecca D.

description: I've had a number of different pizzas at Ragazza on a number of occasions, but it is on this day, the 26th day of June, that I was truly dazzled. Bedazzled? No. But I was thrown from my pizza pretense into disbelief over the edible joy that is currently happening in my mouth. And for what? $13?! This is absolute. This is the truth. Do it. Live it. Experience this wonderment. This has ascended to the rank of the third best pizza I've ever had. And that my friends, is an impressive perch.
author: Brandon B.

description:
The pizzas were yummy and the entree and side I tried were YUMMY. The root vegetables and cheesy baked rigatoni with butternut squash were dreamy.

The service was friendly and accomodating. This is a pleasant new addition to the Divisadero corridor.

Among 4 people we had 3 pies, one entree and one side, plus a few beers.  This was enough food for us, plus plenty of doggy bags.  It came to $90 something.
author: Hella M.

description:
Went here about a month ago (please excuse the late review) for a birthday dinner. We were all a bit strapped for cash but were hell-bent on having a nice dinner out and Regazza delivered.

We started with the pork belly and fig antipasti and an arugula and fennel salad, which were both delicious. The pork was crispy and buttery, the figs were perfectly ripened, and the salad was well-balanced.

For our main course we shared the wild nettles with preserved lemon and the rapini with sweet Italian sausage pizzas. Upon their first arriving at the table I wan't sure there would be enough to go around for three people but after we polished off the pizzas we realized we were all stuffed. The crusts were light and crispy and accompanied the toppings very well.

I don't remember how much the bill came to (we had drinks too) but I do recall it was very reasonable for what we got. The service was fine, nothing to write home about. My biggest issue of the night: parking was a real horror show. Be sure to give yourself plenty of time if you need to get there for a reservation.
author: Sophia D.

description: Wow, everything was delicious. We weren't starving when we arrived so we only ordered a few items but dang they were tasty. We had the beet salad which was so fresh and a simple pizza with a farm egg. The sauce had the perfect amount of spice. We enjoyed the uniquely crisp white wine and the delish Affogato. The staff was friendly and knowledgeable. I'm definitely going back.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Great freakin pizza pies!
We shared a BLT pizza, which everyone at the table loved, including a couple friends who claimed they "didn't like tomatoes." I like tomatoes just fine and really loved the BLT pizza.
We also had the Amatriciana, which features an egg over easy in the middle, and it was hearty and delicious.
Alexis was our server and she was the bomb: good recommendations and a great attitude.
The wait was reasonable for primetime on a Thursday night. We'll be back!
author: Travis H.

description:
We ate here twice in one week and had, overall, amazing food. Great pizza crusts - thin and authentic. (My husband would have preferred more salt, but I love it.) Unusual combinations of toppings - nettles? I'll take it! (My husband prefers meat. Bah!) My son loved that he could add as much meat to his pizza as he wanted. The only downside was that his pizza was too heavy to pick up without a fork and knife! (Cry me a river!)
Overall, this place is the perfect restaurant to walk to in the neighborhood and feels so local and Italian authentic at the same time. Our order got mixed up on our second visit and we had to wait an eternity for our pizza, but the server was very gracious and offered us some free drinks. By the time we were devouring our meal, all was forgotten. I think they just need to work out some logistical kinks ...
All in all: eat at Ragazza! Thanks, ladies!
author: Margaret T.

description: Have been back once since this time. Food is still amazing. Was seated quickly upon our return. Notoriety? I think not. Just good luck. Still confused by the table hold policy but there you go.
author: Sarah A.

description:
so in advance - let me note I got food to go and so my review is truncated.  I ordered the sausage pie and braised greens with bacon and feta.  the very friendly person who took my phone order said 25 minutes, I arrived on the dot of 25 and my pizza had been sitting a while and was cold. 

on arrival at my pal's casa, we ate one slice at room temp and put the rest in the oven to re-heat.  the best thing about the pizza was the sausage on it - the crust is very thin and is certainly okay but nothing to get my heart pounding.  the cheese and tomato sauce seemed a bit better than avegrage.  but the sausage was sublime - tasting freshly made.  the braised greens were fabulous, and the pairing of the bacon with the feta made them decadent and sexy.  

picking up the pizza, I noted the restauarant is bustling.  the staff are friendly and the prices are reasonable.  I did not carefully examine the wine list.

I enjoyed Ragazza and will go back to eat in-house.  it seems to fill a niche between the fanciest pizza places in town and the more traditonal low-brow, cheesey, big-ass pizza.  it's a good additon to the neighborhood options and seems likely to stick and prosper.
author: Eric S.

description: Ragazza is our favorite neighborhood home away from home.  We've never been disappointed by anything on the menu and the service is always friendly.  The arugula salad with goat cheese and the Amatriciana pizza served with the most perfect egg right in the middle are both to die for.
author: Joseph Y.

description: Really delicious, thin crust pizza with superb tomato sauce.  Everything on the menu is reasonably priced including the wines.  We tried the Stracchiatella (creamy inside of burrata), Amatriciana pizza and the Margherita accompanied by a bottle of Sangiovese.  The entire meal was delicious.  Now I have to decide between Ragazza and Pizzeria Delfina.  Oh no!  Decision, decisions.
author: Christina S.

description: Wow! What a meal! Two pizzas -- wild nettles and margherita -- plus arugula/radicchio salad. So, so delicious. And no wait since we went early. Highly recommend this amazing spot.
author: Janet R.

description: Love this neighborhood place! Kale salad is out of this world. Heirloom pizza is fantastic. The back patio ambience is the best spot. Highly recommend.
author: Traci H.

description:
Lovely birthday celebration dinner last Wednesday!  Thank you!

Grace, our gracious server, was incredibly warm and courteous.  We vote Grace to be spokesperson for exceptional customer service!

Food - 
Linguine w/ Manila clams, spicy salume, garlic & wine - cooked to perfection.  Very nice.
County Line Chicories w/ green goddess dressing, shaved fennel , farro & Black Twig apples - wonderful combination.
Amatriciana w/ tomato, pancetta, chilies, pecorino, oregano & an egg pie - could not really enjoy the pie because all the food came out at once.  By the time we got to the pie it was cold and the crust hard - a shame.
Chocolate Truffle Cake w/ whipped cream - luscious and light.
author: Lauren L.

description:
It's nice to see that this place might stick at the Metro Hotel for a while. In the past 4 years, there has been a lot of turnover here.
Showed up on a Thursday night around 7 to a half an hour wait. No problem. They took down our phone number and we set off across the street to the Page for a beer. 
Down to business. . .
Food- split a delicious salad with fresh basil, tomatoes, goat cheese, and a grain I'm blanking out on the name. Then there was the pie. . .thinly sliced pear, gorgonzola cheese, pancetta and then topped with fresh arugula. Very good!
Like this place and looking forward to many returns.
author: Tita G.

description:
Really had a great experience here, in part because the ambiance is so lovely! And the pizza was tasty. Low on the cheese, which was tastier than I expected. We ordered the Moto with pepperoni instead of sausage. Not as good as Tony's but nothing is.

I'd love to go back!
author: Latte Queen W.

description: Sad,sad day. The first take out from Ragazza was very promising but the 2nd(today ) was a disaster. The 2 pies were overcooked to the point total incineration.  The toppings ,if there were any; were totally dried out.. By the way - ordered at 5.34 picked up at 5.54 as per instructions and on the table at 6.01.The kids said absolutely 2 thumbs down. Bauer in the Chron take note. Back to Little Star!
author: sean h.

description: This place is awesome. The food is amazing. I am vegetarian and they always mention that they will gladly make any pizza vegetarian. They add new (delicious) items to the menu often. They definitely have the best pizzas around. I would love to give this place a 5 star review, but I only have one gripe: they have the rudest host in town! I don't mind waiting a while for a table, but the host always seems as if she intends to discourage me from even waiting for a table. One time when I came in to put myself on the list, without greeting me, she told me to "hold on" while she took a personal phone call. For the price of the food at this place, I really expect more from the host. The food and the servers are great though!
author: Molly M.

description:
Great great great! Loved everything from the lovely service to the vibe of the place.  Warm olives are delicious.  Fig salad was perfectly dressed and all the flavors were present.  Roasted chicken was amazing and the pizza bianco was not only a surprise delight but one of the best pizzas i've ever had. 

Go here. You will be very glad you did! Thanks Ragazza. I will be back.
author: Mark B.

description:
Great pizza and service. There are long waits sometimes deservingly so but the blonde hostess provided us with some complimentary olives because of our troubles. 

Will go back again for sure.
author: Matthew M.

description: I've been here quite a few times, and every single time the chef and the server (usually Leah) have knocked it out of the park. One evening they were serving a sardine(esque?) appetizer that was completely out of this galaxy, literally not from this world it was so good. The sausage pizza and red onion piza is the best in my opinion. Oh and be sure to order it with three eggs! Yes, yes, I know it's a bit extreme but it's almost as if the yokes multiply the deliciousness of the pizza,  therefore the runnier the merrier. Also, the fact that they have Moretti is a good enough reason to try them out.
author: Nancy L.

description: I have to say, pizza can not get more perfect than this. The crust is thin and crispy but a little doughy too. And the combinations the chef comes up with are really creative. I will definitely go back again.... and again...
author: Carol B.

description:
meh.  

husband and i went early on a sunday night and walked right in to avoid long lines we typically see late in the evening.  server was nice and attentive, but totally fake (insert fake laugh here - "hahahahaha, you're so charming!"). ps i do not tip you based on your fake compliments to me.

i appreciate their variety of wine choices by quantity - we ordered a carafe of montepulciano for good value.

got the arugula and beet salad, and there was literally no dressing anywhere to be found.  no, i don't prefer a pool of dressing, but maybe just a little something to soften the peppery taste of arugula?

we split the pork belly with polenta cakes and then the mariquita pizza.
-the pork belly was so dry and polenta cakes were cold. boo.
-the mariquita pizza was good, but definitely tasted like a grilled cheese with bacon on it.  they could work out the ratios better.

skipped dessert.  finished our wine under the very watchful eye of the hostess who pointed at us and then (i assume because it was behind a menu held to her face) suggested to another walk-in customer  that we would be done soon.  so much for savoring those last few sips.

we won't go back.
author: Meaghan C.

description: Great pizza, very nice thin crust (had the Moto with sausage, mozzarella, onions, mushrooms, $16).  Tables are very intimately close to each other, but not a big problem although slightly awkward for the server to get to your table.  Hipster service (possibly disinterested because me and my boyfriend weren't ordering much?).  Pleased with the reservations though, hostess put me on the wait list and called when a table was ready.  Would go again for the pizza though... Mm-mmm!
author: Carolyn L.

description:
Came here with some friends for dinner. The Amatriciana pizza sounded good and the waitress mentioned it was their signature dish. We ordered that along with Basil Pesto, Moto and two appetizers. 

Amatriciana- Egg on a pizza was surprisingly good! Definitely recommend, seems pretty unique to this establishment.

Basil Pesto- The waitress mentioned this was a newer addition to their menu. Probably our least favorite pizza, a bit too oily.

Moto- Well spiced and flavorful. A solid pizza.

The wait time can get pretty long, we waited for about an hour. Since it is such a small restaurant, I would not suggest coming here with a large group.

One odd thing, they added gratuity for a party of four. First time I've seen that.
author: Nikhil V.

description: You call this a cannoli?  Shame on you!   I was really disappointed with Ragazza. The food is subpar and the prices are really high.   This place is a copy-cat establishment.   Service was decent, food was not.   Somehow dinner for two worked out to $80, which seemed pretty high for a fancy pizza joint.     Polenta was flavourless.  Cannoli needs some work. Wrapping a pizella around some sheeps ricotta does not a cannoli make.  Not to mention the ricotta filling was not quite right.  There was something off about the whole place.
author: Leeora B.

description: We went there last week Saturday around 7pm. We of course expected some wait time but when I got there I got ignored for about 5 min, my boyfriend was looking for parking. Finally after 5min the host came and said for 1? I said no for 2 please and asked about the wait time. He said around 45 min, I said ok for 2 then. He asked where the 2nd person is. I explained he is parking but the host said he has to be there to be put on the list. I asked so there is a 45min but we all have to be there to get on the waitlist. The host got annoyed and said, well it is a Saturday. It doesn't make sense to have the entire party there to get on a waitlist. And the host wasn't the nicest. We went to little star instead and got a table right away.
author: Anna K.

description: Far too pricey for the kind food and service.  Lots of Pizza's. salty!  Service was OK but  not great!  we ordered two glass of wine.  they served it in small glassed.  $12 for small glass of wine?  wow, the quantity of wine was 1/2 of what you normally expect in any restaurant.  they must be kidding.  I did not say anything  we are not going back.  The place is far too busy and crowded.  they really do not need my business!
author: Ron N.

description: Cozy little place off windy stretch of Divisadero. Margherita was sadly smothered in tomato sauce that was actually higher than the dough in the middle, that made it both immediately soggy and cold. There was hardly any cheese on the pizza and that was definitely not fresh mozzarella which does not form plasticky patches, but luckily there were just few of those. I've tried other pizza options before, and while they work in "I put the odd stuff I found in my fridge on the pizza and look it turned out OK" way, having them as a mainstay on the menu is kind of lame. Pizza dough itself is not bad, even if on the salty side.
author: Maya N.

description:
3.5 stars.
The service was really friendly. The hostess told us the wait was 30-40 minutes but was able to seat us really quickly and apologized for the wrong wait time.
They have a beautiful garden. It'll be awesome when they start letting people eat out there.
I wanted an appetizer but wasn't really feeling the selection.
The Amatriciana was best of the three pies we ordered. I loved the strong bite to it.
The Margherita was a bit heavy on the sauce.
Moto was alright, slightly bland compared to the Amatriciana. The pies came out super fast. 
We'd all consider going back there. It's the best pizza place in the neighborhood+Sunset.
author: Jen Y.

description: I went there last Saturday to give them a second chance. We got in at 6:45, 1/3rd the rest is empty and hostess won't tell us how long it will take for the table of two. In general their staff is very rude, I do realize they are busy/popular just say sorry we can't accommodate you tonight.
author: Subhash J.

description:
This place was such a huge disappointment. 

I adore Pizza.  I have family in Naples, Rome.  I have sought out some delicious west coast pizzas at Pizzaiolo in Oakland, Pizetta 211 in the Inner Richmond.  There are some great Italian style pizzas out there to be had.  But the pizza at Ragazza was a monstrosity.  My Italian came out and I could only think of what a monstrosity the crust was.  In Italy, the secret to ones pizza is the dough recipe... you couldn't call this dough.  It was like a cracker, burnt to a crisp.  

i am a firm believer that dough should have some softness to it, so that it can absorb and carry the flavor of the toppings.  This dough you could pick up in the middle, like a cracker, and overpowered all of the ingredients with a burnt smell.

The arugula salad was small and uninteresting

The service was quick and attentive, I will give them that.  But it was not enough to bring the review up to 2 stars.  The pizza was so bad I would have rather sent it back and left the restaurant.  If you like the taste of burnt crackers, then this is your thing.
author: Alona E.

description: A must place to visit in San Francisco.  They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait.  Their fresh, simple ingredients are true to Neopolitan cuisine.
author: Raquel V.

description: Love at first sight with Ragazza. i was craving "pizza, antipasti and wine by the carafe" on a recent weeknight when we hit this place up. the food is delicious, the prices are fair and the staff is very friendly. their buratta is one of the best in the city, and the cannolis! oh my. and yes the pizza is good too :) cant wait to go back
author: Carolina S.

description:
wow, this is some good pizza.  i have always liked gialina, but i think the pizza at ragazza is even better.  the crust is so thin and crispy.  i have no idea how they do it!  two of us shared the moto and wild nettle pizzas and we were able to leave w/ leftovers.  i'll move up to this 5 stars after i try more items. 

parking in the neighborhood sucks.  that's the only downfall.
author: Helen T.

description: Out of this world! Everything we had was deelicious and perfect! Can't wait to get back there and prove my self right! :)
author: M S.

description: The pizza is great as well as the pig platter. The service was friendly and fast and make sure to get the deserts! They have a nice, focused menu, and the food they make is all around pretty good.
author: Hugo K.

description:
I stopped in on  Wednesday at about 7pm.  The place was busy, but just being one person I was able to grab a seat at the bar space.  

I started off with the lamb meatballs appetizer.  The meatballs were very good.  The delicate innocence of the lamb was complimented by the aged provolone and delicious tomato sauce...or something.  I would have liked the dish served a little bit warmer, but it wasn't off enough for me to send it back.

Pizza: exactly what I wanted, and this was excellent pizza.  I ordered the pork belly with tomato sauce, red onion, spicy Calabrian chilies & farmer's pecorino.  So very good.  The pizza would certainly feed two; I had half left over to take home and I am looking forward to having it for lunch.  The crust was perfectly thin, and the outer crust was bubbly, flaky, deliciousness.

The service was great and attentive.  I didn't feel as though I was lingering two long between portions.

I thought the prices were fine and not out of line with reality.

I will certainly be back!
author: Jason S.

description:
VVSP and I made our first visit to Ragazza last night.  I'd heard very good things about it and we were eager to give it a try.  Every bit of the experience exceeded our expectations.  Our server was superb--friendly, attentive, engaged, impressive knowledge of the wine as well as the food (shout out to Grace).  We started with the large arugula/beet/shaved fennel/lovely goat cheese/pistachio salad.  When Grace brought us an enormous wooden salad bowl for us to share, I was sure we wouldn't be able to finish it--wrong; it was much too good to let go to waste.  We shared a pizza with nettles, pancetta, Portobello mushrooms, provolone, and a lovely egg on top in which to dip our slices.  It may have been the best pizza I've ever had in my life.  The crust is rustic, tasty and toothsome.  (By the way, Gene M., some of us love those burned bubbles in the crust--it's a GOOD thing.)  The toppings melded perfectly, both the flavors and textures.  Our wine was yummy, and our server Grace described it perfectly.  

We will be back--again and again and again.
author: Earline A.

description: Not a bad spot for Italian. Several appetizers, pasta dishes and pizza's to choose from. Reasonably priced wines and desserts too. They were out of the asparagus, so we had the beet & avocado salad to start which was a good size and really yummy. I went with a friend so we split our appetizer, the pork pasta (I think this was my favorite) and a pizza with potatoes, cheese, red onion and bacon on it. We were so full when we finished that we took our cheesecake to go. Everything we had was good. Its best to call ahead, put your name in and shack up somewhere close by. There is nowhere to wait inside and this prevents standing around on the sidewalk. I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Shanna T.

description: Great pizzas with a big-ass crust but that's okay because the crust is light and delicious. The sides are also tasty.
author: m t.

description: I am IM-pressed. I've been twice now and got different pizzas both times that I loved. The pizza with chanterelle mushrooms is my fave and also the sauteed broccoli rabe in garlic. Casual, friendly service. The desserts were so good too.
author: Lucy M.

description: Amazing pizza.  The crust, toppings are all top notch.  Good luck finding a thinner crust.  Better than Delfina by a long sight.
author: Otto D.

description:
I had an experience that was not likely the typical one, so I will give this place another shot.  That said, it went like this:

We walked in and the place was very pleasing to the eyes and nose, almost like I'd been here before.  Sitting down and looking at the menu, I realize I had: the layout, menu, even the black and white photos on the wall were pretty much a carbon copy of Gialina in Glenn Park.  "Same owners?," we wondered.

We ordered the warm olives and blood orange salad for appetizers.  They looked wonderful, but were a little off.  The greens in the salad were....a little too tough, frankly.  It was the difference between greens that are appropriate for a salad and those that were straight off of a lawn after a day of gardening.  It was like Gialina, but not.  A little off.

Next, the pizzas arrived.  They are large and wonderful to look at, but I think they were just ok.  I got the Rabini/Potato/Leek/Sausage pizza, and my wife the Bacon/Brussels Sprouts pizza.  My potatoes were literally tasteless, and overall I did not think the flavors meshed well together.  Likewise, the textures were a little too tough, the portions of the toppings a little too large.  It was kind of like a Gialina pizza (or Peccino, or or or), but a little off.  Neither of us really enjoyed our pies.

With a single glass of wine, our bill totaled about $60 without tip.  The pies are definitely large enough for two people to share.

The place was rockin', so again, I imagine we just had a strange combo of things we ordered.
author: Rob P.

description: Ragazza is a wonderful addition to the neighborhood. The pizzas are great, though I tend to like the salads at Ragazza the most. The wait time is biggest negative, but otherwise, it's worth it.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Ragazza is yet another great addition to the area!!

Metro Kathmandu was one of my absolute favorite places in SF, so I thought it would be difficult to like a business that went into their old space. But, the food is fantastic!

The braised greens with bacon, goat cheese and breadcrumbs are absolutely fabulous!! Its a very flavorful dish and great for sharing. But the pork belly is my favorite dish!! The figs and pistachios make it pure heaven. The braised short ribs leave a bit to be desired. The dish tastes great, but is very heavy on pasta and light on meat. When I ordered it, I wasn't expecting a bowl of pasta, I thought it would be meat with some pasta. The Moto pizza has a ton of flavor and a little kick of spice which is great!! The sausage pizza is also delish. For dessert they have two daily selections of bi-rite ice cream... you can't go wrong with that! But the ricotta cheesecake is something you should not miss. The wine selection is good and reasonably priced. Our server seemed knowledgeable about the selection and directed us to a wine that we loved. If you don't want to eat a ton of pasta and pizza, there are a few selections on the Antipasti menu that should keep you satisfied, but Ragazza is definitely for the carb lovers.

Service was a little touch and go. At times our server was very attentive, and other times we didn't see her for a while. I'm not too crazy about the new decor in the space. It just doesn't have the warm feeling from the Metro days. In a few months they will open the patio, which is hands down, one of the best outdoor restaurant spaces in the city. It's super cozy and well landscaped. 

I'm looking forward to dining here again and think this will end up being one of my neighborhood staples.
author: Kandace K.

description: So good. Lovely little place with a pretty awesome patio out back. I've never had the pizza, but the antipasti and roasts are consistently delicious. Service is great.
author: Danielle L.

description: Great service, great food! Lemme rephrase that superb service, both at door and at the table And superb food! Long queues though
author: Ethan H.

description: I really love Ragazza. It makes me feel like I'm not in SF -- it has a back east feel/smell to it (to me at least). I find it to be a perfect cozy date spot: pizza, sharing a carafe of wine... The Atomic pizza (the Moto w/out the meat) & an Arugula salad is a nice combo to share. The Nutella pizza is the only item I've had there that was a miss. The tiramisu is heaven; the dessert wine & port are also very nice.
author: Lynn m.

description: The secret garden gazebo was amazing, very quaint and beautiful.  Had the fried arancini and arugula salad with beets, both very good.  Also ordered two pies, the Amatriciana and potato.  Excellent!  Intimate restaurant.
author: Laura A.

description: Hit or miss. Heard it was good from a friend who lives nearby. Our pizzas were both just above room temp. You could see that they had been sitting around for some time. Staff was ambivalent. Might have just been a busy night.
author: Colin S.

description: We waited 90min for the pies here. Small resto, quaint, great service. We ordered the pork belly salad, figs barley salad, sardines, seafood linguini and 4 different pizzas. To be honest, everything was amazing until we got to the pizzas, I love the thin crust, flavor was good but it wasn't great. Tony's pizza still has my favorite Margherita pizza. Food was tasty but definitely wouldn't wait 90min for a table.
author: Ennie L.

description:
I went back for a second time this past Saturday. Just as good as the first time. 

The baked rigatoni with butternut squash - uh-mazing. The polenta dish - great as well. The pizzas are uniformly excellent. Had the chocolate truffle cake for dessert - perfection, not too heavy at all. 

I believe our bill (for two people) came out to only 80 dollars or so - for that amount, we got four dishes (one being a pizza) and a carafe of wine. Not bad at all. Great service, too - it was a busy Saturday night, and we weren't rushed through our meal at all.

Eager to go back and try more dishes. I'm committed to working my way through the entire menu.
author: Robert M.

description: The pizza had a nice crisp crust, but in some bites I felt like I was getting a mouthful of flour. The atmosphere is pretty nice, and when I was there it was a nice mix of customers, from families to date nights to older people. I had a nice time, but I don't know if I'll make a big point of coming back--and since they don't take reservations, I might not make the effort.
author: George L.

description: I'm gonna go with a 5 overall because I've had such consistently good food and service, with a minimal wait.  This is quickly becoming my favorite go-to restaurant.  The pies are always fresh and delicious, the pastas have been fantastic and I absolutely love their salads.  Fresh, seasonal, just great overall.  The service is undeniably good for San Francisco.  Maybe we've lucked out with Lea (?) as our server most of the times we've been... I just LOVE her.  This is a perfect place for a casual date night or for a small group of friends.
author: Kasie V.

description: Stayed at the Metro Hotel above the restaurant. Loved the hotel and the wild nettle pizza. Out server suggested we get it with and panchetta and boy was it good.
author: kirsten Q.

description: Another neighborhood gem. This used to be a French restaurant with terrible service and hit or miss food. Now it's a gourmet pizza place with great service and a nice selection of inexpensive wine. I recommend getting any of the pies, a salad, and a bottle of wine (you can easily split the small salad). I'm giving it a 4 instead of 5 because I think some of the other dishes are a bit pricey and not worth it.
author: Jason P.

description: Walked in on a rainy Fri night with the lady, wait for a table was an hour. Luckily the wonderful girl at the door was able to squeeze us in in 30 mins. Space is tight so we walked over to Bar Crudo to hang with the boys. The hostess was nice enough to take our number and give us a ring when the table was ready. Everything on the menu looked worthy of trying but we decided to go with the Polenta, Monk fish and Moto pie, was sent out a Stracchiatella. Everything was great but the pie was a stand out. The crust, the sauce, the sausage all seasoned, prepared very well. Only two things were a miss, the bread for the Stracchiatella was not toasted and the server had suggested we put an egg on the pie, which we thought was a good idea, but it never came out. Didn't want to fuss so didn't mention it. Overall great meal. Will be back for that egg!
author: I D.

description: I could eat here every night.  Absolutely my favorite pizza place in town, and I've eaten at 'em all.  That Amatriciana is incredible, I never would have thought that an egg on a RED sauce pizza would be so good, but it is just the best.  Always packed, but I do the early-bird special thing and skip lunch, then come at 5:30 when they open.  By 6:00 it's always full.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
- food: excellent
- atmosphere: cozy quarters
- price: reasonable
- staff: extra nice

additional info:
- it's worth the wait for the table
author: J. B.

description:
Don't go here. So that I can get a table.

Don't order the nettle pizza. I'd hate for them to run out before I got mine.

Great wine menu, woodburning pizza oven, loud and crowded, friendly staff, and super accommodating to leaving the meat off a pizza for us vegetarian types. 

Want the secret? Get your food to go. Tastes just as good if you aren't in the mood to wait an hour for a table.
author: T. C.

description: The people whining on here are either cheap or don't understand how a restaurant works. I had an fantastic evening with amazing food. 5 stars. Will return.
author: Duncan H.

description: I work across the street and have come here for a business dinner as well as a couple of dates with my boyfriend and every time has been wonderful. Love the small place with great food. I will continue to support this local gem :)
author: Emily L.

description:
Pizza is hard to rate since I love it so much and it generally always tastes pretty good.  that being said, in the last 3 week's i've tried Tony's in North Beach, Zero Zero and Ragazza.

I have to say my wife and i thought that Ragazza's pizza was the best of all 3.  It just feels the freshest and has the best balance of crust that is chewy but also crispy (my wife never eats the crust but ate all of them here).

we ate about 1.5 pies.  tried the margherita and the romo (the one with mushrooms and sausage).

i always ask the question, would i come here again and usually the answer for most places is no.  for ragazza, the answer is a resounding yes.  i want to try out the other pies.

up next, una pizza (forget the name) on harrison.
author: ed p.

description: I don't usually like pizza but it was incredible. They have unique combinations you would never think of! Who knew an egg sunny side up would go so great with pizza!
author: Megan E.

description: Two stars for the food. Zero for the service. The blonde waitress that waited on us made me want to serve myself she was so annoying. Entrees coming out 10 minutes apart also didn't help. And what the hell is an Italian restaurant without fresh baked BREAD? Are you kidding me? $70 for two tiny entrees, 2 glasses of wine and a sm shared salad and my leaving the restaurant hungry. No thanks, we'll be heading back to Uva down the street.
author: Stephen B.

description: Fantastic pizza, great atmosphere, long wait (I've heard). We got in within 10 minutes though, relatively early on a Saturday night. Our server seemed a bit impatient with our drink orders (we wanted to try a wine or two, and she seemed annoyed by this).  She also steered us away from even trying the prosecco, saying it was bad. Most of our food was great though, including braised brussell sprouts with pancetta, and two pies cooked perfectly and with the right proportion of toppings and seasoning. The "pork cakes" were simply strange--we were trying to be adventurous, but this dish fell flat--essentially cooked shredded pork covered in bread crumbs and fried, served with a celeriac puree and balsamic reduction. The pork was somewhat dry and the texture overall unusual. I'd definitely return for the pizza though.
author: Timothy V.

description: I rarely rate 5 stars but this place deserves it! The service has been an absolute joy every time I've come here. The wait averages 45 minutes, but if you have the chance to sit at the bar, do it.  Regardless of the pizza you order, I recommend adding in the fried egg on top, it is delicious! Salads are fresh, their wines are all Italian, and their nutella pizza is overwhelmingly rich (even for a chocolate lover), so this is definitely a dessert to share. Come here early and enjoy!
author: Gloria C.

description: The kale salad was good but the pizza needed more. It was too thin and didn't hold up well with a heavy egg in the middle. Favor profile was lacking in the pizza too. Try the kale!
author: Lan N.

description: A nice place to be. Pork shoulder is overhyped by staff -- it was straight dry. Pizza was good.
author: Guillermo K.

description: Really delicious thin crust pizza on par with Pizzeria Delfina at a cute neighborhood joint. Friendly waitstaff. Cute decor. Yummy!
author: Kari J.

description: Finally ventured through the doors of Ragazza on a dreary Wednesday evening after having walked by many times before. Four of us were able to waltz right in with no reservation to find ourselves instantly seated at the back bar. While we just ordered appetizers and wine, our server did not express any resentment for our lack of a traditional meal. Instead she was very friendly, helpful and knowledgeable about the menu, providing insight to their diverse wine list. The ambiance was modern yet cozy and after a delicious meal we were able to split the bill a few different ways no problem. While I think we may have lucked out with an open table, I would highly recommend this place with a reservation. I'm itching to go back to try their delicious looking and veggie-loaded pizzas.
author: Paul M.

description: Get the Bianca. Best pizza I've had, ever. The service is just okay which is why this isn't a five. Otherwise pretty nice interior.
author: Paul I.

description: I came here last night.  It was raining and cold.  The place was packed but the lovely hostess said it would be about 10 mins and she was right!  The place is small, cute and cozy.  My husband and I ordered the soft polenta and the root veggies.  Delicious!  We also ordered the Moto-tomato pizza which was also very tasty along with a carafe of wine.  I really liked this place.  Food was good, services was great, prizes where good and its in the hood.  Definitely would go back.
author: chloe b.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant. Pizzas are delish! Always hopping, everyday of the week. Show up early to ensure a shorter wait time.
author: Courtney M.

description: Salads are excellent. Love the pizza.  Thin, crisp crusts with a bubbly edge.  Great filings as well.  I especially liked the bianco, which cam with cheese, lemon, arugula and garlic.  The deserts were mixed.  The ricotta cheesecake was brilliant, with a creamy topping. The tiramisu tasted good, but the ladyfingers were a bit hard.  Wonderful friendly service.
author: p w.

description: My wife and I went in to Ragazza on a Tuesday at 5:30pm, and there was no wait at all, so that was a good start to our night.  The arancini looked really good on the menu, but we heard our waitress tell another party that the pizza was larger than personal size, so we had to pass on the appetizers to try the pizza we had heard so much about. We had the Amatriciana and Potato pizzas, and both were delicious.  We loved the tomato sauce on the Amatriciana pizza, and all the toppings were good, especially the egg on top.  The potato pizza also had a great cheese and nice chunks of bacon on it, which we really enjoyed. What we appreciated most was the size of the pizzas, which were much larger than most of the other good pizza places in SF.  We took home four slices of pizza (each pizza had 6 slices), which we enjoyed re-heated the next day.  Service was good, and a lot of things on the menu looked very tempting. We will definitely be back, and we're happy we found another go-to pizza place in SF.
author: Pilan C.

description: Just exquisite. Some amazing takes on artisanal pizzas. Definitely add an egg to your favorite if it doesn't come with one, and spread the yolk the moment it arrives or it will cook where it sits in the pizza. Marvelous appetizers and professional, effective staff. A reservation is worth it. Highly recommended.
author: Josh And Jeff C.

description: Service just so-so, but pizza and salads are BRILLIANT.  Thin-crisp crust pizza with good char, tangy sauce and not too much cheese.  Blood orange salad with fennel was dee-lish.  Roasted brussell sprouts were good but a bit rich from the lardo that melted into the dish a bit too much.  Otherwise, Gialina, part deux -- RAWKS!
author: Don N.

description:
At first thought - did we need another pizza place on divis?  And one in the restaurant spot that never stays open?  But good luck and good cuisine has found a home.

At first dine - feels like an upscale-ish pizzateria in Rome.  The fried egg addition on many dishes is great; nice wine list.  I didnt have the butternut squash pasta but having seen it made I know it will be in my future.  1 less star for the fact that Bob Marley & the Wailers played on repeat and that the last 2 cannolis got taken before we ordered.
author: M M.

description: Finally, an excellent pizza place in SF -- and in our neighborhood to boot.  Prices were reasonable, pizza was amazing, salad was scrumptious, service was just fine.  I'd go back and plan to often...  My other favorite pizza (not the place, just the za) is still Orgasmica.  I've tried dozens of others but only these two suite my palette for good pizza in SF.
author: S G.

description: Yum! We had the asparagus with green garlic and fried egg pizza and it was so so good. Didn't really need anything else, besides a couple glasses of wine. The crust was very thin and the toppings were savory. The only problem here is the wait. But we put our name in and then spent the waiting period down the street at Vinyl, the wine bar (which I would also strongly recommend). Seemed that several parties were doing the same thing. Great atmosphere, and there was a public notice that they will soon be opening a back patio.
author: Emma S.

description: Ragazza is a real nice treat for some classic thin crusted, wood fired pizza. Also they have excellent side and main entree dishes too. I must advice to get the large salad because it's really big and really good!
author: Ethan S.

description: This restaurant had no cheese on their pizza.  But I can live with that.  What I can't live with is that they charged us a $3.00 "service charge" for absolutely no apparent reason.  Then when we asked the waitress about it she told us that it was a mandatory health insurance fee charge for San Francisco employees.  BULL$$$$.  So I looked into it, and it turns out this is a great little scam that a lot of high end San Francisco restaurants have begun profitting from.  Most of these restaurants never even use a penny of the money for health insurance for their employees.  They pocket the money.  This level of greed deserves nothing more than 1 star, even if the food is amazing.  Which it isn't.   Open your eyes fellow yelpers, and take a stand against greed.  Don't eat here until they take off that ridiculous charge of $1.00 per guest ObamaCare style fascist socialism fee, which takes advantage of the liberal left sympathies of San Franciscans for an extra thousands of dollars in profits per month.
author: dom j.

description: Everyone I know consistently raves about Ragazza's sister restaurant, Gialina's, but I think that the food at Ragazza is actually a notch above the Glen Park sibling. I have been here 4 times now and consistently had DELICIOUS pizza, creative & fresh, and so good that you want to eat the whole thing. The crust is always thin and crispy and the balance of salt & flavors is always excellent. Last weekend it was so crowded and the wait so long that my partner & I just ordered a pizza to go and ate it outside on the bench in front of their window. The host was so sweet to us and actually brought us glasses of water outside, as if we were actually being seated out there. Only drawback is that they don't take reservations.
author: emily Z.

description: Sister restaurant to Gialina pizza in bernal heights so it's tied w/ gialina as my favorite pizza in the city.  Ragazza might have a slight edge over Gialina due to its location for me.
author: LT B.

description: It's a damned shame, given that it's in my n'hood and I LOVE Gialina, but there are several things off here. Been a few times now (I keep hoping it gets better) and the service has always been somewhere between eh and rude (not the hostesses, they've always been lovely and helpful). At Gialina the servers handle the small space and the lines with charm and grace. Not so here. You get the sense they'd rather you hadn't come. Also, I'm not sure why, but the pizzas aren't as good as Gialina's. The crust is often soggy. And don't waste $20 on any of the "large" salads. They're good, but they ain't large, and you end up feeling ripped off. Not going again.
author: Hopey N.

description: The food is impeccable - among the best meals I have had in San Francisco.  But the service is slipshod at best, and dramatically diminished the evening for us.  The rigatoni with squash was fabulous, the chicory salad with pomegranate seeds and persimmons was inspired, the polenta was flawless and the ricotta cheesecake was sublime.  Alas, it took a good 10 minutes, and many efforts at flagging down staff, to order a second glass of wine.  And to pay the check, we walked up to the service counter after waiting 20 minutes for our wait-person to attend to it.  My friend predicted this place will not last because of the total lack of professionalism.  I would love to eat there again, but only if I have the whole evening free, and much more patience than I had tonight.
author: Steve S.

description: Owner called me after reading my review and offered me $20 to cover the soft pours. Good form, although I will not take them up on this, it was the right thing to do. This place is getting their feet under them, but they seem like they intend to have a great restaurant.
author: D M.

description: Great addition to the hood. i love this place. Potato w/ erbette was awesome. also got the Boccalone Italian Sausage. which was also killer. the service was top notch. i cant wait to try more of the menu.
author: Jorge E.

description: Ragazza has some of the best pizza I've ever had, but what makes this place so amazing is that you can walk up and get a table with almost no fuss, hassle or wait, even on the weekends. Places like this are hard to come by, and I hope to eat here many many times before its popularity finally matches the amazing quality of its food.
author: Brian D.

description:
I will not eat here again. I went to this place several months ago, and it was pretty good. The brussel sprout pizza was great, actually. They server was someone we knew from the neighborhood so perhaps that's why it went so well. So well, in fact that I decided to go again on Feb 25th for my birthday. Big mistake. 

The menu had changed and everything we had enjoyed the last time was gone. That was not a big deal as we thought we could find something else that was good. My friend ordered the pork belly pizza. Epic fail. It arrived drowning in a pool of grease. I know that pork belly is fatty, but there was so much grease under this pizza that my friend literally poured it onto an appetizer plate to get rid of it. There must have been an 1/8 of an inch of grease. Not a few drips but a puddle that was able to be poured. Not really what she expected.

 Another guest ordered the lamb belly. Something was very wrong with the sauce it came in. Very wrong. This was not a situation where it was just not to his liking but one where someone in the kitchen either added something that had gone bad to the sauce or accidentally used an ingredient they should not have used. I dont know but we all tasted it and all agreed that it was not edible. He sent it back. Then my pizza arrived with the fried egg in the center that I had specifically said needed to be left off when I ordered it. When I said something, the server immediately recalled that yes I had said "no egg". Perhaps it was the kitchen or maybe it was the fact that the server wrote nothing down when we all ordered.  I dont know. I do know that at my birthday dinner I got to watch everyone else eat and then, after everyone else had finished, and they were outside enjoying their cigarettes, I was finally served my pizza 45 minutes after I should have gotten it. Thats right, I got my dinner a long time after the other people I was with had finished and were getting ready to leave.  It was a really really disappointing meal that we ended up paying hundreds of dollars for because there was 6 of us.  The people at the table were not exactly thrilled to throw down about $90 each for a meal where so many things were bad or had gone wrong. I dont know if it was just an off night or what the deal was but this was not good and they have lost me as a customer as well as all the people who were with me.
author: angela j.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and really want to like this place, but I'm still not completely sold. I've been twice now, and maybe I've just ordered the wrong things. I found the Asparagus Pizza to be really bland and unsavory. Also had a couple of the appetizers which I also found to be mediocre (the pickled veggies were just plain awful and didn't even taste pickled-- more like just sitting in a pool of vinegar). I've heard other people rave about the other pies, so I look forward to trying something different in the future.

In terms of service... the place was packed when we arrived around 8:30pm on a Tuesday night. There were only 2 servers/hosts on, which made the experience feel quite rushed. It's a pet peeve of mine to go to a restaurant where you're willing to spend a pretty penny (our bill was just over $100), feel rushed with each course being thrown down onto the table, and then struggle to even make eye contact with the server. We ordered a bottle of wine and about 5 dishes (pizza included), and were out in less than 45 minutes. Way too fast!

I'll likely be back because it's so close to my house, and I really, really want to support the neighborhood. Perhaps Ragazza just needs a few more months to find its own?
author: gilly h.

description:
Unless you like dining with screeching hipsters in your lap, I'd steer clear.  My friend was super-excited to go here late on a Friday evening, so we waited the obligatory 30 minutes for a table.  The tables are jammed ridiculously close together that you literally have to ask your neighbors to move their table temporarily so you can squeeze by.  And despite some styrofoam panels glued to the ceiling, it's hella-loud.  We had the added joy of a table of drunken hipsters screaming to each other right next to us, that was a nice touch.

Most of that can be forgiven if the food is exceptional, but alas our pizza, recommended by the waiter, was pretty blah - super-salty and not a lot of flavor.  And the $9 salad was an embarrassingly small portion.  The pizza did have a really good crust, but other than that there's nothing that would make me want to return - it's over-priced and way too loud & jammed.
author: Jeff P.

description:
i love pizza and i think the bar keeps getting raised here in SF. although i will always be partial to Little Star for my deep dish and i still love Lu Lu's thin crust this place has killer pizza. the service is excellent and friendly and all our other dishes were also great. 
don't be too intimidated by any crowd you may see outside it goes pretty fast.
author: michelle m.

description: Delicious ! Sorry it's so small of a place because the wait is long but we had a great experience.
author: OC 2.

description: The amatriciana pizza is probably the best pizza in the city. It's the sauce that really sets it apart, although the pancetta and the egg don't hurt. Knocking off a star because we thought the service was a little lacking, both from the hostess and our waitress. I've heard similar comments from others who have dined there. The amatriciana is crazy good, though, so it's well worth it.
author: Brian C.

description: just as good as gialina.  the service was wonderful.  great wine.  delicious fig and arugula salad.  the sauce on the amatriciana is so yummy.  the rigatoni is pretty darn good as well.  parking in this hood is terrible....
author: a g.

description: I really, really want to love this place. It's cozy, has really nice and knowledgeable people working there and the pizzas look so good and thin. Unfortunately, each time I've been, the flavor is just lacking on the pizza (salads and apps were great!) I want to try the wild nettle pizza because I've heard great things but each time I've been, it hasn't been on the menu. I'll give it one more try and hope I can have a 5 start experience.
author: Emily R.

description: Worst service ever. Called to put our name on the list n finally received a call back telling us our table was ready.  We live across the street and had already headed down so literally made it there in 30 seconds. The snotty hostess proceeded to tell us we were just waiting for a table to leave - a table who hadn't even received their bill yet and who proceeded to order a BOTTLE of wine! What a joke. Get your reservation system figured out and don't act so entitled. The food definitely wasn't worth waiting for.
author: Anne W.

description: I've been here twice, and the first time the white pizza was probably my favorite in SF. The second time it was good but not as amazing.
author: Max D.

description: Kind service, tasty bites and affordable. We had a group of 6,  we arrived early...split 3 pizzas and some apps and everyone had a drink and we were out of there for 25 each! The interior design is sharp yet simple like the food, worth checking out and I reckon would act as nice spot for a chill night with a friend/friends or a date night.
author: Laney O.

description: Much improved! I have always liked the good here....the pizza and pasta are tops.  But the front of the house was horrible.  but they have new people up front now and my last two times here have been top notch.  they will call you when your table is ready etc.  wait service has always been okay.  now that they have the front of the house working well, give it a try.
author: James A.

description:
Last night's simple pizza dinner at Ragazza was exceptional. We ordered two pizzas - the chanterelle mushroom and the wild nettles, along with a blood orange and fennel salad. The meal as a whole was the perfect combination of rustic and refined - simple ingredients but of excellent quality. What totally won me over was the pizza crust! Perfectly thin and crisp, with a gorgeous brown edge. I love crust and resent other pizzerias that feel compelled to char the crust edge to a crisp. 

There was no wait at all for counter service at 7:30PM but the restaurant was pleasantly busy on a cool Monday night. Our service was fine, nothing exceptional but absolutely good enough. Sitting at the counter makes ordering difficult because you get the first glance of everything coming out of the kitchen, and it all looks great. I can't wait to go back and explore their menu. It would be fun to go with a small group.
author: Lena B.

description:
We went there with another couple - 2 pizzas were fine for the 4 of us.  The chanterelle pizza was very good, but the wild nettles with preserved lemon pizza was truly outstanding - one of the best pizzas I've had anywhere.  (According to our waitress, it's really popular with the fried egg on top - we didn't have the courage to try it that way.)

We're vegetarian, and there's a good selection, especially the combination pizzas with meat can be done vegetarian.
author: Harold E.

description: Pizza - love and hate relationship. LOVE it but of course you can't eat it for every meal. This pizza I would eat for every meal and just not care (well that is what my boyfriend says). It is that good. The Bianca pizza and the beet salad are my favorites on this menu. Worth the drive from North Beach! They also do take out.
author: Rachel S.

description: What a great cozy little place! Upon walking up to the door we saw a few small parties waiting outside and were afraid we'd be in for a bit of a wait ourselves. That was hardly the case. They had a 2 seater table all set & ready. What a start to our experience. The menu is small and simple & it wasn't very hard to decide on what our palates were targeting. We ordered the antipasto (platter perfect for 2, maybe even 3), the farro salad (this by far was my favorite on the table, the fresh sweet summer peaches is what really hooked me), as for the pies....we had the Pork Belly w/ Summer squash, Calabrian chilies, tomato, red onion & farmer's pecorino and the Fiorelli Squash Blossoms w/ sweet white corn & Moliterno truffled pecorino. Both had a does of 2 fresh farm eggs bubbling on top. Everything was outstanding. We left ecstatic, full & already planning our next stop in.  I'd love to go back before the menu takes a slight seasonal change and if I do miss that I don't doubt they'll be replacing some of the items I was eyeballing with menu items just as pleasing.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I am happy to say that up until today I have been a yelp "virgin" but after dining at Ragazza last night I decided that I needed to share with all of you my wonderful experience.
Food was unreal, we had mixed lettuces salad with pomegranate seeds, velvety goat cheese and persimmons, followed by braised greens with bacon, crispy breadcrumbs and more goat cheese. Alexis our server was amazing, bubbly knowledgeable, attentive, and all around excited to be there. We noticed her interacting with the table beside us with a bunch of wild kids, and she was just as kind to them, offering to show the lil ones the garden out back while the parents took a breather!
we finished our meal with the nettles pizza suggested by our server... I literally feel asleep thinking about it, dreamt about it and woke up to eat the piece we brought home for breakfast.. the crust, cheese, onions and nettles all worked beautifully together and I cannot wait to go back..
there are a ton of new pizza places popping up around the city, but take my advice, if you want to be blown away by food and service, Ragazza is the place to be..
author: sonny r.

description: Ragazza is the kind of restaurant that makes me want to stand up and shout "I love food!" Such care was taken in the choice of ingredients, the preparation, and the presentation of the food, I loved every bit of it. I arrived about 20 minutes before the rest of my party, but the hostess was totally cool about it and put my name at the top of the list. I sat at the bar and enjoyed a lovely glass of Pigato and watched the cooks prepare the pizzas while I waited. The atmosphere is cozy and hip.
